card.desc: Glockchain is a connected firearms that captures precise data and posts it on a blockchain to ensure transparency and immutability.
card.thumbAlt: A connected firearm prototype opened to show how it works

content.body: Glockchain enables police firearms to capture precise data and post it on a blockchain to ensure transparency and immutability. Time and location of events, including holster unlocks and trigger pulls, as well as the identity of the officer handling the firearm are stored in real time.  Both the device and the raw data have value, which will be owned by police departments and available for interested parties (journalists, governments, etc) through smart contract subscriptions.
content.calloutBody: How might we automate transparency in life and death scenarios?
insights: Police adoption of firearm usage is less controversial than civilian adoption
Privatizing select pieces of data on a public blockchain leads to unexplored technical challenges
Accurate and immutable data from an incident eases burden of filing reports for officers
Officers are interested in concept of devices with selective users
content.title: Transparency pays in gun safety

card.desc: Fraction allows buying and selling fractional shares in real estate, allowing people to sell part of their home equity - as well as invest in properties with as little as $100.
card.thumbAlt: The fraction prototype at our biannual blueprint event

content.body: Fraction is a platform for buying and selling fractional shares in residential real estate, allowing homeowners to sell part of the equity in their homes and others to invest in individual properties with as little as $100. Though we are no longer pursuing Fraction as a venture at this time, the learnings around new asset creation and market creation continue to inform other CoLab prototypes.
content.calloutBody: What types of markets will exist for assets that were previously too expensive or cumbersome to exchange?
insights: A house is a Home, not an Investment
High barrier to entry for investment in real-estate
People prefer not knowing about, or having responsibility for, simultaneous transactions
content.title: New Ownership Models

Ownership in companies increases customer loyalty
Lowering the barrier for investments given that micro-transactions are possible and the law allows it

card.desc: Litmus providing access to peer-to-peer transactions with small companies to help build reputation.

content.body: Litmus is a tool for freelancers that secures payment and builds reputation by providing access to peer-to-peer transactions with small companies. In a world where freelancing is rapidly becoming the new norm, Litmus provides a way for designers and creative contractors to build a subjective reputation and grow their business online.  Using a transparent blockchain, Litmus ensures accountability on both ends of the exchange, helping to ensure quality work for the client and assure payment for the freelancer.

insights: P2P Reviews can strengthen web of trust through “word of mouth”
Collaborative economy & freelancing are growing
Existing negotiations and working relationships are strained
Reputation is stability

card.desc: Nomad is our open source, protocol-level project that enables easy, open information discovery, remixing, composing, and sharing.
card.thumbAlt: An image of the visualization of the smart grid prototype.

content.body:
Nomad is a decentralized system for subscribing to, processing, and publishing data in the form of ordered message streams. Nomad is decentralized: there are no message brokers through which messages pass. Nomad uses IPFS to create a peer-to-peer network of nodes that routes messages from publisher to subscriber. Streams are published by nodes which are identified by a public key hash, making Nomad a permissionless system. Anyone can create a new node, subscribe to existing streams, and publish a stream without signing up for any proprietary service. Data is a beautiful thing, but it's too hard to share live data, to process data and share real time insights, or to connect visualizations to live data. Nomad draws from the likes of stream processing systems like Apache Kafka but adds a healthy dose of decentralization to create a global system of durable but lightweight data pipes that anyone can build on top of.

Github repo
content.calloutBody: A decentralized platform for open data streams built on IPFS
content.title: Data Nodes for All

SafeShare extends Fidelity’s FidSafe cloud storage service for financial documents to let users share pre-verified documents as part of any application process that needs the documents.

content.body: Dispatch is a new smart box for shipping that protects its contents, and pays it’s couriers. Blockchain and cryptography enable mutual understanding
Separation of decentralized agents from layers of smartness enables flexibility and human readability

Aggregating data from loT devices and delegating decision making control creates new value for all players
Passive transactions happen automatically

card.desc: A network of smart modules for trading posts, to enable autonomous storefronts.

content.body: A network of smart modules for trading posts, to enable autonomous storefronts. Storefront modules could sit in vending machines, convenience stores, mall stands or any retail establishment. Storefront’s algorithm creates dynamic product mixes across cities by matching user needs to local inventory, meaning you can find the goods you need where you need them.
features: Seamless tracking of dynamically changing inventory
Micromarket that matches buyers to sellers
Smart contracts enabling automated payments
Algorithmic optimization of goods to predict demand

card.desc: A self aware water pump, providing state of the art water filtration technology and actionable analytics.

content.body: Imagine a world where water is a barrier-free and accessible common good. MajiSafi offers people confidence and peace of mind about where their next drink of water will come with a self aware water pump, providing state of the art water filtration technology and actionable analytics.
content.calloutBody: How might we make access to water quicker, cheaper, and safer for families in developing countries?
insights: There is a need for access to fresh, clean water
Distributed networks and microfinance gives locals more ownership and responsibility over their water
How do we coordinate with local actors?
What is the most suitable financing structure for the pump and filtered water?
How can the design better resonate with the local culture and actual context?

card.desc: Autonomous mobile education systems that can process requests for lessons, hire and deliver themselves to classes in need.

content.body: Imagine a world where lessons are 3D printed, and educational resources are easily shared and  self-managed. As fully automated business entities, EduPods process requests for lessons, hiring  themselves out to classes  in need. Their transactions are recorded and verified on the  blockchain, and the machines manage their own budgeted  based on funding allocated by the board.
content.calloutBody: How might we prepare students for a technological world?
insights: Mobile and rentable multi-purpose spaces. We’re moving away from large office buildings and towards spaces that support nomadic workers.
Shared Tools + Collaboration. When objects are able to maintain themselves, make smart decisions about their future, and interact fluidly with humans, there is no need for ownership
Making + Learning. Magical learning experiences take place when students are empowered to create.

card.desc: Platform to making carbon offset credits easier linking trees to a cryptocurrency blockchain and digital registry.

content.body: Imagine a world where humans do not outnumber trees, and individuals and corporations are rewarded for removing carbon from our atmosphere. IoTree makes this hope a reality by making carbon offset credits easier linking trees to a cryptocurrency blockchain and digital registry. Individual tree planters use a smart scanner to instantly identify and log the location and type of tree planted on a carbon registry, and receive micropayments in return. Companies can buy carbon credits to offset energy consumption to achieve an “energy neutral” standards thru a stock-exchange-like process.
content.calloutBody: How might we make carbon offset credits a viable tool for supporting our forests?
features: Smart Scanner with Spectroscopy & GPS geotagging
Individaul micro wallets store value for individual trees

-K_bcG-6WIzO6eFxy_L7.desc: Platform to making carbon offset credits easier linking trees to a cryptocurrency blockchain and digital registry.

card.desc: A network of local restaurants which trade their food inventory in a real-time virtual marketplace.

content.body: Mise en Place is a network of local restaurants which trade their food inventory in a real-time virtual marketplace. Sensors placed in refrigerators and storage rooms keep track of supply weight in real time, and place orders in a mesh network of surrounding restaurants for ingredients that are running low. Autonomous agent food inventory decreases the need for management, saves costs, and reduces waste systemically.
content.calloutBody: How might we improve restaurant inventory management and reduce waste?
features: Sensors as a service allow for a more connected resource ecosystem
Distributed mesh networks along machines allows for relationships in the physical realm that replicates what’s happening digitally
insights: Supplier/ restaurant relationships are constantly evolving, looking for better deals
Restaurants have already developed sharing networks based on reputation and relationship - Blockchain makes these networks more streamlined and accessible

card.desc: A sensor and app service that detects human presence and lighting on streets, suggests the safest walking route.

content.body:
Moon Walk is a sensor and app combination that helps people feel safe walking in urban areas by aggregating real-time human presence and lighting on streets and suggests the safest walking route.

Would users report and confirm unsafe behaviors in return for micropayments? Can crime reports be used to determine neighborhood safety? Can microphones be used to measure active flights or yelling?
content.calloutBody: How might we make walking in urban areas safer?
insights: Application and context of sensor data is more important than data itself
Aggregate data is more relevant and private than personal walking data
Past crime reports don’t affect people’s judgements on safety
Human reports are less reliable than sensor data
Sensor data can be misrepresented without the right context.

-K_e4LD7P4BEgDaonLUw.desc: A sensor and app service that detects human presence and lighting on streets, suggests the safest walking route.

card.desc: A sensor installed in a water system that communicates drinking water contents to individuals and cities.

content.body: DataStream is a real-time sensor easily installed in a building’s water system that empowers users to know what’s in their drinking water, and allows cities to monitor quality. DataStream sells the sensors to individuals, builders, and cities. Buyers receive free access to their own data, and recieve  micro-payments from others requesting or using the information.
content.calloutBody: How might we enable individuals and cities to know what’s in their water?
insights: Micropayments alone are not enough incentive to set up a complicated data network or sensor service
Need compelling primary motive (i.e. water quality concerns) to appeal to consumers
Privacy concerns with sensors as service
Value-add to sensors as a service comes from context (i.e. changes to data over time) and, actionable recommendations
content.title: Transparent Water

card.desc: Transforming the experience of bike mobility in the City.

content.body: Arrow is a bike sensor that routes bicycle commuters to waves of other riders on the roads for a safer, more communal riding experience. The real time, aggregated sensor data collects information including biker location, traffic alerts, and pollution data. Charges Micropayments for riding with the service, and subscription service for access to the data, shared with third parties through Smart Contracts.
content.calloutBody: How might we help current and potential bikers to move quickly and safely as a community?
features: Sensors pick-up dynamic data which connect to a user identity.
Sync with traffic regulation systems and resources.
Permit formation of a Biking Economy network associated with businesses and users with mutual rewards.
insights: It’s easier to influence individual change (sensors on person), rather than systemic (sensors in urban space)
Location of sensors presents privacy issues

card.desc: Wearable devices used to communicate to customer and Meals on Wheels teams regards tracking and delivery.

content.body: Care-fully provides Meals on Wheels recipients wearable devices that they can use to communicate to the Meals on Wheels team when they are ready to receive their food, and track delivery. Using the mesh network, drivers are notified and provided optimal routing for meal deliveries in their area. The wearable also notifies authorities if members did not receive meals, were not visited, or are not responsive.
content.calloutBody: How might we make meal delivery to seniors anxiety-free?
insights: Provenance allows for unmet needs to surface over time.
Reputation is an analog for history/ memory.
Be selective about placement, and make distinctions about data that is useful vs. superfluous

card.desc: A vehicle sensor that detects a collision, requests and pays for additional information from surrounding witnesses.

content.body: CrashCapture is an easily installable vehicle sensor that detects a collision and immediately requests and pays for additional information from surrounding witnesses. A particle electron board and accelerometer captures the event of the car crash and triggers a blockchain smart contract to fund an account to pay for data from dash cams, cameras, and nearby vehicles and drivers.
content.calloutBody: How might we help insurance claim adjusters evaluate a crash more efficiently and accurately?
insights: Third party sensors can provide objective information for witness purposes without seeming Big-Brother-ish.
Value is found within sub-networks of sensors connected by a single commonality (event, location, time), rather than a single owner, installer, or purposeful link.
Stakes must be high for people to be willing to put their own reputation at risk.

card.desc: Containers that act as independent entities, and can intelligently manage the delivery process.

content.body: Smart Container is a container that is conscious of it’s contents. These boxes become independent vehicles that can choose their paths of travel and handling preferences along the way. Containers can build reputation and maximize logistics  throughout the process thanks to networked location and shared a remote wallet for custom fees, port space rentals, permits, etc.
content.calloutBody: How might we help manufacturers confidently & reliably ship their products to market?
insights: Recievers want to verify package contents, weight, and safety
Accountability and traceability are key to operations and creating trust
International imports is an opportunity area

card.desc: A device to network wheelchair activity and enable interactions with public transportation.

content.body: Wheeling is a network connected device that captures data on wheelchair activity and enables interactions with public transportation. The device notifies the user that the upcoming bus has the available space fot the user, and pays for fare upon entry, resulting in a smoother boarding process. Collection of wheelchair usage will build reputation and trends of localized transportation systems, allowing individuals to decide where to live and visit, map out accessible sidewalks and streets, and inform cities of maintenance requests and accessibility needs.
content.calloutBody: How might we make public transportation more accessible to wheelchair users?
insights: Reputation can be represented by longer term trend of an abstract concept such as safety, accessibility, or friendliness
Reputation can be built automatically using a device and sensor economy with limited user input

content.body: Imagine a world where regular citizens can provide us with up to the minute photography of newsworthy events.  Witness is an open platform for crow-sourced truth, where news agencies can put calls out for images of events, and  individuals can respond by uploading photographs directly from their smart phones. Each time an image is used, the citizen journalist is compensated through a system of smart contracts, micropayments, and verified metadata.
content.calloutBody: How might we democratize photojournalism?
features: Blockchain provides authenticity to crowdsourced information.
All media is licensed and transacted in Ethereum

card.desc: A news platform that provides both sides of the story, through a crowdsourced timeline of an event or situation.

content.body: Facts & Perspectives is a news platform that provides both sides of the story, through a crowdsourced timeline of an event or situation. With different sections for context, curated via local activists and credible news agencies and perspectives, written by on-the-ground local voices F&P provides an overarching, live updating picture of situations ranging from the Turkish coup to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, to gentrification in San Francisco's mission district. F&P keeps things local by geofencing the content that’s submitted and then upvoted.
content.calloutBody: How might we pop the media bubbles we live in?
features: Geofencing content for local input
Timeline of Facts
Full writer perspectives

card.desc: A platform to crowdsource non-experts to tag a set of images on Amazon’s  Mechanical Turk platform.

content.body:
Lumy is a data solution for satellite imagery. It crowdsources non-experts to tag a set of images on Amazon’s Mechanical Turk platform. For a minimal cost, Lumy creates a set of training data used to train a machine learning algorithm, that can then run over thousands of satellite images, in order to track and stream… just about anything.

Use Cases

Retail Parking lots - identify and quantify retail traffic patterns in parking lots to make retail revenue predictions.
Diesase Outbreaks: count and measure water sources that increase risks of mosquito breeding and specific disease outbreaks.
Urban Trees: measure carbon credit generation w/in an area by counting # of trees in a city.
content.calloutBody: How might we enable new insights and real world intelligence from satellite images?
features: Combines human intelligence and machine learning enables microscopic view on a wide # of use cases & more precise predictions.
Scalability & Cost Efficiency: once a machine is well-trained, it scales faster
Flexibility: Customers can have personalized use cases based on their own specific needs.

Experts sign up and log on when they want to provide responses to questions, and they’re compensated via micropayments for their time and ratings. By tracking and transcribing conversations, Inquire uses machine learning to create heuristics - building towards automation.
content.calloutBody: How might we use humans as sensors?
features: Real Human input
Machine Learning

card.desc: A capacitive sensor that can figure out if humans are in chairs.

content.body: Tush is a new kind of sensor. Using capacitive sensing, Tush can figure out if humans are in chairs. Unlike traditional sensors, Tush can distinguish between bags, books, and other items - and people. Sensors can be built into seat fabrics, and can be deployed at scale for minimal cost into arenas, restaurants, offices, or trains. Tush is ready to create the perfect economy of seats - and butts. Go to the demo site.

card.desc: A new standard for food packaging transparency.

content.body: Good & Gather sets a new standard for food packaging transparency. It features both simple and complex food products side-by-side, contained in radically straightforward packaging, with the ingredients on the front (no matter what they are.) While most modern-day food packaging is covered with imagery, logos, and health claims, Good & Gather strips all of that away, leaving only what’s inside.
content.calloutBody: How might we build a more transparent connection between shoppers and the food they purchase?
insights: Consumers want, and trust, transparent labels.
Transparent is perceived as healthy, or natural
We need simpler, more straightforward labels

card.desc: A new way of experiencing and understanding our food through all our senses.

content.body:
Senslampler is more than a meal kit service - it’s a new way of experiencing and understanding our food through all our senses. Each of the ingredients provided for your family’s recipe, which is curated based on your taste preferences, can be placed inside your Sensampler - a specialized spectroscopic projector. This projector takes a spectroscopic reading of the ingredient and projects a live motion picture on the wall of your kitchen, bringing you closer to the source of your food. Fun for the kids, and the kids at heart

Prototype Brand at Target Tech Stars, now called Origins
content.calloutBody: How might we get children and families excited to learn about healthy food?
insights: Consumers want more connection to their food
Seeing is believing

The ByteME bracelet is a two-part sensor that measures nutritional inputs (food, water, and supplements), and functional outputs using spectroscopic and optic sensors. The dual tracker talks in real-time to a smart app which provides daily readings for nutrition, hydration, and energy, and offers personalized suggestion to optimize health.
content.calloutBody: How might we eat for health?
insights: The microbiome offers a new frontier of understanding health.
Even though the microbiome is all the rage, poop is still taboo!
Will users  be willing to scan everything they eat, and release?

content.body: At LEGO Food Lab we’re building to learn about food! Each LEGO piece in this specialty Food Land set contains hardware that is coded as an ingredient, complete with the corresponding nutritional profile. Use the blocks to build a complete recipe - or create your own! Physical meets digital in the Food Lab app, where kids have a personalized LEGO avatar suggest recipes and respond to nutrition and flavor profiles.
content.calloutBody: How might we make learning about food personalized and FUN?
insights: There is no “one” right way to learn about food
Allergies are a big concern for parents
Kids need a way to develop their own food values

content.body: Pickl is an end-to-end solution for the busy shopper who wants to get in and out of the supermarket quickly, and find products that aligns with their values, budget, and health needs. Users create a profile to share key information about their dietary needs, budget, and what causes they want to support. Pickl then aggregates data from that profile, third party resources, and news fedes to curate customized menus and shopping lists.

Compares items for quicker and easier decision making

Trust in food labels is at an all time low
AR technology creates a useable wayfinding experience

A food bazaar with pop-up food stalls surrounding a community dining hall, and 3. A grab & go station for take-away meals from our refrigerator.

card.desc: PopCycle is the kitchen appliance that transforms your unused produce into ready-to-use frozen ingredients.

content.body: PopCycle is the kitchen appliance that transforms your unused produce into ready-to-use frozen ingredients. American families throw out 25% of the food they buy, which hurts our wallets - and our planets. PopCycle offers consumers a mess-free, simple and organized solution for preserving and storing their produce for later user. Simply scan in your extras to the PopCycle device to blend, vaccuum seal, and label your extras for easy freezer storeage. Inventory data is recorded on an app interface which means you’ll never forget what you have on hand!
content.calloutBody: How might we eliminate food waste at home?
features: Image recognition to program accurate storing conditions
Simultaneous blending and heating for reduction
Vacuum seal technology

card.desc: An AI device that creates scents in the home to positively impact how occupants think, feel, and behave.

content.body:
Odoto is an intelligent scent generation system that analyzes facial expressions to determine the impact of various scents on an individual’s overall sense of well-being. It learns more about the individuals over time and adjusts scents to optimize a person’s perception and experience in the home.

Odoto provides an opportunity to both improve human quality of life, and to continually learn more about the field of olfaction through the data captured by the AI.
content.calloutBody: How might we enable AI to improve quality of life in the home based on the occupants’ current mood and needs?
insights: Cognition, emotion and even other senses are affected by olfaction.
Multi-sensory AR provides an indirect way to interface with data.
Scent is an under-explored medium for Augmented Reality – we can further the field by capturing more data.
Most AR is focused on individual experiences. Scent affects multiple people at once.
Opportunities exist for personalization of environments, such as rental cars or hotels.
content.why: We believe AI can enable a fundamentally different and better home management system. The occupants of a home should enjoy living in the space, and have the space work for them. AI's participation should facilitate delight, productivity, calm, or whatever mood the occupant desires. Real-time data is important to a personalize AI - fast, convenient, and unobtrusive inputs are crucial.

card.desc: An adaptive home monitoring system that monitors and interprets multiple data sources

content.body:
Kevin gathers data from a motion sensor, a pressure-sensitive doormat, the homeowner's GPS, and an outdoor voice interface (Google Home).  The Kevin prototype explores several common user journeys: In one case, a neighbor comes by when the homeowner is home. In another, a neighbor comes by when the homeowner is NOT home. In a 3rd case, an intruder comes by when the homeowner is not home. 
The prototype leverages its sensor inputs to be more accurate and flexible in how it responds. If the user's voice/name is known, it can respond differently.
The key part of this system (not yet prototyped) is the system's ability to self-verify -  that if 2 sensors are picking up a signal, the system would expect a 3rd sensor to give a certain readind. It doesn't,  the system can self -diagnose that something appears to be wrong with that 3rd sensor.
content.calloutBody: How might we correlate many types of data to better gather meaningful, trusted information?
insights: Individual sensors cannot be trusted. In centralized systems, hubs cannot be trusted.

In a system with many stakeholders (homeowner, appliance manufacturer, advertisers), its important for us to not only manage stakeholder interests, but also have the interoperability to utilize all these disparate systems in a single network.
Cross verification and certifications are a nice proxy for device identity and fingerprinting due to the fact that patterns can be unique to their environment and operations.
content.why: Data triangulation enables insights or decisions based on multiple sensor inputs. This can lead to "smart" networks of low-cost sensors rather than higher-cost "all-in-one" devices.

-K_kClpIOBMLew-v8CD-.desc: An adaptive home monitoring system that monitors and interprets multiple data sources

-K_kClpIOBMLew-v8CD-.title: Kevin

card.desc: Home and grocer-monitored consumption to recommend possible actions and uses to reduce food waste.

content.body:
Food purchased from smart stores such as Amazon GO will contain blockchain information on the food - including purchase date, expiration date, name of food, brand, attributes (organic, free range, etc.) that could be automatically added to your Home Inventory. Through the use of sensors (QR scanner, RFID, etc.) food that is removed for use can be tracked and maintained for your home. This information can be used to help recommend recipes to reduce waste from food expiring soon, analyze the nutrition contents of what you are eating, or keep a running inventory of the food in your pantry to avoid over-purchase.
Our prototype uses a chatbot AI using free text and speech to query this information to make informative decisions about what can be made with the inventory in the home, what food is expiring soon, what food has expired, and to analyze recent nutritional intake. This data helps to reduce food waste within a home and community by recommending the use of items that are nearing expiration. It also enables extra food to be shared to friends/neighbors for their use. The nutritional information can be used with a  doctor to discuss eating habits in relation to health.
content.calloutBody: How might we reduce food waste, change eating behaviors, and share food resources within a community?
insights: With Amazon Go idea and offerings from similar stores, the items that we purchased will be more trackable and have more data about their provenance. This will allow us, as individuals, to use that data to help improve behaviors, health, costs, etc.
Blockchain implementation in a quick format at small-scale is not simple. Utilizing chatbot AI with many different channel interactions can also be a challenge.
links: Working inventory, add and remove items are at: http://www.ccomfort.com/ideo/sensor.php
content.why: Food waste is a growing problem in the US, and may be addressable by providing options for behaviors other than discarding excess food.  This would allow for better purchasing and use of food and also provide an avenue for sharing of food within a community.

-K_kD28Ou05ph0IYjfIO.desc: Home and grocer-monitored consumption to recommend possible actions and uses to reduce food waste.
-K_kD28Ou05ph0IYjfIO.title: Smart Pantry

card.desc: An AI that provides adaptive, contextualized homework for students based on location and current events.

content.body:
Contexta uses predefined math problems built off two articles from the Boston Globe and the New York Times. It includes two Customer Skill Models: (A) Sam from Boston (B) Jane from New York - this determines which set of homework questions to provide. The prototype, built with an Amazon Echo Dot, creates a dynamic, educational experience with AI.

Scenario 1: Sam from Boston
Utterance: “Alexa, this is Sam. What is my homework?”
Alexa provides Context and math questions on minimum wage article
Utterance: “The answer/ my answer is ___”

Scenario 2: Jane from New York
Utterance: “Alexa, this is Jane. What is my homework?”
Alexa provides Context and math questions on New York tuition policy
Utterance: “The answer/ my answer is ___”

AI Opportunities:
Create tailored learning experiences adapted to every student’s needs
Voice interfaces are already in millions of homes and are becoming socially accepted
Gradually add small (invisible) amounts of machine learning inside curriculums
Voice interfaces are fun and interactive, but user testing is necessary for further development
Start with simple homework exercises and learn more about students homework habits Iterate before students get familiar with the experience and integrate in classrooms for fact checking or TA roles of virtual assistants

AI Limitations:
Machine learning still requires considerable human intervention to be able to generate entire school curriculums
Data availability is limited and inconsistent
Content for curriculums is protected by copyright - potentially non-cost effective licensing
To what extent can we trust an AI to shape education for generations?
Current “Virtual assistant” capabilities cannot stand alone (i.e. replace classroom teachers), but can augment teaching
Current voice interface technology is too weak to meet the demands of class ‘lectures’
content.calloutBody: Create an adaptive & responsive curriculum that reflects the needs/ interests of the community?
insights: Communal AI is successful when the interests of the community align with individual needs. If the end user is separated from the decision maker, then the AI may evolve to meet the decision maker’s needs, not the end user’s needs.

AI and machine learning is not currently capable of both parsing and then generating educational content given the constraint of current and future “context.” Machine learning could at first help recommend and curate content, for example to help teachers make curricula based on learning objectives.
How individuals interact with an AI will have an impact on the effectiveness of AI as a tool to represent the interests of a community or society.
Conversational user interfaces cannot support sustained human-computer interaction required for classroom and personal student learning.

Ultimately, AIs that represent specific groups or communities may need a standard interface with other AIs to translate values and interests of their respective communities. However, those standards may be partial to the creator.
The ability to create dynamic curricula would require restructuring the data architecture of existing content to become modular (step 1) before an AI could be used to manage it (step 2).
content.why: AI's often focus on the needs of an individual community or group, but don't consider differences across those communities, and whether the systems that exist serve one community better than another. Educational content (e.g. classroom or after-school) is a context in which students may need the most help.

-K_kDoFMhL6Y1mnSsAg-.desc: An AI that provides adaptive, contextualized homework for students based on location and current events.
-K_kDoFMhL6Y1mnSsAg-.title: Contexta

card.desc: An mobile network of intelligent nodes that coordinates electric vehicle charging between vehicle owners

content.body: The SPARK service is a fleet of mobile charging units for electric vehicles that route dynamically, based on demand in the network. Electric vehicle owners sign up for SPARK and using a network of sensors, a fleet of mobile charging vehicles are able to identify when and where an electric vehicle needs charge. Users can pay a monthly subscription to always have their electric vehicle charged, or opt to only pay for a charging vehicle to service them when they need it the most. In times of high demand, subscription users can sell their “priority status” so that others can use the service, and receive credit for that on their subscription.
content.calloutBody: use blockchains and sensor networks to enable markets for underutilized assets where and as needed?
insights: Subscription vs. episodic. We learned that there’s a huge variance among EV owners between wanting to pay per charge, vs subscribe monthly to a charged vehicle.

City vs. Suburban. City electric vehicle owners take shorter-distance trips and have many morecharging stations available. Suburban electric vehicle owners feel the anxiety of not having access to charging stations much more more.

Recombination. We can make meaning by not just collecting singular data points (battery utilization, expected trip distance, MPGe), but by combining raw sensor data with machine learning to create predictions. We explored using blockchain technology to assign nodes to the vehicles on the network and facilitate the transactions between people to purchase battery power.
content.why: We identified a need for increased access to charging stations for electric vehicle owners, as well as the inefficient use of current charging stations given their lack of mobility. With this challenge, we tried to answer the following: how might we increase the availability of electric vehicle charging stations, and how might we deliver battery power to individuals when they needed it the most? We validated that people would pay for access to charging stations but that people assign different value to this access based on situational factors. We decided to build a prototype that would showcase a network of people who need different levels of battery charge and valuing access to this charge based on a combination of need (current charge level) and price (willingness to pay).

-K_kDwbQvWDKcYaKxkOZ.desc: An mobile network of intelligent nodes that coordinates electric vehicle charging between vehicle owners
-K_kDwbQvWDKcYaKxkOZ.title: Spark

card.desc: A new system that encourages people to buy low-energy produce through color-coded energy stickers.

content.body: Produce Greens is a system that uses a set of criteria to identify high-energy output foods, then a brand to label them for the consumers. Our system notifies consumers which individual piece of produce is the best buy when it comes to energy consumption up to the point of sale. The system uses machine learning and IOT (pallet tracking for energy output) to rank different foods, and includes an easy-to-use app interface for farmers to track their farm's energy efficiency.
content.calloutBody: incentivize people to eat foods that require less energy to produce and deliver?
insights: In opaque markets, it’s hard to scale a set of common sensors to reach critical mass. There were a lot of points of contact we’d need to convince, to get the data we wanted.

Consumers make choices based on the information they have available. While it’s hard, it’s not insurmountable to create simple systems that make meaning from the many data points that are relevant to the consumer’s choice.
content.why: We believe there’s a lot of opportunity to surface relevant information, at the point of sale, to help people make better decisions. Whether it’s farmer contemplating what to plant and when or consumers confused about which avocado to purchase, we think helping people parse information is critical in changing behavior. Today, supply chains are opaque and complex for the average consumer to navigate, and our simple green-yellow-red labeling system gives consumers a better sense of how food ends up at the store they visit.

-K_kE78V6u32VJWjpE3G.desc: A new system that encourages people to buy low-energy produce through color-coded energy stickers.
-K_kE78V6u32VJWjpE3G.title: Produce Greens

card.desc: An energy consumption management system that provides actionable recommendations to individuals.

content.body:
Both large and small decisions can have big impacts when it comes to your utility bill and your impact on the environment. Simple actions such as choosing to delay your dishwasher load for a few hours or lowering the thermostat setting by 1 degree can lead to significant reductions in environmental damage as well as substantial financial savings, if they’re coordinated across a network. But right now, even if you want to save money on your bill and have a greener footprint, it’s unclear what actions to take and when, or what the meaningful impact is - on your bill and on your world.

We’ve redesigned your relationship with the energy you consume to make it effortless and transparent. You’ve chosen connected devices to make your life easier and help you save energy. We take the data from those connected devices and sensors in your home, use state-of-the-art machine learning to distill it into a set of simple actions: Go Green.

What is “Going Green”?

Going Green is a system that includes passive home environment signals that provide you real-time feedback on the impact your action is going have on your consumption, a “Smart Bill” to summarize and interpret the long-term impact of your “Go Green” Actions, and metrics for comparing your performance with other relevant populations.

Example Scenario

 Dishwasher: Eric is about to put a dishwasher load on. He has two options, do the load now, if he has company coming over and needs dishes immediately, or go green by pressing the physical button if he’s not in a rush. Eric decides to let the system do the work of figuring out the most energy- and cost-efficient time to run his dishwasher. Later, when looking at his Smart Bill, he can see the impact of the times he went green and the times he didn’t translated into terms he understands: Dollars he could have saved and the energy impact he’s prevented. Good news is Eric doesn’t have to figure out how to translate that into his life, he just needs to Go Green more often. The devices themselves suggest the actions.

Text "start" to 720-961-2494 to begin.
content.calloutBody: reveal invisible information to help us monitor and improve our consumption behavior?
insights: Consumers would like to save energy, but generally don’t want to spend time thinking about it. (6-9 minutes per year, on average).
Bill payer would like their utilities company to provide personalized data on energy consumption and specific action items to decrease overall impact. General recommendations carry little weight.
Homeowners are open to the idea of “Groupon-like” pooled purchasing deals for mid-to-large scale utility-related purchases such as home renovations and appliances.

Utility providers are interested in more granular information about consumer user habits to better forecast demand and optimize grid loads. We all agree that saving the environment is an important problem that needs to be tackled now and together and making money is a problem that can be solved down the line.

User engagement, transparency, and permissions can be encouraged by leveraging monthly, mandatory interactions such as bill payment. By using these mandatory interactions, we can get users to engage in more technologically-costly actions such as downloading and logging into an app to save energy over time.
content.why:
Our initial discussion raised a question: Can we bridge the intention-action gap? You might want to save energy or save money on the bill, but don't know how individual decisions affect the final total, or what that looks like in the long run. This led us to make a prototype of a physical interaction with a home appliance that would “signal” an optimal / less optimal behavior, basically a go-no go signal. Feedback from testing was positive but users didn't want an invasive signal and didn't envision at the moment querying further into why the signal was “go” vs. “no go.”

Larger impact actions might be upgrading appliances, or choosing to remodel house with more energy saving windows. We realized that consumers currently make that decision largely unaided. What if we could enhance this process?

We took the insight that consumers really don't want to spend more than 6 minutes making decisions about energy consumption, but they would want to have recommendations about what to change, and decided to target the bill pay process. We envisioned a Smart Bill which presents your monthly utilities bill in the context of a comparison to neighboring homes.

-K_kEFCk5YvjrQLOv51I.desc: An energy consumption management system that provides actionable recommendations to individuals.
-K_kEFCk5YvjrQLOv51I.title: GreenHaus

card.desc: A device that smooths energy demand by coordinating appliance usage.

content.body: OHMNI is a device that plugs in between an appliance and a power outlet with a simple interface which displays three options for use: Now, Soon, & Later. The “certain completion” time is prominently displayed as well as the current cost of use to run that device. As users input the priority of their usage, the job is posted to a feeder-wide ledger where AI-fueled smart contracts negotiate the order of execution.
content.calloutBody: allow communities to reduce their resource burden by better coordinating their usage and behaviors?
insights: Understanding how to prioritize demand is a significant challenge when we cede control over engagement to machines, and it's not done by humans. Who should decide that my dishwasher should run at 10pm, but my neighbor's will be done at 1am?
The benefit for participation needs to be shared with the consumer to make it financially meaningful for them. Saving $1-2 may not be enough.

-K_kERhl53Zx9stCPfBq.desc: A device that smooths energy demand by coordinating appliance usage.
-K_kERhl53Zx9stCPfBq.title: Ohmni

card.desc: A system that supports on-demand sharing and selling unused groceries.

content.body:
As the Internet of Things brings more devices into our homes, we can consider an "Internet of Fewer Things" - that is, systems that reduce waste or redundancy. In the USA, 30-40% of the food supply is wasted, equaling more than 20 pounds of food per person per month (source: http://www.worldfooddayusa.org/food_waste_the_facts). Pass the Beat focuses on urban environments, such as neighborhoods or apartment buildings, in which sharing groceries or left-over food can help reduce waste.

Pass the Beet includes a prototype app interface as well as a smart mailbox made with with basic LittleBits/Arduino-enabled sensors that can detect pressure to know when objects are added and removed from the box. The prototype explores the logistics of providing such a service as well as convincing users to use it. Future delivery system prototypes would likely move from a smart mailox to an automated delivery drone mailbox.
content.calloutBody: How might we enable neighbors to share groceries and food with each other?
insights: There are opportunities for spectroscopy, smell sensors, and scanning to track the quality and identity of the food.
People are not used to sharing food with strangers and are conditioned to trust big box stores and supermarkets, rather than local grocers or grocery carts.
Smart refrigerators are still not common in the market, and the fridges that exist do not track food quality.
content.why:
1) As a team, we were intrigued by the idea of drones or bots that make an asset available to users at a particular location. However, we wanted to explore applications beyond the individual home (wifi, lighting, etc.). We struggled with wanting to tackle something with larger social benefits, rather than the convenience and luxury of an individual household. As a result, we were drawn to issues of food and community, namely the inability of neighbors to share groceries or food with each other due to trust issues in a modern society.
2) We were trying to answer the primary question in the brief — how valuable assets might move themselves to where they're needed. In our case, unused food is our valuable asset that we're moving between neighbors. We wanted our prototype to answer the question of how do you create trust between neighbors to enable them to share unused food with each other, rather than just throwing it out?
3) We validated the initial logistics and concept that enables these questions to be a reality. We invalidated a complex approach with too many features.

-K_kE__mMih7n6AD690h.desc: A system that supports on-demand sharing and selling unused groceries.
-K_kE__mMih7n6AD690h.title: Pass the Beet

card.desc: A pop-up rental market for neighborhood tools built on blockchain.

content.body:
SHED is a deployable pop-up tool market for your neighborhood. We send you a fully-automated and prebuilt SHED to house your tools (especially dangerous ones) and those of your neighbors so you can share underutilized resources.

HOW TOKENS WORK: Each home pays into the SHED of their neighborhood individually on a subscription basis. This deposits tokens in their community’s SHED individual account. You don't see or count the tokens your SHED has, but they can be spent to rent tools from other SHEDs or to purchase new tools for your own SHED.

MOTIVATIONS: (1.) Clean up your garage/storage space by moving tools to a centralized location (2.) By sharing your tools, gain access to the tools of your neighbors. (3.) Keep dangerous tools away from children in the home (4.) Money from the subscription service goes towards cleaning and maintenance of your own tools.

#IOT: Used to connect the SHED to the network and keep information connected.

#BLOCKCHAIN: Harnessed to log payment info from each individual and also token accounting between SHEDS in a secure and fully automated location. Also used to account for tools being checked in and out so no one can steal tools or falsify entry data.

SIGN-UP: A SHED is sent to a neighborhood once 8 houses or more have signed up to be SHED members. Neighborhood must have network connectivity access. Sign up process involves entering in address, payment and tool-ownership info. Once 8 homes have signed up, the SHED uses an algorithm to determine which house is the best one to host the SHED given location, lighting and yard size. It pings the owner of that house and asks for verification that they are still willing to host (they get a discount per month). Once that has been verified, the SHED ships. SHED Recommends size of Shed Pod(s) based on tools, zoning,& space. Uses modular shipping containers. This whole process (other than SHED manufacturing) is fully automated to avoid overhead costs.

DEPLOYMENT: The SHED lands pre-loaded with lock boxes and electronic verification system in place. It then sends a notification to each SHED member to come deposit their tools. The tools are marked as ""checked-out"" by the owner until they are turned in for the first time. If the tool is not returned (or in this case deposited) within a given timeframe, charges begin for the owner as they would in the case of a late-returned item. Once tools are deposited they auto-lock as when checked-in.

ENTERING SHED: If you want to enter a SHED, you press the ""request access"" button on your SHED phone app for a 6-digit verification key. Once you receive the key, you punch it into the key pad on the door. The key code works for only a short time-frame for security and is tied in with your personal account so we know who is entering. Info on people entering and leaving the SHED is sent via IOT to the Blockchain ledger.

RENTING A TOOL: You can check your SHED app before even going to the SHED to see if a tool is checked in or out. Once you arrive, the process for check out is much like entry. You say you want to check it out on your phone, you get an access code, you enter that into a keypad on a secure box housing the tool, and the box releases the tool for your use. Info on who has taken or returned a tool is sent via IOT to the Blockchain ledger.

RETURNING A TOOL: If you do not return the tool in a pre-determined time frame, you begin to be fined for usage. To return it, you reenter the SHED, put the tool back in the box (which auto-locks) and check the tool back in on your phone app. Info on who has taken or returned a tool is sent via IOT to the Blockchain ledger.

OTHER SHEDS: If your SHED does not have the tool you need, but the next neighborhood over does, you can either spend inter-SHED tokens to rent a tool from another SHED or pay extra money to rent it. You request access to the neighboring SHED through your app and it sends a limited-time access code as normal. The amount of tokens needed for this exchange is tracked and transferred by the Blockchain ledger. The user is informed only if there is not enough SHED tokens to borrow the neighboring community's tool.

TOOL DEMAND: If a tool is in high demand, such as a snow-blower on a snowy day, there is surge pricing or bidding in order to gain access to the item first. The item also has a more limited rental time than normal-demand items. This is all fully automated to eliminate overhead.

OTHER CONTEXTS: Could also be a food co-op or really any neighborhood resource. Interesting applications in labor markets to exchange expertise.

NEXT STEPS: (1.) Validate with integration with blockchain: Accounting design / implementation and contracts implementation. (2.) Migrate mock-up of app from static to dynamic. (3.) Design SHED pods of varying size appropriate for a neighborhood. (4.) Build bidding system to let the SHED handle contractors available for automating work (Snow plowing, furnace maintenance, equipment maintenance).
content.calloutBody: How might we use blockchains and sensor networks to enable markets for underutilized assets where and as needed?
insights: It will matter where SHED is and if it’s well-lit, etc.
Concern with what happens if a tool breaks. Will need to build out more what happens in that scenario.
Competition may be local maker-spaces which are better managed and maintained, or also regular tool shops like Home Depot.
A little more about blockchain and the security component as a crucial value and reason to use the technology.
content.next:
Build a pure peer-to-peer exchange platform without the physical shed (e.g. basement-to-basement).

Partner with retailers and tool makers (e.g. Home Depot and Dewalt) to pilot the physical shed.

-K_kEj2kJqJI2q4JQxNa.desc: A pop-up rental market for neighborhood tools built on blockchain.
-K_kEj2kJqJI2q4JQxNa.title: Shed

card.desc: A Shared Values-reputation platform derived from sensors and traditional reviews.

content.body:
Homerun is a digital platform that matches customers with home repair professionals based on shared values and retains job histories; it is accompanied by a set of devices that use IoT sensors track repair performance and use smart contracts on the blockchain to manage transactions.

Translate the Transaction: Bitcoin is not a suitable payment medium for repairs people who have been using traditional forms of payment for years; as such, it is important to remember that the value in the smart contracts is to be translated into something more meaningful for the individual.

Personalized sensors for all conditions: Iot Sensors are not a one size fits all for every appliance. They also need to be able to withstand harsh environments (e.g. water immersion, cold, heat, etc) and, in order to be widely useful, fit in a variety of existing home systems.

Zoom in on Safety: Regardless of someone's online reputation, letting a stranger into your house is uncomfortable when you don’t know them personally.
content.calloutBody: How might we standardize the telling factors of a repairman’s performance and build trust between customers and contractors?
insights: Translate the transaction
Personalized sensors for all conditions
Zoom in on Safety
content.next: Tie-in with a functional smart contract system.
content.why: Our exploration began on the premise that in order to build trust between customers and contractors, we need to build a system that measures reputation upstream and downstream: Inform decision-making, Communicate results, Verify results, Establish metric for evaluation.

-Ka3NCdrkewqrw8gk0Aq.desc: A Shared Values-reputation platform derived from sensors and traditional reviews.
-Ka3NCdrkewqrw8gk0Aq.title: Homerun

card.desc: An AI that encourages positive human behavior by analyzing social media.

content.body: We built a front end user interface in the form of a Facebook messenger bot that is able to help a teen decide, with peer input, whether or not they should spend their time volunteering. Then we built a front end to the backend of what powers that bot by using Google Tensorflow to create a neural net that learns from a training dataset to predict, from user statistics, the likelihood of them accepting a challenge to volunteer. Eventually the neural net would start to take user input and create a whole new neural net personalized just for that user, and grow over time with new datapoints.
content.calloutBody: How might we onboard a personal AI to donate your time based on your interests and intentions?
insights: Neural nets are easy in concept, sort of hard to construct and train, really hard to make it do what you want.

People think AI is something that can do anything they want it to and use it as a catch all. It's not. It's got a very specific set of things it currently can do, and nobody has developed a very good high level way of interfacing with it...but new languages and programs are coming out daily.
AI that's been familiarized by human use is just considered normal computing. If it's unproven and sometimes unreliable, it's considered AI.
There needs to be a visual language around AI to allow people without a technical background to take a peek under the hood and understand at a conceptual level what it can and can't do.
Group dynamics in AI are super interesting and easier to model than an individual AI, in part because the structure of a neural net mimics social dynamics.

A new neural net needs to be created for each person, with each new data point, in each new scenario. They can't be merged at current and this is why it's hard to onboard or teach an AI, because the small changes in data have huge implications in what happens to the entire neural net. We want to look at LSTM and reinforcement learning neural net models to see if this would take in dynamic data better. The closest thing out there today to this kind of AI learning is around financial markets.

There is a learning curve to an AI and a level of trust by the user to an AI. There is, in the middle, a trough of disillusionment and it sort of sucks, but if a user can keep feeding it data, there will be exponential growth in how close an AI is aligned to a human's interests, and the gap will close to be trivial because eventually a human will start trusting the AI enough to reinforce it. See image of graph."
content.why:
We started with the following hunches: AI CAN HELP US REACH OUR FULL POTENTIAL. We believe that we (as humans) are not operating at our full potential. Because we can’t. Not because we don’t want to.

AI SHOULD OPTIMIZE FOR US We believe AI is better at optimizing than we as humans can - and that it should be used.

AI WILL HELP YOU GET TO KNOW YOURSELF BETTER We believe that people do not know themselves as well as they think they do. AI should facilitate those insights.

AI WILL DELIGHT YOU WITH SUGGESTIONS We believe that AI can be more than just coordinating. AI should suggest your desires and delight you.

We then went on a really wild ride trying to figure out how to build an AI that could start onboarding..and quickly realized that this is no easy feat. A neural net is simple in concept, not that simple to implement, and much hard to train and have it output useful insights. There's a huge opportunity here to create a visual language to help people understand misconceptions about what AI is.

-KaFx7_xIKEErG3YVVy7.desc: An AI that encourages positive human behavior by analyzing social media.
-KaFx7_xIKEErG3YVVy7.subtitle: Your self learning, personal AI
-KaFx7_xIKEErG3YVVy7.title: Aura

card.desc: B-Lock helps you unlock registered devices with an immutable history of interaction.

content.body:
B-Lock harnesses IOT and Blockchain technology to log identity, entry and exit of an individual accessing a secured area. The lock operates with 2-factor authentication. You have a secure identity that the Blockchain recognizes. The web app loads on your phone, enter in the lock's ID and request access. It sends you a key code, which you type into a keypad on the physical lock itself to verify both your identity and your own possession of your phone. The IOT tech recognizes when you lock/unlock the box and the blockchain immutably tracks each step. The business or client monitoring the backend gets a full display tracking data and interaction.

There are a number of business applications for this locking and tracking technology. We are starting with a vending machine technology that allows you to try on and put back the items you decide you don't like. We settled on eye glasses as the best first product. We will put the machine in a central area where people wait (like a mall or a bus stop). They can use the ID authentication described above to open the box, which is tracked on the blockchain. They try on the glasses, see how they look, and then direct order them to their home if they want to purchase. If they steal it, the box knows via NFC tech on each and automatically charges them. The data on the box can't be hacked for theft as it's immutably tracked on the blockchain. This also allows a users preferences and locations to be tracked and logged without revealing their personal financial info.
content.calloutBody: How might we use blockchain to track who locks/unlocks a secure item?
insights: Consumer desire for efficiency of the internet world with tactile experience of the physical world.
IOT doesn’t have to be scary! Blockchain can ensure history is immutable.
Many Blockchain implementations can accomplish this model. With our custom built API, doesn’t matter which Blockchain we choose.
content.why:
We started with asking what the most interesting part of the SHED technology was from our first prototype and settled on the locking tech -- specifically how IOT integrates with Blockchain and how that can create an interconnected network. After that we iterated for quite some time on where that tech could go -- what would you lock? What would you unlock? Would it be as big as a house or as small as a pillbox? Would it be a B2B implementation, B2C retail or C2C sharing?

Ultimately we decided on divide and conquer -- Andrew and Junning got to work on coding the software and the API to integrate technologies, Kate and Kate did market research and conducted user surveys. Through the 'doing' process we invalidated: 1.) Our initial medical management idea would not be effective in stopping drug theft. 2.) C2C sharing would not be trusted by the community with no central management. 3.) Blockchain tech is most useful if there's some reason to actually have the information shared beyond one person's record. So not just locking a gun up, but allowing insurance companies or lawmakers to track who opens/shuts the case as well.

We did validate that we can reduce costs of tracking through a decentralized system that doesn't require monitoring. This has positive implications for business, military and more.

-KaFxu3ElvntJTENQfLB.desc: B-Lock helps you unlock registered devices with an immutable history of interaction.
-KaFxu3ElvntJTENQfLB.subtitle: Access physical Locks like Gmail
-KaFxu3ElvntJTENQfLB.title: B-Lock

card.desc: A purpose-based AI that optimizes travel for vehicles with priority “intents,” such as for medical emergencies.
card.thumbAlt: Passengers driving passively... and then labor happens!

content.body: Emergency K.AI.T.T. is a purpose-driven AI that gives priority to specific vehicles in a system based on their intent. Once a driver or passenger requests an emergency via the voice-based interface, Emergency K.AI.T.T. clears the vehicle as a priority vehicle and enacts several system-wide changes. In a world of autonomous vehicles, other vehicles on the road may clear the road for an emergency vehicle, while smart road infrastructure reacts to expedite the transportation (e.g. all the stoplights turn green). This AI represents a fundamental paradigm shift from “you vs. the world” to “you are the world” in a future where your interests can be absorbed and acted upon by other vehicles on the road.
content.calloutBody: How might we ensure that AIs represent our collective interests as a society?
features: Individual AVs react based on their environment.
Autonomous vehicles can follow such behaviors without centralized decision system but through environmental feedback.
Give a desired outcome for a group of vehicles to achieve collectively on a micro level (eg:let a vehicle go through an intersection or escort another vehicle).
insights: Intent-based prioritization is a crucial building block for an AI that furthers the collective interest of a community based on a set of community values (e.g. people with medical emergencies should be prioritized over others.)

However, humans may try to trick a system to further individual interests (e.g. “I need to go home because...we’re having a home birth”) so data validation is crucial to correctly identify when individual intent aligns with community values.
Best emergency response requires group behavior
content.next:
Engage municipal government to explore organizing citizens' assets to achieve on-demand goals. 
Redesign a distributed 911.

-KaFyOitpf6akL-PI6NH.desc: A purpose-based AI that optimizes travel for vehicles with priority “intents,” such as for medical emergencies.

hero.title: Kaitt
