-KaFyOitpf6akL-PI6NH.title: Kaitt

card.desc: A companion for the elderly, helping minimize the likelihood and consequences of falls.
card.thumbAlt: Bernard and the sensors he looks after

content.body:
Bernard is a fully modular system of sensors feeding data into a federated brain which can detect falls, interact with the elderly user, and notify the appropriate 3rd parties. The sensors can be thought about in 3 categories: wearables that go with the person as they move through the world, stationary sensors that are placed in the home, and external data sources such as weather and medical history. Bernard's capabilities include monitoring, logging, user interaction, and notification.

For the elderly population, many live in isolation without any kind of social interaction. Interacting with a Google Home or Alexa is a step in the right direction, but not ideal. This is because they are made more for order and command, as opposed to conversation and relationship building. For elderly, a more suited solution is something conversational that gives them not just response, but can prompt convos (“How are you doing today?”).

From the perspective of the child of an elderly, the preferred priority of who gets notified (them vs. 911) seems to be dependent on their context and what they have recently experienced (i.e. it’s not standardized). In all cases, though, - if they are confident in the system’s accuracy, then they would be ok with the system dynamically making the determination. - The child would still like some sort of summary of events that happened, even if they aren’t contacted first, just so they can be aware.
content.calloutBody: How might we correlate many types of data to better gather meaningful, trusted information?
features: The easy creation of intent: Because of the remixability of the state of the data we can easily create our own “recipes” or algorithms for determining what the information is telling us. Then we can add machine learning to context interpretation and train it to recognize additional scenarios.

Importance of distinction: Because we got a bunch of data sources that can be used for different intents such as a camera being used for environment identification vs help has arrived. These should all be in different nodes with a singular purpose for really quick and remixable usages. It also allows for more transparency of intent for privacy concerns.
content.why: We liked the concept from Sprint 1 where IoT devices cross-validate one another, but wanted to focused on a more specific use case. We were drawn, through our brainstorming to the elderly as a user group, and that turned into our big question of "How might we use an intelligent network of sensors to inform caregivers and care receivers of what's happening". We then did 2 phone interviews and 1 in person interview to inform our exploration.

-KaFysbkbyfkzag09kdd.desc: A companion for the elderly, helping minimize the likelihood and consequences of falls.

hero.imageAlt: Bernard and the sensors he looks after
hero.title: Bernard

-KaFysbkbyfkzag09kdd.subtitle: Minority Report with Lassie
-KaFysbkbyfkzag09kdd.title: Bernard

card.desc: A system that combines sensing and machine learning of behavioral data to improve productivity and collaboration throughout the workday.

content.body:
Fulcrum is a platform that helps individuals on teams optimize their workflow by utilizing real-time sensing of behavioral data and machine learning to capture task progress and surface optimal actions to improve productivity and collaboration throughout the workday.

You have your to-do list. We surface insights to help you shape a more fulfilling work process by: Augmenting individual awareness of productivity; Surfacing ideal moments for collaborative problem-solving; Creating a living artifact of your competencies & working style. Our sensor-based technology uses machine learning techniques to interpret facial recognition, on-screen behavior, physiological and tactile inputs captured from IoT devices to help you work better with your networked team.

Both managers and individual contributors are uncomfortable with work environments in which companies are essentially “Big Brother/machine overlords” and tracking their every move, additionally, managers prefer not to micromanage, rather they’d like their employees to be as empowered as possible to get their jobs done There are already many task-management & productivity digital services, so our AI needs to provide value above and beyond simple task management and allocation of work.
content.calloutBody: reveal the realities of productivity to enhance individual and company workflow?
insights: Both managers and individual contributors are uncomfortable with work environments in which companies are essentially “Big Brother/machine overlords” and tracking their every move, additionally, managers prefer not to micromanage,  rather they’d like their employees to be as empowered as possible to get their jobs done
There are already many task-management & productivity digital services, so our AI needs to provide value above and beyond simple task management and allocation of work
content.next:
What if there was a way to reveal insights about your skills and competencies to give you actionable insights on the kinds of team structures and organizations you work best on?
What if we could use the shared insight of this data to determine & define the overall culture of a company? What if there was a way to reveal what organizations have work cultures that best align with your own?
We’d like to do more testing to figure out what would incentivize people to track their data & share it with others
Customers: End User: Individual consumers who would like to be more productive. They are currently pulled in different directions at work and would like to get a better handle on how they’re spending their days & time. These could be individual managers - interested in improving themselves and their personal development along with their team’s personal development. This could also be freelancers, who go into different workplaces and need to quickly adapt to the work culture and produce value.
Experience: Customers would purchase our product and sync it to their work device (laptop+phone). The AI would run seamlessly in the background, highlighting different moments or interactions throughout the day to improve personal & team productivity & integrate with existing
Value: The data we provide allows consumers more insight into their personal workstyles, skills, projects and collaboration styles . They can use this data to be more productive in their current work environments and to quickly assimilate into new work environments. With this synthesized data, they can easily keep track of their skills and the types of projects/teams they’ve worked on and share their personal profile internally when seeking promotions or new projects or externally when seeking a new job.
Pricing: Freemium model: Free tier: for individuals to track their own data & sync their data with 1 other person. Paid tier: monthly or yearly subscription for enterprises to sync data from multiple teams
content.why:
We followed a structured process in this three day sprint:

Day 1: We tackled our HMW, developed 4 different prototypes and sent out an invitation to IDEO employees to join us at a happy hour in order test 2 prototypes. Our goal was to make information already available in the workplace more tacit and real vs hidden

Prototype #1:
Genius Bar: A place that people can come for help.
Questions we asked: I’m exploring how to improve productivity in the workplace. Is there anything you worked on today that you could talk about?
Assumption: That workers needed help with projects today, but did not ask for it. That they’d like a place to come and get help without having to explicitly ask.

Prototype #2:
WaterCooler: Hotspot of activity Robotics, Ants & Neuroscience experts will be available to chat.
Assumption: That workers need inspiration during the day to lead to productivity. We’re testing to see if work conversations will inherently come out?
Result: During conversation, “work topics” did not naturally arise, but we discovered that at IDEO, there are already natural “hotspots of activity”. By nature of sitting in certain areas, this indicates that people are available if help is needed.

Prototype #3: Personal Prioritization Board:
Prioritize the 3 tasks that you’d like to get done today. We’ll create a big sign over their workspace to broadcast these priorities.
Assumption: We’d like to test people’s priorities vs the team’s priorities. That providing transparency on work priorities is beneficial for the team & individuals productivity.
Result: The teams felt the prioritization board was in the wrong form as it wasn’t in their face and not relevant to them since the all already knew what to work on. As a project manager, Ali wished the board would be visible for some of her teams.

Day 2: We conducted user interviews, built & tested our prototypes with users and reached an inflection point of whether we should keep the focus on the team or pivot to the individual. After doing some research on potential solutions already in the workplace, we realized that we needed to strengthen fulcrum’s benefit to the end user so that they’d use our platform. During our interviews, we discovered that:
- When people are passionate about their work, they’d like to be able to understand how to do it better
- There are disruptions that happen during the day - and people don’t want these automated out, but would like them to be compartmentalized
- Individuals or teams don’t want big brother - however, inputs that surface latent moments where productivity could be augmented would be helpful

-KaFzTNoM4za_2BiOcQa.desc: A system that combines sensing and machine learning of behavioral data to improve productivity and collaboration throughout the workday.
-KaFzTNoM4za_2BiOcQa.subtitle: The future of work
-KaFzTNoM4za_2BiOcQa.title: Fulcrum

card.desc: A peer-to-peer network of servers that acts as a virtual Content Delivery Network.

content.body: Shortcut is a network system to reduce latency over a broadband network for high bandwidth tasks (like playing a Netflix movie) by allowing peers to connect and share storage space for shared tasks. Using IPFS technology, Shortcut facilitates peer-to-peer connections across a distributed network. This network improves end users' latency by making use of the underutilized assets of downstream bandwidth and device memory. IPFS requests are magnitudes faster than traditional HTTP requests resulting in millions of dollars in cost savings for Internet Service Providers and Content Providers while improving the end user experience. Our system connects devices who are looking to consume the same content (such as a new episode of Game of Thrones, streamed from HBO), negotiates an exchange for downstream bandwidth and access to device memory, and delivers that content more seamlessly to the end user.
content.calloutBody: reduce latency across a network of users?
insights: Optimizing data allocation strategy (i.e., distributing the availability of content across the network) is critical.
Existing Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) are exploring P2P sharing models but its full potential has yet to be realized.
Addressing privacy and security concerns for end users is important to gain their trust when deploying a backend system.
content.why: We were inspired by energy companies that pay people to use excess energy throughout the day. We wondered if we could create an analogue, in a different industry—if we could reduce latency for content delivery by incentivizing people to share device memory. If people in the same geographic  area were watching a similar show, everyone benefits by seeing it served up faster.

-KaFzppBZbBbEBhkVCrB.desc: A peer-to-peer network of servers that acts as a virtual Content Delivery Network.
-KaFzppBZbBbEBhkVCrB.subtitle: Faster Streaming by P2P
-KaFzppBZbBbEBhkVCrB.title: Shortcut

card.desc: A friendly bot that brings you light when you need it, where you need it, and just how you need it.

content.body: A self mapping and navigating bot that, when invited, will direct itself to the desired location — such as the couch, office desk, or kitchen table. In an office, the bot would be capable of delivering itself to a specific office, conference room, or work station. Instead of having 300 individual task lights for 300 architects in an office, there could be much fewer that are distributed and redistributed on demand to workstations and breakout spaces.
content.calloutBody: How might we leverage a resource-intensive item and make it more used/useful in an environment?
insights: Even though the Create 2 from iRobot is touted as a “programmable robot,” there are very few resources that enable a user to “plug and play” hack into it. It was extremely difficult to find libraries for standard microprocessors such as Arduino and Photon. We eventually went to using a MATLAB toolbox developed by the US Naval Academy that utilized the serial port. At the moment, the ability to use something like a Roomba to make a useful, programmable bot, is very limited. Another type of open source bot/drone might be much more suited for this type of technology.

One question that came up was “How do we prioritize user needs?” If two people need light, how does the bot decide who gets the light? This can be extrapolated to larger moral and ethical questions of how should resources be autonomously allocated?

We found through this prototype that beyond being a convenience or luxury to have light autonomously brought to people, there was no compelling need for specific item. People found it “nice but not necessary” and the “nicety” of the device was not enough to prompt much of a business case for it. We could imagine a business case could be made for more complex bots that could be more useful in everyday life - bringing the elderly daily medication and other needs, helping with cooking, etc.
content.why:
1) We were charged with really focusing on delivering a resource in a literal, physical, prototypable way. We decided to focus on delivery light within a home or office as a lightweight version of the potential to deliver any number of resources, such as emergency generators or emergency batteries.

2) We wanted to answer the question of how we could teach a robot its location, the desired location of a light, and then have the robot autonomously deliver the light.

3) We validated that this is possible without preloading the robot with a map of the space. The robot can map and navigate simultaneously, the only inputs required are the goal location, robot start point, and boundaries of the room (size of the room).

-KaG-DjRtRn94pF2bKhw.desc: A friendly bot that brings you light when you need it, where you need it, and just how you need it.
-KaG-DjRtRn94pF2bKhw.subtitle: An autonomous light droid
-KaG-DjRtRn94pF2bKhw.title: Eddi

card.desc: A platform that integrates with Electronic Medical Records to track disease spread

content.body:
The landscape of medical data today is complex and fragmented. Patient data, external medical records, and literature are all assessed and managed separately, through protocols which sacrifice efficiency for security. KeyMD is a platform for global medical insights. It connects hospitals around the world with other hospitals, as well as government organizations who benefit from crucial medical information shared across boundaries while protecting privacy.

KeyMD Mixes medical record information and external data to make meaningful observations. It enables patient’s medical records to be accessed anonymously from anywhere. Data is encrypted and HIPAA compliant. KeyMD doesn’t replace current EMR software. It goes one level up, combing them all and then returning non-patient specific information back to each software program. It can be used to diagnose difficult cases by extending the doctor’s knowledge with literature, environmental data, and millions of records. It can enable dynamic forms that immediately flag risk factors based on what’s happening with people’s health worldwide. Because it securely informs government offices, it can also predict and communicate epidemic data to multiple parties.
content.calloutBody: get global data points to communicate with and learn from one another?
insights: HIPAA compliance is a large barrier to entry in the healthcare space, that can be solved if there was a seamless way to de-identify and share data across multiple parties.
In healthcare, everyone sees the opportunity for shared information but no system talks to any other system.

Starting with compliance. The next step would be to build a prototype for a singular point in the network - likely the nodes between the institution (hospital) and the authorities (CDC, etc.) This allows for data that is already shared (no privacy concerns) being shared in a more real time, repurposable way
content.why:
We wanted to focus on what truth means in the context of overwhelming data. That sent us down a path to identify a domain that could benefit from a node-based structure. 
We believe data is stuck in silos, but if each field in a form could be an individual Nomad node, we could protect individual privacy by sharing the most critical information.
Today, there is significant latency between the outbreak of a disease and reports being parsed at the CDC about that outbreak. We imagine a system that streams that information, live, so that government agencies can react more quickly.

-KaG-STeHh1Q_ijyMZsn.desc: A platform that integrates with Electronic Medical Records to track disease spread
-KaG-STeHh1Q_ijyMZsn.subtitle: Global medical insights
-KaG-STeHh1Q_ijyMZsn.title: KeyMD

card.desc: A platform to dynamically connect communities with resources

content.body:
InReach dynamically connects consumers to mobile services they need. Our team created an interactive real-time demand map that illustrates how the epicenter of demand for a particular service changes over time. Our goal is to enable service providers (e.g. specialized exercise equipment, lounges, nap pods, swim-in-place pools, haircuts, food trucks etc.) to travel throughout the day on a mobile, semi-autonomous truck we're calling an InReach Unit (IRU) to the epicenter of real-time demand for their particular service. Our system clusters demand and routes IRUs to areas of high demand.


Initially, we imagine people manually indicating desire for a particular service on a phone application, paying more money to weight their demand node more heavily and thus summon a service closer to them. In later iterations of the application, we can leverage machine learning to identify patterns in individual behavior, as well as trends across a city, in order to predict where demand will be the highest. In addition to a demand map prototype, we created a simple Nomad node for an IRU, and UX mockups for a phone application.
content.calloutBody: better connect communities with resources and/or services dynamically?
insights: A technological opportunity exists to make services as dynamic and mobile as people, increasing efficiency by responding to real-time demand across a city.

Food trucks have wheels, and yet barely make use of their mobile nature. They might as well be storefronts, in many cases. A real-time demand map enables services, even those that are already mobile, to take advantage of that mobility.
content.next: What legal issues arise around conducting a business from a parking spot?
content.why:
LOCATIONS: People seem to be interested in having services near their homes, workplaces, bus/train stations, and locations they wouldn’t normally be able to access. Their needs for these services changes over time (making it unrealistic to require a permanent open retail shop) but they are willing to pay to get a gym near them.

SERVICES: Food and medical services (e.g. dispensaries) were services that people were initially interested in. All people we spoke to expressed interest in other services becoming more mobile and accessible. Mobile services like hair salons could locate in relevant areas based on the highest demonstrated interest.

LIMITS: Some neighborhoods suffer from limited varieties of establishments and early closing times. Creating mobile units, like food trucks, could help solve this problem.

-KaG-hiiYEWoI3BVoZv0.desc: A platform to dynamically connect communities with resources
-KaG-hiiYEWoI3BVoZv0.subtitle: Real-time demand map for mobile, specialized services
-KaG-hiiYEWoI3BVoZv0.title: inReach

card.desc: An AI platform that uses machine learning to humanize the reputation of home repair professionals.

content.body: PRISM uses A.I. to aggregate and analyze online reviews of home repair professionals then expands the rating system into a multidimensional representation of their reputation. The user, given a dire need to find a repair person, enters a request for exactly what they need in natural language, and the service extracts their intentions (electrician, plumber, etc) and preferences using AI and pattern matching. It then uses the Yelp API and web scraping to collect and analyze the sentiment of reviews for their requested service, then scores and ranks the results according to the sentiments of the reviews relevant to their preferences.
content.calloutBody: How might we create a multidimensional representation of a repairman's reputation?
insights: One friend > a hundred strangers: A friend’s personal recommendation overrides a bunch of other people’s opinions online.

Sentiment analysis needs context: To accurately represent reputation from  online reviews, the AI will need to process not only the semantics and sentiment of the textual data, but the context in which they were reviewed. For example, if a person had a particularly bad day or is known for having a poor disposition, a successful AI would take this into account to avoid bias.

Sources Need Synthesis: In order to get the best picture of a repairman's reputation, we need to be able to synthesize results from a variety of sources and eventually collect and crosscheck more objective data.
content.next: Create a functional version of this system – that atomizes reviews in this manner and feeds it back into the system.
content.why:
We started off with our basic model for viewing open reputation: Collecting data --> Verifying and Modeling --> Communicating --> Decision Making From our first brainstorming session, we knew that the process of choosing a serviceman for a job could be a daunting task; we originally tried to do this using IOT to measure the person's performance, but realized that there could be a lot of potential in processing all of the existing information in the form of reviews. From this, we believed that we could remove the extreme bias that's inherently present in most reviews on a one dimensional scale (the star rating system) and transform it into a multi-dimensional representation of a serviceman's reputation. Reputation as a whole is still very much based in the stories that communities tell about you, and we wanted to harness this as much as possible.

We believed that we could use AI in this pursuit in two ways: 1) To pick out the preferences of a user in order to emphasize a particular aspect of a serviceman's reputation. 2) To analyze the reviews in order to give a truly quantitative spin on the different dimensions of a repairman's performance. We also got the opportunity to talk to specific stakeholders in the process, who educated us on certain factors that could take precedence in the design. From this we realized that a fully ""chatbot""-esque interface (which was the original intention) would work poorly for emergency purposes, since multiple questions slows the process of getting what they want. Many also said, concerning the review system, that it was naturally a very biased and arbitrary process, thus confirming our original hypothesis. Beyond this, we also talked to Allan about how to display the information to the user, who suggested the importance of comparing the given results to an average/baseline.

In designing the interface, we wanted to make it as simple and painless as possible. Hence, while we included buttons to indicate preference, we also allowed for simple pattern matching (AI in a more advanced, ideal prototype) to pick out the user's preferences from the natural language in the text and dynamically highlight these choices. Additionally, we took the info from the user stories in order to provide a clickthrough link for the top result, as well as the top five relevant reviews and a radar chart indicating the repairman's top preferences.

-KaG05yopb_GOo_zJ0Yv.desc: An AI platform that uses machine learning to humanize the reputation of home repair professionals.
-KaG05yopb_GOo_zJ0Yv.subtitle: Optimized referrals for repairmen
-KaG05yopb_GOo_zJ0Yv.title: Prism

card.desc: A virtual pharmacist that manages inventory across a distributed network.
card.thumbAlt: Shelf that can sense products on it

content.body: V.Pharm is a virtual pharmacist that manages inventory across a distributed network. The prototype takes the form of a cardboard prototype of our V.Pharm tray in conjunction with an API.ai chatbot available via the Google Home. The chatbot enables a human-machine partnership with pharmacists in the field – relying on the human to report inventory levels or usage, while the system logs levels for replenishment. The tray demonstrates the modularity of our system because it could be placed in existing drug inventory cabinets. It is three light sensors connected to an arduino, connected to a nodejs process running locally on a mac os that continually sends http requests to a php application running on an aws server. The php application handles application logic and updating our database to maintain the physical state of the tray. The user "uses" drugs by saying so to the Google Home and can order more drugs through it as well.
content.calloutBody: How might communities reduce their resource burden by better coordinating their usage and behaviors?
insights: Voice interfaces are welcoming and exciting to users when they see them in use.
The voice interface provides an instantly-deployable way to track inventory without the need to add many sensors or train machine learning systems.
The concept of building a connected network of inventory seems desirable.
Subject matter experts saw many applications for voice in combination with smart inventory.
content.next: Pilot a more robust prototype on a small-scale where inventory tracking is important.
content.why: We started off with 'Smart Pantry' in sprint 1. We found the voice interaction to be intriguing but felt that consumer food inventory didn't have a need for this. We identified a user that could benefit from this technology and used the rural health care worker as a guide for designing a drug inventory system. We then questioned whether a primary school educated health care worker would be comfortable using voice as an interface. We designed a prototype around that question. We brainstormed future expansions to be focused around a network of centers and managing inventory among that system.

-KaG0XOGqtPU9wOE3iRi.desc: A virtual pharmacist that manages inventory across a distributed network.

hero.imageAlt: Shelf that can sense products on it
hero.title: V.Pharm

-KaG0XOGqtPU9wOE3iRi.subtitle: Siri for drug inventory
-KaG0XOGqtPU9wOE3iRi.title: V.Pharm

card.desc: AR glasses that give meaningful context cues so that people can have better conversation using AI.
card.thumbAlt: VR Man with info above him

content.body: Super Glasses are an AR application to make conversations more meaningful by provides body language interpretation and social media cues. It's built on a non-invasive headset that displays virtual interface, embedded in existing eyewear. Context cues are generated using machine learning and neural network AI to aggregate information from APIs of existing social networking and find meaningful commonalities between individuals. It also recognizes and translates verbal and nonverbal communication and offers suggestions constantly to streamline and improve communication.
content.calloutBody: What role, if any, does AR have in inter-personal relationships?
insights: While we built SuperGlasses for social interactions, it has significant therapeutic benefits for people with autism or other disorders. It also could be used to deescalate unsafe or heated interactions by suggesting new conversation topics..

Our prototype raised concerns about privacy and trust that become more relevant as we become more connected and transparent. How much better will social interactions need to get for people to feel comfortable being recorded and analyzed, and avoid the “Glasshole” effect?

Partnership is critical for most AR applications, if we want our realities to actually surface meaningful and personalized information. SuperGlasses will need to partner with a social media company, face recognition or body language technology company, and healthcare companies to be most effectively.
content.why: Today, conversation can be vacuous because people often lack information about commonality and body language and subtle facial expressions are often difficult to decipher. Superglasses solves this problem by layering social interactions with things in common (like recognizing a friend, and reminding you that his favorite sports team just won a championship) and constantly interpreting body language (such as noticing a furrowed brow and helping people with social anxiety recognize that as a social cue). Our AR app is built on the Google Pixel and uses facial recognition, social integration and machine learning to smooth social interactions.

-KaG1QvREpdZVUgqq8Vl.desc: AR glasses that give meaningful context cues so that people can have better conversation using AI.

hero.imageAlt: VR Man with info above him
hero.title: Super Glasses

-KaG1QvREpdZVUgqq8Vl.subtitle: Talk smart
-KaG1QvREpdZVUgqq8Vl.title: Super Glasses

card.desc: An AI-powered charitable giving tool

content.body: Givewell is an iPhone app that learns about your interests and values, and automatically donates to relevant causes based on real time news and trends and event triggers. It uses artificial intelligence to scan news headlines for events that affect causes you care about, and automatically allocates your charitable giving budget each month across causes.
content.calloutBody: How might we spend a portion of our disposable income effectively and automatically in a way that is relevant to our interests and values?
insights: While there are other platforms that facilitate personalized donating, an AI solution would be able to respond  more dynamically to current events, but decision making would also be less transparent to the user.
content.next: If we were to continue working on this project, we'd explore ways to simplify the ui and ux, as well as other ways to apply a feedback loop for machine learning.
content.why:
We were intrigued by the idea of building a socially embedded prototype that helped you to do things you knew you "should" do, but required a lot of work to get to. It takes a lot for humans to parse all relevant information about causes they care about, and make choices about charitable giving actively.
Most people are "set it and forget it" about their finances, including their donations. We sought to create a system that let you "set it and forget it" while trusting an AI to do the active portfolio management you know that you should do, but never get to.

card.desc: An energy audit system that gives your home self-awareness leveraging distributed sensors.

content.body:
Parker is a federated brain which collects information from a distributed network of sensors through someone's home, as well as takes in external data such as weather. This system then uses that information to assess the energy efficiency of the user's home. By triangulating data from all of these different nodes, Parker is meant to give the homeowner very specific guidance as to what they can do to improve the energy efficiency of their home.

This guidance covers big capital project suggestions such as replacing windows or insulting a room, all the way down to small daily activities, such as closing the shades in a room to prevent it from heating from sunlight or remembering to close a door to prevent a wind draft.
content.calloutBody: How might we correlate many types of data to better gather meaningful, trusted information?
insights: Powerline Networking - The existing electrical infrastructure can be leveraged as the communication vehicle for a disparate set of sensors across broader networks than just the home, like the neighborhood or city.
Open Platforms - Open sensor networks can provide a platform for new applications. New data sources can deliver insights into a variety of consumer and machine actions.
Interdependent Topics - Our brief actually had 3 distinct areas that need to be explored further: Identity, Resiliency, & Meaning.
content.next: Buid a functional verson of this concept with partners from energy and insurance.
content.why:
We started out by plotting our insights from previous sprints on our foam board. We were guided to verifying insulation as a use case, which relates to energy. We aligned our scope and focus around automating home energy audits. We wanted to be as concrete and real as possible so after considering the options we wanted something that we could demo like the solar power rec's prototype. This prototype uses a bunch of nomad nodes to establish the chain of dependencies in the information while doing basic operations like time stamping the data or cleaning it up.

We then used a local host nomad go server to run a local website that subscribed to the composite node and rendered it plus doing calculations unique to our application so it doesn't dirty the data. It then can actually render in real time the change in pressure indicating door opening and other sorts of house interactions and provide relevant recommendations.

-KacLA-9zVSI3SaF-q9O.desc: An energy audit system that gives your home self-awareness leveraging distributed sensors.
-KacLA-9zVSI3SaF-q9O.subtitle: Auto Home Energy Audit
-KacLA-9zVSI3SaF-q9O.title: Parker

card.desc: Using machine learning to align civic priorities with public sentiment to manage non-emergency services
card.thumbAlt: User posting a pothole in app

content.body:
Our prototype has two parts:

1) chatbot that interfaces with the 'citizen' to report 311 issues, its Messenger-based and hosted on Heroku;

2) Machine learning - Historical scoring of 311 data records by encoding twitter sentiment and safety concerns to represent the historical priority of an issue. Word2vec was used to identify BOS311 tweets that correlated to 311 data records. Twitter data was captured via twitter API and mapped against categories from a database of 311 requests (from city.boston.gov). We began to apply simple Machine learning was to this historical dataset to predict the prioritization of future records given a number of factors present in the 311 data- requires a lot more room for improvement because the model was overfit (if we had more time)
content.calloutBody: How might we recognize changes in public sentiment to reduce the disconnect between public expectations and government priorities?
insights: Sentiment analysis is not accurate or precise enough to understand implicit assumptions or contextual clues in natural language
Understanding “intent” is a really hard problem based on current technology—difficult to correlate social media data to categorical data
Machine learning programs must be continuously trained with incoming, real-time data, otherwise it becomes static and possibly irrelevant over time
How you program the algorithm for priority of an intent can have a huge impact on the amount of bias programmed in the AI
The city cares about public opinion and needs.
However, there is a disconnect between the city and public due to timescale and unavailable information (e.g. 5-year construction plan).
The city tries to mediate this disconnect by setting public expectations but can’t always do it.
Employees use their own experience managing issues to prioritize.
Citizens appreciate “a human touch” with up-to-date, transparent information."
content.why:
We accessed the Boston 311 Open Data system, which we decided to leverage for our communal AI prototype. To better understand the dynamics of the city & civilians, we spoke to a variety of users in the city decision-making ecosystem. We spoke to Lee Gianetti, who is the Communications Director for the City of Cambridge about the 311 process. We also spoke to Soroush from the MIT Media Lab (Lab for Social Machines), a citizen we found on the streets of Central Square while using 311, and Kris from Urban Mechanics (Boston's skunkworks projects department). We even visited a senior community center to get a feel for the values of the Central Square community and look for opportunities.

We learned about the journey of an incoming 311 request as well as all of the different factors that contribute to the prioritization of a 311 issue. We realized that there were two problems: how the citizens experience the 311 system in the form of communication and how the government makes decisions about 311 priorities (and how they try to take public sentiment into account). We wanted to explore the question of how we might measure and leverage public sentiment to provide better alignment in civic priorities, e.g. deciding which 311 issues to address when, or monitoring bike lane obstructions because the city of Cambridge cares about bikes. We also realized the solution needed to increase transparency around issue resolution with the public, e.g. If you report that your street needs to be cleaned, the city can immediately tell you its already been scheduled, so the citizen feels heard and knows the resolution.

-KacLBGCcnT-Mre9Q8kl.desc: Using machine learning to align civic priorities with public sentiment to manage non-emergency services

hero.imageAlt: User posting a pothole in app
hero.title: C-311PO

-KacLBGCcnT-Mre9Q8kl.subtitle: ‘Waze’ for Civic Problems
-KacLBGCcnT-Mre9Q8kl.title: C-311PO

card.desc: Frond uses conversational AI and AR to assist students transitioning into a new school.
card.thumbAlt: Visual AR detecting emotion in students

content.body: Through AI, Frond offers students safe place to process emotions, a helping hand in dealing with difficult situations, personalized development recommendations, and guidance in reaching out to adults when necessary. Teachers can better understand a student’s emotional state and how it might impact their academic performance, monitor the sentiment of a classroom in real time, and gain insights to personalize interactions with students through AR.
content.calloutBody: What role does AR play in facilitating interpersonal connection?
insights: Artificial intelligence seems to imply the need to replace humans; for some, a better conceptual model is intelligence augmentation - using machine learning to make existing human relationships better. For us, this meant that instead of building a bot to replace a school guidance counselor or take the place of a friend, we built a bot to encourage kids to seek out help and become more confident.
Talking to a screen can help people be more true to themselves. Kids will text school counselors as a way to put out social feelers without being face to face, especially with sensitive subjects.

To have a truly empathetic AI, we need better ways of assigning value to non-numerical data. Emotional data relies on faces or a binary sentiment analysis, but more structured training data is required for predictive models.

Incorporating new technology into a classroom is inherently risky. Teachers are especially sensitive to concerns about student privacy and the liabilities associated with access to student data (or things obstructing their field of vision).
content.next: Engage civic, healthcare, or academic partners to find potential applications for surfacing personal data with AR
content.why:
American schools have continued to de-segregate students, causing them to feel displaced and there is currently no place for these students to safely express their emotions and act on it. We looked at methods to “smooth” the inherently disruptive transition between different educational environments. We had thought about a physical place as refuge for these emotions which later transitioned to a more remote and accessible app. After extensive interviews with counselors, government officials in the DOJ and students we were convinced that anonymity and ease of access were important aspects to the project. Moving forward, greater focus could be dedicated to using A.I. to predict these situations allowing the student to more adequately prepare for the change in environment.

We discussed how to get students to use this bot - which is important because it gets better as it receives more data. We thought about if students would rather use an app during a time required in class, or if it would be something done spontaneously. Our discussions with teachers led us to move away from a model that was too structured or disruptive to the school environment - we wanted the students to feel comfortable using the bot as a personal space. However, by allowing teachers (and potentially others) to view personal data, we introduced privacy concerns that warrant further exploration.

The use of augmented reality as a way to visualize data dynamically was an exciting challenge - we assumed that the initial qualms expressed by teachers would subside as the hardware progressed, and focused on designing an experience for the future of AR. This also gave us a platform to visualize hidden insights from the AI. "

-KacLCaml_dr0BDIJxgz.desc: Frond uses conversational AI and AR to assist students transitioning into a new school.

hero.imageAlt: Visual AR detecting emotion in students
hero.title: Frond

-KacLCaml_dr0BDIJxgz.subtitle: HAL but not evil; Tom Riddle's diary but not a horcux
-KacLCaml_dr0BDIJxgz.title: Frond

card.desc: AR enabled game to visualize home energy usage to create more efficient behavior

content.body:
White Fang is an Augmented Reality game that makes it fun for kids to learn about energy and form better habits around efficient energy behavior it. Through our gaming app, kids can help grow a lovable polar bear avatar through energy saving activities (hand washing dishes, reading instead of watching TV, turned down the thermostat and building a blanket fort to stay warm, etc.). We also have an sensor (hacked from a Kill-A-Watt) that publishes energy data from a specific appliance to a nomad node. The nomad node then pushes this information to the app, so that the game can respond to energy usage in the house.

In the future this would work via a home energy usage disaggregator (like Sense) or some other IoT enabled home device. We also hope in the future to leverage social networks to create community wide behavior change (the polar bears could 'fight' for example, so there is competition to have a stronger bear and thus more efficient energy behavior). Through small behavior changes around very specific actions (turning down the thermostat) we hope to create long term habit formation over good behaviors that protect our planet.
content.calloutBody: How might we create meaning from home energy usage data to encourage more sustainable consumption patterns?
insights: AR is great helping people visualize data in ways that are more meaningful and can help generate empathy.
Translating specific actions into sustained habits is the key to behavior change.
Energy is boring to most people, long term engagement is difficult to sustain because of this, and monetary savings are too small to incentivize significant change.
content.next:
Explore whether we can get data granular enough to be engaging at the appliance level:

_Find partners (like Sense or Smappee) to get appliance-level data.

_Work with Utilities to create a pilot program.

_Contact the Fluid Interfaces group at the MIT Media Lab to review current and past research projects that may be relevant.
content.why: Energy is boring to most people. Savings from energy conservation are too minimal to incentivize efficient behaviors, and engagement with inert data tends to drop off quickly. Data alone is not enough to change behavior, no matter how many analytics are layered on – it needs to be linked with values and stories that resonate with people, and tied to specific actions. Thus, we wanted to make something fun to keep people interested.

-KacLEJeOe-v9QRZkcTB.desc: AR enabled game to visualize home energy usage to create more efficient behavior
-KacLEJeOe-v9QRZkcTB.subtitle: Pokemon meets Nest
-KacLEJeOe-v9QRZkcTB.title: White Fang

card.desc: An app that analyzes human speech, then provides feedback to improve collaboration.

content.body:
By leveraging individual smartphone microphones we are able to pull multiple streams of audio in meetings. That audio is broken into two paths, one is the audio stream which is analyzed for elements of the physical sound and interpreted by our AI to create the Vocal Intonation. Seven audio elements make up the speech personality: (1) pitch, including pitch range and inflection patterns; (2) volume (degree of loudness); (3) tempo, or rate of delivery; (4) vitality, or energy; (5) voice quality, including resonance, timbre, and tone; (6) pronunciation; and (7) articula­tion, sometimes referred to as diction or enunciation (the movement of speech organs to make speech sounds).

The second audio stream is then converted to text and the content analyzed for a number of key factors. These factors include predicted intent and text analytics discovered (word count, etc.) The two streams are then combined to provide deeper insight into the current conversation that is happening. These insights are then materialized in views to direct the individuals to transform the team into a high performing team. The team will become more efficient by producing better outcomes and increase speed to those outcomes. Additionally, employees will increase the trust they have with their teammates, become aware of bias that they were previously unaware of and have higher job satisfaction.
content.calloutBody: How might revealing invisible information help us monitor and enhance our environments?
content.desc: An app that analyzes human speech, then provides feedback to improve collaboration.
insights: Speech to text recognition is both an opportunity and limitation - it works, but has latency issues, very hard to do real-time analysis
Neural networks and deep learning present a great opportunity for using AI to really adapt and become useful to specific groups of people
Speaker recognition is difficult. Recognizing multiple speakers talking at once is even more difficult and still an area of much research (blind source separation)
AI could remove biases currently inherent in using human facilitators
Call centers currently use humans to analyze how talks went. They record everything so there is a plethora of data waiting to be analyzed by an AI!

There is already a lot of great research into intonation analysis (BeyondVerbal API: Like body language, our vocal intonations are language and culture agnostic. The API was built out of analysis of 40 languages in 170 countries.)
content.next:
Create a functional app using the existing APIs 
Explore the identification of speech acts 
Explore multiple real time interfaces for participants  
Explore AI capabilities that would increase the effectiveness of achord"
content.why:
We began by considering the various physical attributes of our environment that are “invisible” to us - everything from energy consumption, air & water quality, temperature, smells, sounds, wireless communications and more. Explored unsensed realities based on our senses, mainly hearing and sight based on the everyday interactions or our work.  

From there, we arrived at a few main questions: How might an AI reveal latent information from human behavior? How might AI gather “passive” information and data for pattern recognition? How might an AI nudge a human to change behavior? How might a listening AI proactively facility and improve human collaboration?

We built our prototype to help answer these questions and get rapid feedback from people in industries who might use this to determine whether or not it would be well-received and if there is a deep need for this technology.

-KacLFmEeVX2yi6BFa6r.desc: An app that analyzes human speech, then provides feedback to improve collaboration.
-KacLFmEeVX2yi6BFa6r.subtitle: Human Harmony
-KacLFmEeVX2yi6BFa6r.title: achord

card.desc: Inter-company tracking and routing of line-workers in emergency situations.

content.body:
Eta is a line-worker efficiency app to help energy companies better track and allocate skilled workers after an emergency weather event.

The app is on line-worker phones, and also connects to a central coordinator for them to oversee all issues. The first functionality of the app is to track your location and upload it to the Blockchain with a timestamp every 30 seconds. This allows a central authority to know where all workers are at any time for both better tracking of how long they were out in the field and if they were in unsafe conditions if there are any complaints from OSHA, unions or lending energy companies. Next steps for this functionality are to add in a button so you can designate yourself when you are ""on,"" ""off,"" or ""lunch breaking,"" etc for better hour tracking.

The second functionality is a vibration/impact sensor in the app. Every 10 seconds it uploads to the blockchain if there have been any dramatic impacts to the phone (like if you fall off a ladder or are hit by a truck). If this occurs, the central coordinator sees a red pin pop up on the map and for them to dispatch someone else to check up on them. Next steps for this functionality are to add a pop-up on worker screen if impact is detected asking if they are ok. A non-response will be assumed as a no.

The third functionality involves better updating conditions at work sites and then prioritizing them for workers. The map shows a series of pins: Green are low priority sites, yellow are mid-priority sites and red pins are where someone may have fallen or been hurt (as per last function). If you click on the pin, you can see more info on what is going on there and even some pictures. Color coded priority level is based on these reports. The app allows workers to update the pins of info from the field and add pictures in case conditions weren't what scouts originally described. Next steps for this functionality are to build out a ranking system based on sensor data to help automatically deploy worker teams to the most important issues in a decentralized and automatic manner. This functionality will take into account what skills and tools are on each truck and allocate them to the issues they are able to tackle.
content.calloutBody: How might we help utility companies monitor line workers during storms in an open and immutable ledger system to maximize safety?
insights: Our research did not validate the need for bidding as part of a crew sharing system.
Teams can perceive micromanagement if tracked by app.
Advanced planning (like the summer before storms hit) is most helpful -- map out beforehand where you could send trailers, where you can refuel, etc so no need during crisis.
It's still unknown if Blockchain adds value where multiple organizations are sharing resources.
Better scouting / info gathering of the issues is key for efficiency once workers are on the ground.
content.next:
Build an inter-operable tracking system for line crews.

Build a request & respond system for coordinating crews.

Further develop the event tracking aspects of the application.
content.why:
We were originally started off with a prompt to build a bidding system between companies, ala pop-up market prompt. This was quickly determined to not be desirable by companies. We shifted to then figuring out how to be more efficiently allocating line workers to tasks that need their specific skills most.

One of the biggest insights is that there is tremendous spending on logistical issues. (i.e. acquiring hotels, trailers, catering food etc.) That one of the biggest problems is being able to damage assess as accurately as possible. The more accurate the assessment the more efficient the resource allocation can be deployed across the different substations, zones, and crew. We found that even with sensor data, on the ground scouts, and social media reporting, there is still a lot of ambiguity and guessing that goes into resource allocation. This led us to create an app that is from a bottom up approach. Empowering line workers to add resource orders to an immutable ledger for all OMS and ROD to be cross reference with. So lets say a line worker shows up to a job with Cretan resource from crew and equipment. They soon realize this job is much more than the original assessment and will need more linemen and equipment. This can be captured via photo and data input so that the need resources can be immediately sent to all parties who are in charge of resource allocation.

-KacLHOztUjr9IhCqpoL.desc: Inter-company tracking and routing of line-workers in emergency situations.
-KacLHOztUjr9IhCqpoL.subtitle: Deployment of line workers
-KacLHOztUjr9IhCqpoL.title: η (eta)

card.desc: Cred is a web tool to reveal the credibility of news content for consumers and content creators.

content.body:
In the age of low barriers to entering publishing, high degrees of consumer choice, and a huge amount of fake and untrustworthy news, what is reliable journalism? With cred, we have designed a web navigator tool to reveal the reliability of news content for both news consumers and newsmakers:

Cred is a web browser extension that attaches a trustworthy metric score to news articles and their sources. This metric reveals how much other readers trust the publication, how many other sources corroborate the information and the journey that the story has taken over time, and provides a feedback mechanism for readers to indicate whether or not they trust the article.

How does an article’s cred, get determined? It involves several factors including:

- Combination of the author’s reputation, publisher’s reputation, and news topic itself (how breaking, etc.)
- General Metrics for any one article published online (track changes in articles over time--either by accessing any single site’s API if they make it available or scraping the actual article themselves when they are updated. The quality of changes (or lack thereof) is based on the quality of the content being changed (are the numbers being corrected to their “correct” values) and the time it takes to make those accurate changes)
- Author equation: Past articles--(article quality)*(traction/readership)*(reviews)*(background in topic)*(ranking if available)
-
Publisher Equation: Past articles--(article quality)*(traction/readership)*(reviews)*(domain specialization?)*(general rating)

Cred creates value for consumers by giving newsreaders an alternative metric for determining how reliable the article is in comparison to other articles reporting on the same breaking news.

We create value for newsmakers and aggregators by revealing:
- How reliable does the public think I am/my feeds?
- How reliable am I in relation to other journalists?
- How does my article’s reliability change over time?

And we create value for the press industry by creating a broad use metric / reference point for reliability
content.calloutBody: create a metric to determine the reliability of news?
insights: We could see the reliability metric creating a new ecosystem for news content online. Could it develop a into medium where journalists not only input their stories, but also search for & source information? Could we continue to transform it into a new way to trace a claim and how it morphs over time?

We learned that there are implications to the technology that we’re creating that need to be explored further. Could a reliability metric attached to journalists have a chilling effect on the decisions behind the news they choose to report on and reinforce a “herd mentality” where journalists have a fear of being the first to break new news because it’s“unreliable”?

-KacLIo06z5leqa_0mgb.desc: Cred is a web tool to reveal the credibility of news content for consumers and content creators.
-KacLIo06z5leqa_0mgb.subtitle: Rely on news
-KacLIo06z5leqa_0mgb.title: Cred

card.desc: Authentity verifies identities of people across networks by aggregating their digital presences.

content.body:
Today, 60% of users online are bots. On dating platforms, 10% are catfishing or scam bots. How can you tell if someone is who they say they are?

Authentity is a platform for verifying human identities by cross-checking patterns across social media platforms. The AI behind Authentity uses facial recognition to verify that yes, the person in across these platform's photos is indeed you, and cross checks this against a smartphone or web-cam selfie. Authentity also looks for patterns in people, location, and tonal language to triangulate a given individual's true identity. Consistency across these aspects, as well as through a profile's history, are uniquely human indicators.

Authentity integrates into any platform which opts into our service. It manifests as a visual badge on usernames; once you have an account, your badge will appear with you. People can check the strength of their profile as well as others' profiles by visiting the Authentity profile database via a unique user ID. Strength is determined by how much media is on each platform, as well as how reputable the source. (e.g. Facebook versus Government ID.)

We imagine that Authentity will create a more authentic and trusted web between humans.
content.calloutBody: correlate many types of data to better gather meaningful, trusted information?
insights: Truth lies in the overlap of information. It comes from mixing and remixing information to identify ciritical issues.
How do we legitimize individual nodes?  Does certifying body subscriptions make them legitimate?

Weight different data is going to be a major challenge to solve for when understanding what truth is. There are obviously trustworthy and important data sources - but there are others that may be relevant. How do we figure out what's most important?
We created an AI inverted Turing test, where AIs were working to determine if they could identify other AIs. We think this has a lot of future potential, and we're interested to see where it goes.
content.why:
Our primary question was around how much information is out there that can be linked across platforms. It turns out there are links we can draw across disparate platforms and services, like identifying similar friends in multiple pictures, that help to verify true identity. We used name, school, number of platforms, analyzed differences in posts to have our AI identify a bot versus a real human.

We also built a simple facial recognition tool to do an instant selfie identifier. We imagine this could have applications beyond online dating -- it could be used in the sharing economy, or to quickly match individuals who show up at a bank to their financial accounts. It was hard to fool our tool and we think it could be used widely.

-KacLLTMjjmtUrC9BG94.desc: Authentity verifies identities of people across networks by aggregating their digital presences.
-KacLLTMjjmtUrC9BG94.title: Authentity

card.desc: A system to connect civilians to emergency services, supplies and evacuation pathways

content.body: Emergency Mode is emergency messaging infrastructure that leverages UC Berkeley's ShakeAlert™ early earthquake warning system to identify an impending earthquake, alert civilians in a disaster zone and then guide them to a shelter for food, water, medical assistance, and evacuation, and notify machines to take precautionary procedures. Emergency Mode does this by automatically customizing traffic lights along a route to get people to safe zones. This system leverages a cheap, low power repeater that uses 800MHz radio signal to send critical needs data to dispatch centers across a city or neighborhood.
content.calloutBody: create a coordinated system to ease civil duress and guide civilians during an earthquake?
insights: We can repurpose existing infrastructure simply by connecting it. Traffic lights can be used for new and novel things, like routing you to safety in an earthquake.
Seven seconds is slow for humans to react, but fast for machines.
content.next:
How do policy, social, and technological changes affect each other? 
How might we design a coordinated economy from scratch? On Mars? 
Which comes first: social change or technological implementation? 
Empowerment vs. replacement—how can we strike a balance with automation?
How do you visualize and/or map demand?
How can we best mitigate fear?
content.why: How might we repurpose existing infrastructure to better respond to emergencies and disasters? How might we coordinate assistance on city, state, and national levels to provide relief and assistance before, during, and after a disaster? We learned that the Fire Department prioritizes their response based on written info, communications over radio, and radio into main 911 dispatch center an that 911 dispatch has the burden of prioritizing and releasing it. Incident Reports are written afterwards that feed into citywide coordination efforts around emergencies and disaster management.

-KacLMpKMFYC0enHtPdl.desc: A system to connect civilians to emergency services, supplies and evacuation pathways
-KacLMpKMFYC0enHtPdl.title: Emergency Mode

card.desc: Remedi helps hospitals track and share medicine and medical supplies across a network.

content.body: Remedi is a system that connects networks of pharmacies to help them exchange unused medication. It consists of containers that track inventory of medicine and medical supplies for hospitals and blockchain technology that allows them to instantly transact across a network of hospitals in the area when they need a particular medication or item. Pill availability is recorded as transactions on the Blockchain, with the currency being the pill itself. Requests for pills (bids) are issued as Smart Contracts which are automatically resolved when the supply is available.
content.calloutBody: redistribute unused medicine?
insights: In order for this model to scale, an IoT system is needed in combination with blockchain to be able to track physical assets (in this case, medicine). This raises the oracle problem - how can we guarantee that the pills actually move as digitally represented?
This technology would benefit the entire pharmaceutical supply chain, however all parties (e.g., manufacturers, wholesalers, pharmacies) would need to participate.

Other types of medical facilities could benefit from this technology in order to optimize the use of medical resources. Another use case for this technology would be to allow community clinics to bid tokens for unused medical supplies from nursing homes and hospitals.
content.why: One main question we were trying to answer was "Where was there demand in the system?" and "Who would be interested in using this platform for their underutilized medicine?" We validated that demand existed in community clinics and that there was pop-up demand in hospital emergency rooms for particular drugs. We found that local retail pharmacies were not interested in using this technology, but that ER rooms in hospitals could benefit from it. Remedi would allow them to transact with other hospitals in the area where and when as needed.

-KacLOBRtCdHjkgpM3xs.desc: Remedi helps hospitals track and share medicine and medical supplies across a network.
-KacLOBRtCdHjkgpM3xs.subtitle: Instant supply-sharing for hospitals
-KacLOBRtCdHjkgpM3xs.title: Remedi

card.desc: A messenger bot that coordinates serindipitous meetups in your area.

content.body: Ringo is a Facebook messenger bot that coordinates serendipitous connections between strangers. Think of him as a friend who learns about you over time and introduces you to interesting new friends. He learns about you and introduces you to new friends outside your immediate network, connects to your calendar to set up time, and trains you to behave in a way that works for the system.
content.calloutBody: How might we ensure that AIs represent our private, individual intentions and interests?
insights: Users endow trust in an agent they’re familiar with and associate human personality with intentionality.
The more senses engaged, the better when it comes to interacting with AIs.

-Kad5vjKCW_wDAxQASVc.desc: A messenger bot that coordinates serindipitous meetups in your area.
-Kad5vjKCW_wDAxQASVc.subtitle: Making Social More Social
-Kad5vjKCW_wDAxQASVc.title: Ringo

card.desc: A tool for building credit using informal agreements and interactions.

content.body:
Trustwell is an AI-powered kit-of-parts for translating everyday verbal agreements into written agreements logged on the blockchain as smart contracts. This new system for reporting credit captures the consistency and depth of responsible interactions within a community. Our system is meant to interface with the current system of credit, which is entirely based on one’s ability to pay back borrowed money. This broken system amounts to a “Catch 22” of sorts, through which an individual who is already in a poor financial situation cannot possibly borrow money to build credit without getting into an even worse situation. As such, our proposed system attempts to find a new proxy for the trust that “credit” attempts to mirror by capturing the consistency and reliability that many people portray in their daily interactions, jobs, etc., which may be used in conjunction with the existing system as an alternative portrayal of credit.

Trustwell takes the form of an AI assistant in the home (currently using Google Home) that can guide or capture a conversation between two people and use the context clues of that conversation to create a smart contract on the blockchain. After this, the two parties must verify that the conditions of the contract were met, and can add additional context to why a particular condition was met or not. Doing so makes this system as a whole more empathetic to life circumstances and allows individuals significantly more control over their credit, as they can see all of the contributing factors to their composite credit score.
content.calloutBody: How might we create a decentralized system to track the telling factors of future reliability?
insights: When you formalize something informal, you change it qualitatively. When using technology, we need to preserve the quality of informal interactions.
The value of a credit score is entrusted by the system in place. If we use new inputs to create a trust score, we need to ensure that the new score has currency to fully give people second chances.
Trust is heavily based in consistency, and is commonly perceived through the quality and genuinity of personal interactions.
content.next:
Explore the idea of "micro agreements" – smaller agreements that lead to dimensionalized trust.

Connect the system to functional backend smart contracts.

Tie the smart contract to automated payment

Use the output of a successful/unsuccessful agreement to log and update a reputation score, as in the Prism concept.
content.why:
We started by exploring the purpose of credit score, and sought to redefine what the could be redefined to put people in the center. We then proceed to explore, through user interviews, the types of information are salient that should contribute to one’s credibility. And finally, we made the assumption that we could use a friendly Google Home AI/api.ai voice interaction as the interface for tracking agreements made in everyday interactions and formalizing them into written agreements that can be used to calculate trust.

QUESTIONS Coming out of the last sprint, we were pretty excited about the possibilities of AI to give further insight into one’s reputation, especially in the realm of demystifying subjective data. We’d created a model towards the beginning of this exploration of open reputation that seemed to hold true up to this point: that is, the flow of collecting data (subjective and objective), processing and modeling it, communicating it, and then using that information to make decisions. We found the question of credit to be especially interesting due to its opaque nature and the possibility for high impact (specifically, the opportunity to give people second chances after failing the existing, entirely financially based system of credit ratings). Paired with the chance to flesh out the base of our process -- collecting data to build a reputation -- we felt that this would be a great concept to pursue for the final three days of the CoLab.

PROCESS The concept of a “second chance” for those attempting to rebuild their credit was especially intriguing to us, and guided many of our thoughts at the beginning of the process. We honed in on a few key concepts: Gathering information about credibility from more than just finances Adding context to this information by telling their story rather than presenting them as a number. Identifying who is building their credit from nothing at all and those attempting to regain their credit in society. Credit as a proxy for TRUST. We used the next day and a half to talk to a lot of people about these ideas, as well as key questions on how credit has played a role in their lives or work. These interviews were invaluable in determining exactly what problems we should be tackling -- and why. We spent a lot of time trying to properly model these findings, so we did not have as much time to prototype. However, we did lay out everything we would need to do in order to create our ideal mock of our new system, which will be detailed in the appendix. We ended up prioritizing the most user facing components of our prototype: the Google Home conversational interface and the ideal look and feel of the data presented to the user (including the contract created).

ANSWERS Validated: The idea of capturing informal transactions as inputs to build a stronger reputation

-Kas_Uj4H4VhrWyS7nm-.subtitle: Credit From the Bottom Up
-Kas_Uj4H4VhrWyS7nm-.title: Trustwell

card.desc: Disaster Bot helps coordinate Emergency Response Efforts by informing relevant teams, and then re-scheduling staff for emergency responders.

content.body: The prototype "Disaster Bot" aka "D-Bot" performs the key function of coordinating the response to a disaster / event by notifying other bots such as a Hospital Scheduling bot, Transportation bot and / or a Police Emergency bot. The triggers for the D-Bot could either be a human invoked trigger or respond to a systemic alert from command centers ( FEMA, Weather Tracking Satellite, Call-ins, Emergency Departments ). Our specific prototype deals with the communication of the Disaster Bot to the Hospital Bot that manages the schedule of responders ( Docs, Nurses ) based on a tree-based resource allocation machine learning model that factors in availability, resource cost and distance to the hospital.
content.calloutBody: How might we enable bots to make decisions and allocate resources on behalf of an institution?
insights: In the insurance industry we believe that this prototype could proactively reach policyholders and provide guidance to evacuate and initiate a claim faster. This prototype could alert energy companies of an upcoming disaster within their service areas and allow them to assign more resources proactively. For banks that service the disaster areas, the bot can help their clients to look for alternate ways to deal with their financial situation and locate resources to protect their home and family.
content.why: Our prototype demonstrates the ability to progressively alleviate the need for a human intervention during a disaster event. It allocates resources efficiently and dynamically while also learning from each such interaction and getting better over time. We believe that this would lead to faster response times during an event, communicate to all relevant stakeholders and keep the community safe and secure

-KhTH9fruYmsorJVlaZ4.desc: Disaster Bot helps coordinate Emergency Response Efforts by informing relevant teams, and then re-scheduling staff for emergency responders.
-KhTH9fruYmsorJVlaZ4.subtitle: Bot coordination for emergency staff
-KhTH9fruYmsorJVlaZ4.title: Disaster Bot

card.desc: Aura is a real-time algorithm which combines sentiment analysis with physical activity data to assign a wellness score at both the individual and global level

content.body: Using IBM Watson sentiment analysis, combined with data from a wearable device (e.g., heart rate from a FitBit), we created a voice and text activated chat bot to assign users an overall wellness score and provide real-time recommendations for improvement. Wellness scores are aggregated over time and depicted on the individual and global level.
content.calloutBody: How might we use real-time signals to better understand wellness, risk, and treatment for college students?
insights: BCBS MA can potentially incorporate a wellness to current fitness reimbursements and other rate discounts/reward programs. Adoption of Aura can help improve health outcomes and reduce costs of care.
athenahealth can potentially incorporate Aura into its online patient portal.
Virgin Pulse is looking for easy and approachable ways for our members to adopt healthy behaviors.
content.why: Aura helps break the stigma of mental health. We heard from end-users that dealing with mental health issues in college is particularly challenging because it's taboo to admit that you are struggling.

-KhTIY-zfxmeIdKy4M0o.desc: Aura is a real-time algorithm which combines sentiment analysis with physical activity data to assign a wellness score at both the individual and global level
-KhTIY-zfxmeIdKy4M0o.subtitle: A wellness score upkept by an AI
