card.desc: A token where you can pay to send emails, as part of a broader market protocol.

content.body:
We started this week by prototyping how we could make the latent asset of data storage meaningful.  We began to build a UI for it, and gathered a lot of really interesting feedback.  We also realized that we were building a product rather than focusing on an experience.  So we focused on trying to understand how we could reframe our understanding of micropayments.  We developed this hypothesis: micropayments work when you receive a coin for doing what makes that coin valuable.  Said another way, micropayments don't work on their own, they work as park of a market protocol.  We need to think of micropayments as a proof of ability, rather than an expression of money. 

To that end, we started to build a new email token protocol, where you pay for email exchanges.  The use cases of this token would be that you could pay to surface your email in someone else's inbox, that you could guarantee it was read, you could create new marketing metrics, and you could tip content creators with this coin.
content.desc: A token where you can pay to send emails, as part of a broader market protocol.
features: Our prototype attempted to make sense of the abstract and often difficult to digest world of blockchain technologies. It clarifies why blockchains are so powerful, how new coins can be introduced on top of ethereum, and how clients can be integrated into these newly defined protocols.
insights: Seeing micropayments as part of a broader system of market protocols enables us to focus on how we design incentives inside of crypto-currencies and the unique markets those currencies create.  Instead of designing how we might pay to play, we can design the system around micropayments, and think of how we want to show a proof of work in those systems.
content.next: Our prototype attempted to make sense of the abstract and often difficult to digest world of blockchain technologies. It clarifies why blockchains are so powerful, how new coins can be introduced on top of ethereum, and how clients can be integrated into these newly defined protocols.
content.why: Our prototype exists as an example of how 'alt-tokens' and the protocols around them can be designed to efficiently support micropayments. By helping people shift their lens from the conventional understanding of micropayments to the new standard, our prototype will help other CoLab teams and perhaps the world better understand how to design efficient micro-payment systems.

-KpG5QhXpEKO5x3pPcRu.desc: A token where you can pay to send emails, as part of a broader market protocol.
-KpG5QhXpEKO5x3pPcRu.subtitle: A token for sending emails, as part of a broader market protocol.
team: Michael Gingras, Asaia Palacios, Caroline Crandall

card.desc: BioMine is a platform that helps you quickly and securely sell the biometric and environmental data that is collected through your wearables.

content.body:
BioMine is a platform that helps you quickly and securely (effortlessly) sell the biometric and environmental data that is collected through your wearables. BioMine assigns intelligent agents, or bots, to act as your personal data broker. Your bot searches our marketplace for data purchase requests and automatically checks if you are eligible, turns on and collects sensor information, packages the information for the buyer, and handles all of your payments. By using the Nomad open-source protocol for data collection, BioMine also ensures that only the relevant data is streamed, and that no one but your bot can access it, maintaining your security and privacy at every level.

BioMine | Make Your Data Work for You
content.desc: BioMine is a platform that helps you quickly and securely sell the biometric and environmental data that is collected through your wearables.
features: When most people hear bots they automatically think of natural language processing, an online robot you can literally talk to. However intelligent agents are much more than just an interface humans can speak with using language, they are autonomous entities which observe their environment through sensors and act upon it using some sort of actuators (i.e. it is an agent). Most bots direct these activities towards achieving goals and can learn or use knowledge to achieve these goals better. The most simple version of an intelligent agent is actually something like a thermostat. For this reason, we wanted to move away from a language interface and really focus on how intelligent agents can allow us to outsource part of our agency to a machine so that it can make a limited range of decisions based on available data. This automation saves users time and mental fatigue, allowing them to setup preferences once and then acts according to those wishes until the constraints are changed.

One area where we though this would be very useful is helping to collect, exchange, and receive compensation for human's unique sensorium, the collection of senses they have and what those senses can observe. By using sensors to replicate these senses, we believe that bots will become important in collecting, sorting, and selling these senses directly to other people (e.g. live streaming, location sharing) or to organizations who need the data.
insights: This prototype may start from Health industry, but can be expanded to so many industries such as retail or shopping as a whole. We are sure that most o the companies - and even individuals - will want to get & study data of others' lifestyle. Therefore, this prototype is going to have a bigger impact on various industries.
content.why:
Today, millions of people track their biometric and environmental data through sensors in jewelry, smartphones, or clothing.

But have you ever wondered where that data is going?

We did. And found that companies like FitBit, Nike, and Apple are selling users data to everyone from advertisers to city planners.

However most people have never seen any of that money, or had control over where it was going.

We think its time for a change. We believe that people should own their data, and actually get something in return when it is used.

BioMine makes these aspirations real as a proof of concept for how a platform like this could work using intelligent agents (bots) to automate the buying/selling of information and the blockchain protocol to maintain data security and user anonymity.

-KpG7gHCJXdHcNAlMUOu.subtitle: A platform that helps you quickly and securely sell the biometric and environmental data.

card.desc: Land Sense uses sensors to record trail use in parks and smart contracts to dynamically allocate resources from public and private contributors.

content.body: The Department of the Interior’s annual budget to protect and manage the United States’ public lands totals $13.4 billion. With potential cuts to this budget in the future, it is critical that there is a system of transparency and shared truth that allows resources for public parks to be properly distributed to the places where they are needed most. Land Sense is a service that uses sensors and smart contracts to collect data on the usage of parks around the country and dynamically deploys resources from public and private contributors based on park need. By creating a digital identity and performance history of public land, we can better ensure the sustainability of our ecosystem.
content.desc: Land Sense uses sensors to record trail use in parks and smart contracts to dynamically allocate resources from public and private contributors.
features: Our prototype makes use of sensors and smart contracts to dynamically issue resources across a system of parks.
insights: Our prototype offers insight into how sensors can work with blockchain technology to record the history of a physical space.
content.why: Land Sense creates a shared truth around the condition of our parks and the resources that are being dedicated to them to create a fair, transparent system.

-KpGCDFbQBnls_uX2ZY7.desc: Land Sense uses sensors to record trail use in parks and smart contracts to dynamically allocate resources from public and private contributors.

card.desc: A new standard in crypto currency portfolio investing that limits fees + increases transparency + decreases risks

content.body: We are proposing an alternative open sourced project and standard for portfolio investing where a token fund token (TFT) can represent multiple other crypto currencies and can be sold back and 1. cash out for Ether or 2. redeem for its underlying assets. This achieves radical transparency. Our solution also removes the need for third party (and hence fees), leading to higher returns for the individual investor. Also, since your digital assets are not stored on a third party exchange, you limit the risks of hacking and fraud
content.desc: A new standard in crypto currency portfolio investing that limits fees + increases transparency + decreases risks
features: We created a series of smart contracts on the Ethereum blockchain to create the token fund token and enable the possibility of redemption of the underlying assets
insights: This model poses interesting questions about and redefines our traditional concepts of:

1. Proof of ownership - Currently, when you own a house, you still need a deed and lawyers, etc to prove your ownership. Even with money in the bank (or on an exchange with Shapeshift), you are relying on a third party to validate your ownership. However, with this model where you can redeem your token fund token for its underlying assets and the inherent nature of blockchain, you have absolute proof of ownership
2. With absolute proof of ownership, radical transparency can be achieved
content.why: The craze around digital asset investing is heightening, but the protocols and models around it are still evolving. Currently, Shapeshift is the only model that enables an individual to create his/her own portfolio of digital assets. However, they charge exorbitant fees (1% monthly fee + more) and adopts a model of taking a counterposition to your investment. We believe there is room to propose an alternative model that increases transparency and limits fees. We are also experimenting with the technical feasibility of creating a token fund token that will represent multiple underlying assets.

-KpHDRsAkCJ2KGms4aKJ.desc: A new standard in crypto currency portfolio investing that limits fees + increases transparency + decreases risks
-KpHDRsAkCJ2KGms4aKJ.subtitle: A new standard in crypto currency portfolio investing that limits fees, increases transparency, and decreases risks

card.desc: A distributed network platform for self-organized communities of devices to leverage cooperative buying power and provide a responsive load to utilities.

content.body:
We've created a smart contract between a utility and a decentralized community of power users (who all use the same utility). 

The smart contract says that if the community uses a set amount of energy during peak times, the utility will give the network a discount.  Bulk buying of energy happens today at a pretty significant price difference (10c to 6c).  This is good for the utility because they want predictability and they don't want to dig into sources of power that are inefficient.  

The community treats this block of energy as a shared resource and uses an algorithm to manage the price of energy amongst community members.  This algorithm dynamically adjusts the price based on who is using what when.  This algorithm increases price if there isn't a lot of power left to use, increases the price if there is a lot of demand, and decreases as time goes on in peak hours (the option value of waiting). 

In order for this to work, everyone in the community must be able to see who using what when, and verify it.  They don't want to have to trust each other. 
The community uses a decentralized network to do this. 

Each person in the community can also see the price change over time, dynamically, so they can know the best time to operate their devices.  

When each member of the community turns on their washer, dryer, etc. this is a microtransaction that draws energy from the pool, and pays towards the community's shared bill. 

The community does not trade credits - this is not about making money from your neighbors, this is about working together to pay the lowest power bill possible.
content.desc: A distributed network platform for self-organized communities of devices to leverage cooperative buying power and provide a responsive load to utilities.
features: The lightning network is essential for this prototype to exist because our micro market needs a real-time dynamic price to work.  The community of homeowners who are agreeing to use this block of power together need to verify that their neighbors really are paying for what they say they are and using what they say they are using, a system that writes these transactions to a blockchain is super useful in this case.  As well, the smart contract between the utility and the community is great for managing this day-to-day transaction without fees and legal hassles.
insights: We developed this prototype with a corporate fellow from Southern Company which really helped us ground this idea in reality.  He helped us see that reductions in price can actually help utilities in some ways, if it happens during a peak time of power.
content.why: It allows communities to organize amongst themselves to pay lower prices for power, and it allows utilities to avoid using really expensive and inefficient sources of power like natural gas.

-KpHG6x3fwK4HBOVKuQ8.desc: A distributed network platform for self-organized communities of devices to leverage cooperative buying power and provide a responsive load to utilities.
-KpHG6x3fwK4HBOVKuQ8.subtitle: A distributed network for devices to leverage cooperative buying power and provide a responsive load to utilities.
team: Michael Gingras, Caroline Crandall, Brett Estep
-KpHG6x3fwK4HBOVKuQ8.title: Apogee

card.desc: HOME.ID is a digital record of a home stored on the blockchain.

content.body: We created the back end, front end and data visualization for a digital home identity using the example of 2 Bryant Street (the IDEO CoLab office). HOME.ID pulls the property information from the City of San Francisco's API and enables a verified homeowner to add additional information. We created this in order to focus on HOW a digital home identity actually gets created using blockchain technology.
content.desc: HOME.ID is a digital record of a home stored on the blockchain.
features: Our prototype uses blockchain to create a transparent, immutable record. Although our prototype doesn't focus on a decentralized network today, it still offers shared truth and greater transparency into real estate properties today.
insights: The actual creation of a digital asset to represent a physical asset may of interest to members' businesses or industries. Our prototype is an example of this concept.
content.why: Digital property titles increase transaction speed and reduce fraud, resulting in significant time and cost savings for real estate. A digital event history aobut a property ensures that homes have any and all permit, inspection and regulatory requirements completed, improving overall governance. Digital purchase history related to a home provides greater transparency on the components of a house revealing true asset value and helping future occupants navigate purchasing decisions. Lastly, smart contracts enables transparent agreements and payment between parties who are making a transaction related to home.

card.desc: A system where auto manufacturers can issue precise part-level recalls, and cars function as bots/agents to coordinate a response between driver, dealer and manufacturer.

content.body: In the “BlockBag” prototype, we developed a system for a car to check the authenticity of installed parts (such as an airbag). When the airbag is scanned, it is associated with the car and this data is posted onto the blockchain for parties to reference in the future. With this in mind, we are assuming that auto manufacturers can query a list of cars and filter by specific parts (or sets of parts). In the event of a recall, the auto manufacturer flags impacted vehicles, triggering an alert to the car. When the notification is received the car determines an appropriate course of action. Leveraging the matching conditions used in the “BikeChain” prototype, the car compiles a list of convenient dealership service locations for the maintenance to be performed. The driver / owner then “chats” with the car to work out an appropriate service solution (location and scheduling). Once the driver / owner makes a selection, the car automatically books an appointment with the dealership service department by reserving time on the online calendaring system. This action could also trigger an action with the manufacturer, who would then send the part to the designated service location. Once the new part is loaded into the car, it is associated with the car, updating the blockchain records and triggering payment to the franchised dealership service provider.
content.desc: A system where auto manufacturers can issue precise part-level recalls, and cars function as bots/agents to coordinate a response between driver, dealer and manufacturer.
features: By establishing shared provenance of parts in vehicles, we can lay a foundation for future automation. In this case, we have parts tagged with QR codes that reference the blockchain ledger to ensure authenticity and recall status. When a recall is issued, we can tap into automation and have the car serve as an intermediary between the manufacturer and the driver (acting as bot).
insights: This prototype showcases 1 particular use case on what can be done when you build an immutable system of nested identities of vehicles and their parts. While we are specifically talking about auto recalls, we imagine that such a scheme can be used to build many other powerful consumer services in retail, possibly even healthcare, where object provenance is key.
content.why: In a world where machines are becoming more and more intelligent, they are in a position to manage their own identities and statuses, and interact with their owners in a meaningful way. Our prototype takes a stab at this idea, with the use case of a car.

-KpHObpQfQsuvNKGImFg.desc: A system where auto manufacturers can issue precise part-level recalls, and cars function as bots/agents to coordinate a response between driver, dealer and manufacturer.
-KpHObpQfQsuvNKGImFg.subtitle: A system where auto manufacturers can issue precise part-level recalls, and cars function as agents to coordinate a response.
team: Gloria Chua, Rob Sieg, Varma  Mantena, Alan Gordon

card.desc: An interview assistant that draws personalized questions and candidate summaries throughout the application process.

content.body: Interviewers often come unprepared to interviews, leaving candidates at a severe disadvantage and creating a surface-level interview experience. Tobi shares summarized insights about a candidate with the interviewer directly before the meeting and also listens in on the conversation to learn good questions for a company. It also is able to ask more in-depth questions based on its comprehensive knowledge of the candidate.
content.desc: An interview assistant that draws personalized questions and candidate summaries throughout the application process.
features: Using NLP as a way to read through huge bodies of text and pull out personal attributes that can then be presented prior to and asked about during an interview.
insights: This is a great system for companies with many applicants and possibly inexperienced interviewers. Full-time employees that act as interviewers can reduce time researching candidates while increasing personalization of the conversation.
content.why: People are naturally bad at holding a lot of information in their mind and making holistic decisions. Therefore, we can utilize machines to provide recommendations or at least insights based on past interactions with people.

-KpHR4r0n76_fcaedPrM.subtitle: An interview assistant that creates personalized questions and candidate summaries throughout the application process.

card.desc: A dynamic chatbot that produces a personality score (OCEAN) based on qualitative answers to application questions

content.body:
A better first point of contact with an applicant, a chatbot, is able to interview a candidate for an at-home IT support position including a simulation of a possible support call. We then took this qualitative text and ran a sentiment analysis tool (Magic Sauce) to produce an OCEAN personality score. These traits were then displayed on a front-end dashboard for the recruiter. 

As an experiment, we collected unique key words from CoLab Makeathon application responses sorted into two groups based on acceptance. We then showed these out of context, seemingly random words to a sample group who were able to create and corroborate group personifications. The interesting takeaway is that a machine can possibly determine the culture of any group of people based on qualitative answers to questions.
content.desc: A dynamic chatbot that produces a personality score (OCEAN) based on qualitative answers to application questions
features: It uses NLP to highlight words in a piece of text and therefore communicates simpler insights to a human. NLP can also create a more natural conversation between a bot and a human.
insights: Tobi is able to create a more in-depth and rich experience for the candidate and the interviewer.
content.why: Tobi minimizes cognitive load and application reading from the initial steps of the application process. It pulls out useful data that can be put into a machine learning algorithm from complex qualitative text.

-KpHSBgHQjx6y35_KGwG.desc: A dynamic chatbot that produces a personality score (OCEAN) based on qualitative answers to application questions

card.desc: TENDER is an online platform for building and training personal shopping bots to help users reduce the time, mental load, and annoyance of searching through e-commerce sites for the perfect product.

content.body: TENDER helps users seamlessly communicate their information through linked social media profiles, quickly and easily setup their shopping assistant, and train their shopping assistant over time with minimal daily prompts about products. TENDER works by scraping data from your social media profiles about your age, personality, and likes/dislikes to build an initial model of your stated preferences compared to our database of others users. TENDER then learns your specific preferences by showing a series of  images of different products and asking you to like or dislike them, while also tracking your engagement with each product through facial recognition. TENDER continues to learn your preferences daily, sending out a notification asking you to swipe right to like, or swipe left to dislike (much like Tinder) a handful of products. All of this information is run through the Tender neural network, constantly retraining and perfecting your TENDER’s individual purchasing ability.
content.desc: TENDER is an online platform for building and training personal shopping bots to help users reduce the time, mental load, and annoyance of searching through e-commerce sites for the perfect product.
content.why:
Today...
e-commerce websites attempt to match us with products we would like through monitoring our purchase history, products we look at and sending customer quizzes and surveys to capture our stated preferences. Others employ a subscription-based model that helps both artificial and human agents to learn our preferences over time as we keep some items and return others.
 
But imagine...
a world in which your personal shopping AI, TENDER, can comb your social media profiles, purchase history, and even reaction to specific products across websites to help you find the perfect match, every time. Imagine if TENDER could know your preferences, price points, and events so well that it could ship you what you needed, when you needed it, and ensure that you loved it.

team: Dana Martens, Noa Kaplan, Josh Jeong

card.desc: A blockchain platform that creates a digital identity for a vehicle and gives it a wallet, enabling it to generate credits.

content.body:
Mobilized is a vehicle wallet platform that lets vehicles generate renewable credits based on how sustainably they are driven and trade those assets with other drivers, vehicles or third parties on the road.

Current transit systems are hugely inefficient, particularly with regards to productivity and greenhouse gas emissions. The average person in Los Angeles, for example, spends 100 hours a year stuck in traffic and wastes $2,400 annually on fuel and lost productivity. A major factor in this inefficiency is the inability coordinate resources on the road—like enabling those in a rush to “jump” to the front of the line.

Markets could solve these problems; they are tools for coordinating resources in an optimized way. But in order to have a market, we need assets that can be tracked and traded, and in order to have assets, we need wallets to store them.
content.calloutBody: Create a transactive vehicle that has its own wallet and digital identity?
content.desc: A blockchain platform that creates a digital identity for a vehicle and gives it a wallet, enabling it to generate credits.
insights: Every transactive vehicle needs an instance of blockchain onboard to enable decentralized markets in the future.
We can build a transactive vehicle right now.
The vehicle’s identity is independent from the identity of any of its human users.
A verified digital identity for a vehicle can be leveraged by a broad ecosystem of users.
Transactive machines quantify and capture the cost of externalities in real-time choices.
In the short term, we can start with small centralized programs (like corporate incentive systems) to test this opportunity.
In the future, autonomous transactive vehicles can unlock pop-up markets for latent assets.
content.why:
We believe that giving vehicles secure digital wallets and assets to transact are a building block to creating a more efficient transit system.

Once vehicles can transact and generate currency, we need to develop incentives that reward sustainable transit decisions to catalyze behavior change. Vehicles equipped with the Mobilized platform can generate credits (similarly to renewable energy credits in the energy industry) when they are used sustainably. Credits are generated by doing things like carpooling through a transit desert, driving at an off-peak time, or taking an alternate route at rush hour. More sustainable drivers and vehicles earn more credits. Those credits can then be transacted for resources like access to parking when demand is high, dynamic tolling, or access to priority fast lanes.


The final result is a real-time market of road resources, allowing for more efficient and sustainable means of mobility. We built a series of prototypes to highlight the system-level Mobilized opportunity, including:

  • A dynamic user experience for driving a transactive vehicle. We created a vehicle dashboard containing interactive consoles, pedals, and a view from the windshield. As someone drives the transactive vehicle they experience how credits are generated and traded.

  • A market visualization that shows the different types of vehicle transactions and how these transactions propagate across the blockchain.

  • An interactive website that explains the specific technical architecture of a transactive vehicle.

  • A venture prototype for tech companies, a CSR program that rewards employees who commute sustainably, and one of the first use cases we see for the Mobilized platform. This prototype included brand design, a business case, and UI for an employee application.

-KrXRvBpssdetizuhP2d.desc: A blockchain platform that creates a digital identity for a vehicle and gives it a wallet, enabling it to generate credits.
-KrXRvBpssdetizuhP2d.title: Mobilized

card.desc: A shop owned by you, curated for you

content.body:
We imagine a future in which individuals own and maintain their own digital presence, including the data they generate. Rather than large companies scraping, selling, and restricting access to our online actions, individuals will be in control of their data and can use it to create richer digital agents that understand our tastes and make more informed recommendations.

ME.AI is an e-commerce experience that curates products and other digital content in a contained and private environment. You begin with a blank store and connect social media profiles such as Instagram and Linkedin to build your AI. Over time, your AI will evolve visually and “mentally” by continuing to collect your interests and motivations from activity across your browser. It also learns as you interact with items in your “store,” allowing you to give quick feedback on whether you hate or love products.


Key Features

Features in prototype: Onboarding to Capture Shopping Intent and Relevant Personas: Basic questions that collect the user’s shopping goal and current frame of mind (e.g. What color best represents your mood right now?) to create a semi-personalized first look. We also envision the next prototype to include the step of linking your social media profiles so ME.AI can improve recommendation accuracy based on personas generated from your data.

Taste Forking Filter: After onboarding, the user is prompted to select (or “fork”) taste profiles — personas, interests, influencers, and top friends —that they identify with. The site then pulls curated products based on the user’s forked tastes to populate the curated shop. This feature explores the “cold start” issue when a user has no prior training or specific taste preferences, instead “forking” preexisting training and tastes to kick off their product exploration.

Curated Shop: The user’s shop consists of curated products based on forked tastes as well as customized imagery to create a visual experience like browsing an aesthetic magazine. The shop’s hero image and taglines are sourced from onboarding questions, establishing that the store is not only curated for the user, but owed by the user. Additional banner images are sourced from forked taste profiles. The user also has the option to customize additional imagery through the unsplash API.

Product Preference Training: As the user provides feedback to train ME.AI, it will continue to improve the accuracy of its product recommendations through machine learning. Scrolling below the curated shop, the user can explore a much larger grid of products. As the user hovers over each product, 5 emojis, ranging from happy to sad, pop up so the user can provide feedback over each product. Each emoji applies a different opacity to the product (visible as normal for love, almost transparent for hate), rendering a visual map for the user’s tastes. The emotive training provides a much more robust data set for product preference, encoding ranges of emotive responses from very positive, to neutral, to very negative.

Visualizing ME.AI Evolution: Since AI evolution happens in the backend over time, typically with few immediate and noticeable difference on the frontend, users often get discouraged and stop training the AI. In ME.AI, as the user applies emotive training, a colored shape in the top right of the header begins to “evolve” by changing color and growing in size to visualize training progress, thereby getting immediate feedback that the training is adding value.

Purchase Direct from Retailer (not built into the prototype): When the user clicks on ‘Buy,’ the platform redirects him to a retailer site to complete the purchase. In this way, retailers can build a consistent brand experience and direct relationship with the user, instead of being reliant upon Amazon. Your ME.AI also already has your credit card information so you would not have to re-enter it on the retailer site.


Fun Terms

Persona Tags The aspects of any human's personality, behaviors, or tastes that can be determined through online activity. Think richer demographics created based on true passions or interests.

Active Data Pieces of information reflecting a person’s taste, collected via active input. An interface may be deliberate and concrete in telling the person that their actions are actively feeding an AI.

Passive Behavioral Data Data that does not obviously lead to some interface change in the mind of the user. This includes social media likes, posts, and images posted as a part of a normal day.

AI Training The human interface side of providing data to a machine learning model. This can be gamified, collected passively, or used as a tool to learn collaboratively with the AI.

AI Evolution The notion that as you train your AI, a user can visually observe the progress of the machine learning model, abstracted from the actual technical detail.
content.calloutBody: An AI that personalizes and curates an online store just for you
content.desc: A shop owned by you, curated for you
insights: Distinct clusters of personas emerge around different products (e.g. a pair of headphones loved by industrial designers and classical music enthusiasts)

Collaborative filtering, a common machine learning method of providing recommendations by comparing users and items (products, songs...) in a matrix, can possibly be improved by pre sorting people based on the persona tags they identify with
People feel scared, insecure, and confused by big data collectors,  which makes them hesitant to engage with recommended content

A user will trust an AI system in which they influence the look and feel of the store as well as have control over the data the AI collects. The opposite of this is an AI system that makes decisions without informing the user of the reasons and feels more prescriptive than collaborative

AI training should incorporate both explicit moments (such as an active ‘Captcha’ training moment), to give users a sense of ownership, and implicit moments (such a Chrome plugin to passively capture browsing behavior), to relieve the burden of massive user input.
content.why:
We believe that there is a major market opportunity for a platform that both personalizes and curates based on individual tastes. We see a gap in current retailer recommendations and an increasing desire among users to regain control over their personal data.

Right now, big companies own your data, limiting transparency and control over anyone’s online presence. This data is then sold to advertisers and retailers that use it to integrate “targeted” ads into our online experience. There is little possibility of providing feedback to eliminate poor recommendations or expand upon excellent recommendations.

In online retail, Amazon-like platforms make recommendations primarily based on your past transaction and click history. These factors limit recommendations, especially in new categories in which you have never purchased. ME.AI leverages cross-domain passive social media data to create richer personas that improve the accuracy of product recommendations. These include more than transaction history and extend to linkedin job roles, instagram followers, and twitter interests.

-KrXx0SDLIcjNAHqakId.desc: A shop owned by you, curated for you
-KrXx0SDLIcjNAHqakId.title: ME.AI

card.desc: A physical / digital tagging system that enables transparency and traceability through aggregated identity and shared truth.

content.body:
Recognizing the significant risk to automakers and consumers incurred by counterfeit airbags, BlokMotiv uses traceability of parts to dissolve illicit markets, improve consumer safety, and reduce manufacturer loss. In doing so, it also provides a provide framework for future autonomous applications.

Airbags are generally composed of three main components: the inflator, cushion, and cover. Airbag counterfeiting typically occurs when these components are stolen (either from the factory or directly from vehicles) and reassembled into what is called a “Frankenstein” airbag. For instance, a “Frankenstein” airbag might include a Ford cover, a Honda cushion, and a Toyota inflator. Since all of these components are optimized for a specific vehicle, this can make for a deadly combination. Mechanics and other consumers purchase these fraudulent units through standard ecommerce channels, such as Ebay, often unknowingly. When installed into the vehicle, the driver has no idea that this safety-critical part will not function properly, and could injure or kill them during a crash.

Airbag manufacturers put their products through stringent quality assurance practices and carefully track the inflator, cushion, and cover as they are assembled and put into vehicles. Today, manufacturers use barcode stickers, engraved serial numbers, and other traditional inventory practices to track parts. These methods are manual, static, and difficult to manage. By replacing these options with RFID tags, we can create new opportunities to more efficiently and precisely track airbag components.

RFID is a standard technology to digitally track physical objects. After analyzing the market of existing solutions, we identified an opportunity to create “aggregated identities” for machines—which is the packaging of a unique combination of three or more tags. Blokmotiv airbags are RFID tagged by inflator, cushion and cover, and those parts are combined to create a singular “part identity.” This approach offers significant security advantages compared to existing approaches (e.g. placing a label on the packaging). Since only this specific combination of individual components constitutes an authentic airbag, our approach prevents the creation of “Frankenstein” airbags.

Blokmotiv Merkle Trees are used to establish an aggregated identity based on the individual components that form a part. Merkle Trees are great data structures for this system, because they enable the order of part assembly to be tracked. Furthermore, we can store the components’ respective Merkle proofs in the RFID tags themselves. With this information, we can distinguish exactly which specific component was invalid in the event of a fraudulent scan.

When the RFID tags on the inflator, cushion, and cover are scanned together at the point of manufacture, this aggregated identity gets posted to the BlokMotiv blockchain ledger. When the airbag is later installed into a vehicle, an in-car RFID sensor reads the combination and checks the validity against the ledger. If a record match is found, the airbag identity is digitally coupled with the vehicle identity on the blockchain. If it is not found, the unsuccessful install attempt is also logged onto the blockchain. If the vehicle is ever in an accident that causes the airbag to deploy, that deployment event is written to the airbag’s blockchain record, preventing this retired asset from being reused.

The BlokMotiv blockchain is a semi-private blockchain - while anyone (including the public) can read from the blockchain with the necessary APIs, only particular stakeholders can write to it. Write access is controlled by the OEM (e.g. Ford), who can authorize the airbag manufacturers, as well as its manufactured cars, to register manufacture and install events onto the blockchain. Public read access allows for consumer transparency, and also for other secondary stakeholders like insurance companies, to take action on the information available on the ledger.

For blockchain prototyping, we used Tierion’s API. The current technical constraints around blockchain systems, such as block size and verification times, present possible limitations for scaling the platform. More research into the most appropriate distributed ledger technology (DLT) would be required to move forward.

Installing a fraudulent airbag flags that unit as inauthentic, triggering alerts to the OEM, the airbag manufacturer, the driver, and the insurer. This process maintains shared truth that allow different parties to take the appropriate corrective action.

In addition to validating the authenticity of airbags at the point of install, different stakeholders can access the BlokMotiv ledger of shared truth for a variety of applications. Individual owners can check the history of parts of their current or future vehicle. Insurers can query their client’s vehicles and set premium rates based on the vehicle owner’s use of authentic parts. Brand protection teams across the auto industry can share information on fraudulent installs to identify counterfeit sources. If a recall needs to be issued, manufacturers can precisely trace recalled parts to their respective owners with much greater accuracy. Finally, looking towards a future of autonomous transportation, a system like Blokmotiv could be used to monitor parts installed in these vehicles and guarantee that they are genuine.
content.desc: A blockchain parts-identity system that links physical components with digital records to secure the automotive supply chain.
insights: The problem with counterfeit parts goes beyond brand—we validated desirability to enable sub-component traceability of parts from manufacturing to install.
RFID tags are the right hardware. They’re both a technically suitable and cost-effective mechanism to give components their identities.

The car should be treated as a stakeholder in the communication flow, with read/write access to the blockchain because this would allow for verification of part authenticity without the need for human intervention.

Aggregated identity (through Merkle Trees) and shared truth (through a blockchain ledger) could be the foundation for many powerful applications beyond securing the authenticity of auto parts. We think this could also be immediately relevant to the energy and aerospace sectors. Additionally, the BlokMotiv model could facilitate future autonomous machines, which require high uptime and traceable parts.
content.why:
How might we create a system to identify counterfeits of safety-critical parts (e.g. airbags) when they’re placed into motor vehicles?

Counterfeit auto parts are the fifth most commonly counterfeited good. Over $45 billion worth of counterfeit auto parts are sold yearly. In particular, airbags are highly counterfeited, constituting a major liability for automakers in terms of IP security, brand reputation, and most importantly, customer safety. Today, there are a number of stakeholders in the airbag supply chain and lifecycle with different motivations. There is a lack of transparency and traceability of parts across the supply chain and beyond.

Current anti-counterfeiting solutions are inadequate as they rely on infrequent, manual verification, which generally requires trust that all stakeholders to follow the rules. There are no shared digital records between airbag manufacturers, automakers, and car owners. As a result, there is little to no insight into the authenticity of parts when airbags are replaced and used cars are purchased.

-KrY3AI690mA_7NEo86N.desc: A blockchain parts-identity system that links physical components with digital records to secure the automotive supply chain.
-KrY3AI690mA_7NEo86N.title: BlokMotiv

card.desc: A decentralized, credit-decisioning platform that enables credit-thin users to prove their financial responsibility through verified, alternative credit data.

content.body:
Overview:
Credo is a decentralized credit-decisioning platform which enables the 70mm credit-thin consumers in the US to prove their financial responsibility through alternative credit data, verified by the data provider in real time. The prototype specifically demonstrates that a credit-thin user can request and own their verified utility payment data from Exelon so that Ford can access and trust it when making a credit decision. Lenders like Ford may typically rely on credit bureaus for scoring, which don’t include information like utility, rent, and telecom payment history. For consumers who don’t have loans or debt, this is often the only financial data they generate.

Decentralized Identities:
The prototype is based on the Blockstack protocol, through which each of the parties creates an identity. Users can link a personal database (Google Drive, Dropbox, Amazon Cloud, phone/hardware storage, etc.) where their payment history data will be stored. Blockstack IDs were created for the user, Exelon, and Ford.

Profile Setup:
Users log into Credo, which registers a Blockstack ID, and they then link their bank account(s). Credo scrapes their bank statements (using the Plaid API) in order to identify recurring payments that could prove financial responsibility. Based on these recurring payments, Credo makes API endpoints in the user’s personal database. Through these endpoints, data providers can sign, hash, and post the user’s payment history and lenders can view this data. One of these API endpoints corresponds to Exelon utilities data.

Pulling Verified Data:
When a thin-file user needs to prove their creditworthiness to a lender, in this case Ford, through alternative payment data, they can use Credo to prove that their data was verified from the issuing source and was not altered. They can directly request the corresponding data provider, in this case Exelon, to post digitally signed payment data to their personal databases via their API endpoints. The prototype mocks up the process of the user signing a smart contract that ensures the data provider will be paid whenever someone accesses the verified data they have posted to the user’s database. Then the data provider (Exelon), represented by an EC2 server, signs, hashes, and posts data to the user endpoint.

Verified Data Access:
The user then goes through a mocked up experience of granting the lender, Ford, access to their data. When making a credit decision, Ford can actually see the signed data in the user’s personal database and can therefore trust that the data has not been altered. If the data is tampered with, the data hash will no longer match the hash produced by the data provider.
content.calloutBody: How might we empower credit-thin users to prove their financial responsibility to lenders through alternative credit data?
content.desc: A decentralized credit platform for credit-thin users that verifies alternative credit data from utilities to prove financial responsibility.
insights: It’s hard to plan for a future of intangible and uncertain milestones, so many people do not feel like they need to build their credit until it’s too late.
The credit system is designed for long-term financial planning, but lower-income people usually plan on the short-term in order to stay afloat, thus being particularly ostracized from the system.
The credit system is perceived as increasingly cryptic and scary due to its lack of transparency and high-consequences, thus causing “credit anxiety.”
Millennials have a fundamentally different approach to the financial ecosystem, as evidenced by the fact 67% of them do not have credit cards.

Especially in cities, rising real-estate prices and popular ride-sharing apps have made it less likely that people will buy properties or vehicles, thus taking down two main pillars of the credit-building.
The credit system was built for a different world and has not adapted to the way people live today.
Lenders in the industry have realized that the credit system is becoming increasingly less representative of people, limiting its ability to quantify risk and to increase customer bases.

Credit bureaus rely on companies to voluntarily push data to them without monetary compensation, so data providers that could contribute alternative credit data have no business incentive to do so. This makes the data incomplete.
Credit-decisioning data needs to have not just trusted sources, but trusted predictability of financial behavior.
content.why:
Problem:
Despite the credit system being over 100 years old, it has changed very little over time. As attitudes towards ownership and credit change, the current inputs that build credit―bank loans, auto loans, and credit cards―are becoming increasingly less representative of the American population. Thus, the credit system is becoming less effective at quantifying risk. According to a study done by Upstart and Transunion, more than 4 in 5 Americans have never defaulted on a loan, yet less than half of them have access to prime credit. Tough regulations, misaligned incentives, and difficulties verifying that data has not been altered is preventing the credit system from adapting to the way people live today.

Opportunity:
There is plenty of alternative credit data siloed within different organizations such as utilities, telecom, etc. However, directly sharing data between companies in order to make credit decisions is heavily regulated. These same organizations choose to not participate in the credit system because they have no business incentive to do so. In order to get around that, credit-thin people usually print out bills that they believe will prove their creditworthiness and present them to lenders. However, there is nothing ensuring that the data has not been altered in the process, so lending agents cannot trust it.

Solution:
Credo enables thin-file people to prove their financial responsibility by bridging the gap between companies that hold payment data and lenders that want to see that data. At the user’s request, data providers can post cryptographically signed, alternative credit data to the user’s personal database. This is key, since instead of asking companies to push data into Credo, we’re enabling the user to pull and own it. Then, with the user’s permission, lenders can pay data providers a small fee in order to access the verified data in the user’s database. By making the user the custodian of their data and the bridge between the data provider and lender, Credo helps circumvent regulations around sharing data directly between companies. In the end, data providers get to monetize previously stagnant data, lenders get access to data they can trust in order to expand their customer base, and thin-file people are empowered to prove their creditworthiness and get better rates.

-KraTvnLNaPFD5JBY_0g.desc: A decentralized credit platform for credit-thin users that verifies alternative credit data from utilities to prove financial responsibility.
-KraTvnLNaPFD5JBY_0g.tags: identity, credit, blockchain, decentralized credit, alternative credit
-KraTvnLNaPFD5JBY_0g.title: Credo

card.desc: Marelai is an augmented reality (AR) application that uses hands-free data collection and augmented reality to facilitate more efficient, patient-centered care during transitions within a hospital. Audio is inputted through the hololens and processed to strip out keywords that then get pushed to a firebase database, along with vitals data that are streamed from a particle sensor. The Microsoft hololens pulls from the firebase database in realtime in a constant stream. In this way, multiple hololenses can share the same data instantaneously. Through working on this project, we hoped to nail down what information is relevant for different doctors to see, when they want to see this information and how augmented reality can change retention of information.

content.body:
Transitions of care are an integral component of our healthcare system but because a significant amount information is communicated verbally, this leads to omission (information loss) and commission (too much information communicated) during handoff points from one person to the next in the healthcare delivery pipeline.

We chose Emergency Medicine (EM) as the use case for which to design our prototype because an Emergency Room (ER) is a stressful environment where many transitions occur.  From speaking to Emergency Medical Technicians (EMTs), nurses, and doctors, we identified the specific use case of an EMT verbally briefing an ER doctor or ER nurse about an incoming patient's condition.

In a stressful situation, it is not ideal to rely on the human brain, because humans are very good at recognizing information, but are not great at recalling information. So, we built a system that translates an EMT's voice input into AR in real time such that it does not distract a doctor or add additional time to their workflow.
content.desc: Marelai is an augmented reality (AR) application that uses hands-free data collection and augmented reality to facilitate more efficient, patient-centered care during transitions within a hospital. Audio is inputted through the hololens and processed to strip out keywords that then get pushed to a firebase database, along with vitals data that are streamed from a particle sensor. The Microsoft hololens pulls from the firebase database in realtime in a constant stream. In this way, multiple hololenses can share the same data instantaneously. Through working on this project, we hoped to nail down what information is relevant for different doctors to see, when they want to see this information and how augmented reality can change retention of information.
insights: Practitioners have unique workflows for collecting information and it makes it difficult to communicate it efficiently.
Successful handoffs are integral to safe and effective healthcare delivery
We as humans are good with emotions but fail at juggling complex information
Data around handoffs is limited by HIPPAA and regulations which hinders our ability to categorize relevant information.
Voice to text isn’t quite there technologically
Emergency medicine not the optimal use case to test this idea
content.why: Our question was “How might augmented reality be used in a hospital environment to improve the experience, collaboration, and performance of doctors or nurses?” We spoke to 15 people from doctors to electronic health record software developers, to design researchers at IDEO with experience designing projects for the healthcare space. From these conversations, we learned that transitions of care within a hospital often lead to communication gaps and distract a physician’s attention away from the patient.

card.desc: Marelai is an augmented reality (AR) application that uses three-dimensional (3D) space to contextualize and capture key moments of information about a person over time to provide “flash empathy.” Marelai’s first use-case focuses on presenting doctors with a snapshot of patient information before the patient’s visit. The Marelai front-end allows doctors to quickly build “flash-empathy” for a patient by seeing a snapshot of their human traits and social data, things like occupation, where they live, and what they like to do. The built-in time-stack allows doctors to see patient health data in correlation with life-events and outside factors that may be attributing to an illness or condition. In this way, data is contextualized for new insights.  Pattern detection algorithms in Marelai’s software intelligently analyze weights of different attributes of a person’s health data alongside outside factors to surface highlights to allow quick looks at what might be causing a problem.  This experience is enhanced by an AR haptic glove that allows the user to physically interact with the data quickly.

insights: Flash empathy/transfer of feelings between people - thesis that AR/VR is good for that.
Documenting into an EMR is on a doctor's dime and time
Even the best doctors have a hard time remembering everything about a patient
Contextual info (emotional and physical data) helps quality of care
Readability in AR is difficult because text colors change when displayed on real-world elements.
AR has the capabilities to engage a user's senses beyond a 2D world and can incorporate data multisensory.
Gestures and voice commands are difficult for a user to pick up right away.
content.why:
Our question was “How might augmented reality be used in a hospital environment to improve the experience, collaboration, and performance of doctors or nurses?” Going to the doctor is a shared experience, yet how much does a doctor really get to know you? What if you move and need a new physician?  A 3D environment enables doctors to contextualize patient information quickly.

Our future vision for Marelai is to create shared empathy for a single patient in interactions with multiple doctors, and through saved layouts and doctor-highlighted insights, collaboration across doctors, hospitals, and insurance providers to provide a more connected and personal health experience.

card.desc: The decentralized energy network is a platform that incentivizes electric fleet vehicles to offer available battery capacity as a storage bank for surplus energy (solar and fuel based) that can later be discharged to the grid offsetting peak demand. While creating an incentive for utilities, fleet managers, and possibly auto manufacturers, it creates a marketplace for energy storage and procurement.

content.body:
Imagine a future where a portion of electric vehicle batteries can be used to store and discharge power to offset energy demand. What would that world look like, what would have to be true for this to happen? To start let’s take a walk down memory lane.

In early 1900 our energy grid infrastructure mainly moved power from A to B, in a centralized fashion. Today our grid is much more sophisticated with multiple points of supply, types of supply (renewable and non-renewable), and all the while highly variable throughout the day.

More and more we’re seeing solar power production advancing which is great, however, we’re in the beginnings of a massive storage problem, effectively solar harvesting occurs during the day while demand is low and without adequate storage, this power is wasted (pushed to the ground).

As our team considered these barriers we explored arbitraging energy using consumer Evs with the hope of creating a mobile power bank. As we verified through research most vehicles have very low utilization rates (especially consumer EV’s), and even more true with certain municipal sedans, and light-duty trucks. After speaking to our utility members, electric vehicle drivers, and learning about the electric grid Battery Technology in decentralized networks it became apparent the infrastructure cost and the at the consumer level far exceeds the benefits even in the near-term. After this realization we considered consumer fleets as the primary customer, it became apparent that the predictable schedules overnight storage in a centralized location and already available infrastructure would make consumer fleets how much more viable storage solution a large capacity

After speaking with the San Francisco Municipal Fleet, ChargePoint, Ford Global strategy, Exelon, Duke Energy, and Southern Company we verified that commercial fleets would be a viable alternative for storing energy in a decentralized fashion. That said we started prototyping predictive models to approximate the availability of battery storage within consumer fleets.

Stakeholder incentives

By communicating available supply via battery storage utilities would be able to take proactive measures to combat surplus production resulting in saving money. Fleet managers also have an incentive to store power in these latent batteries while the vehicles are parked. Stored power can then later be sold back to the grid during high demand times all the while fleet vehicle remain dormant. Based on our algorithm the vehicles would still achieve their full charge for their duty cycle for the next day.
content.calloutBody: Track vehicles, predict available storage, and estimate arbitrage opportunity.
content.desc: SparkFleet is an AI agent that lets fleet owners turn their electric vehicle batteries into storage banks for the grid, to create a market for energy procurement.
insights: Electric vehicle fleets are a better use case then consumer vehicles due to their consistent
Lack of scalable storage results in underutilization of renewable energy
With over half a million EVs on the road in the US this now represents enough capacity to power 18 million 15 kWh homes for a day
In 3-5 years the average EV range will be around 300 miles thus reducing range anxiety.
EVs have become more economical due to reduce maintenance costs, longer life overall, and fewer parts.
content.why:
We iterated on a few prototypes including positioning of an asset in real time on maps, Fleet management software user experience, a variety of touch points including audible in home in vehicle and mobile. Our team also developed the ability to use real time Chariot data to determine how much available storage capacity existed after a routine use of these city bus vehicles.

Novel to figure out the available capacity in a vehicle and aggregate that total storage we can now use that number to figure out at what point is that available storage significant utility company these thresholds are really important in defining the viability of this project other questions that we're trying to answer are what are the costs for infrastructure installation to discharge alternate the energy to a usable frequency. All this information can we use to define an energy Marketplace for Fleet managers and be able to discharge and sell power back to the grid while the utility could purchase that power to offset the man during peak times of the day these incentives may possibly satisfy the to stakeholders creating a business model for a decentralized battery storage Network.

-KrnyOArSe0dPQf3YhQh.desc: SparkFleet is an AI agent that lets fleet owners turn their electric vehicle batteries into storage banks for the grid, to create a market for energy procurement.

-KrnyOArSe0dPQf3YhQh.title: SparkFleet

card.desc: A multi-modal commuter routing app that provides the right notification at the right time for the anomalies that might occur during one's commute.

content.body:
The efficient movement of a population through a city enables a city to grow, creating new business opportunities, economic growth and encouraging more people to move into the city, and so on. In order to facilitate the flow of people, the city needs to be able to respond to anomalies in a timely manner. The city's existing system is highly manual and analog. Making this system more responsive calls for both a top-down and bottom-up approaches: building a digital twin of a city starts with the citizens. By consistently measuring the actions of individual citizens, we can create and improve in real-time a digital model of the entire city. The benefits are two-fold: it would enable citizens to move around the city fluidly and help the city to better allocate resources and plan for the future.

How Gui works:

Gui aggregates multiple data sources to provide useful transit information for the multi-modal commuter. The data sources include: 1- Public transit disruptions reported by cities transit authorities (e.g. MBTA API) 2- Hyperlocal Weather Predictions (e.g. Dark Sky hyperlocal weather forecasts) 3- Occupancy in buses, trains, subway stations, and spaces (can be measured using computer vision techniques used on existing camera feeds)

Categorizing anomalies:

Gui deconstructs each commute into segments based on modes of movement: walk, bike, subway, bus, etc. Based on these modes of transportation, Gui can categorize the types of anomalies that are relevant to the specific leg of a user’s commute. For example, walking and biking will be affected by rain whereas taking the subway will not; the lack of seating on a bus may deter the user from taking the bus at all. Categorizing the anomalies enables Gui to provide the notifications that fit the context of the user’s commute.

Measuring occupancy:

Object detection models built on top Tensorflow allow Gui to count objects from any input camera feed. These objects include people, cars, and bicycles. The Tensorflow model leverages convolutional neural networks, a machine learning technique that identifies the shapes and associates them the objects that need to be identified. It is usually trained with a large number of images along with the ground truth. Gui object recognition model was trained using the "SSD with Mobilenet" data set.
content.calloutBody: How might we synthesize multiple streams of data to predict patterns and anomalies?
content.desc: A multi-modal commuter routing app that provides the right notification at the right time for the anomalies that might occur during one's commute.
insights: About Users—Routine commuters don’t regularly check the status of their route and therefore are most susceptible when anomalies arise. The cognitive load of managing information from multiple sources—weather, traffic, personal schedule, and so on—is so taxing that users silence notifications altogether. Users need information that’s personally relevant to their journey, delivered at a time when the information is required in making a decision about their journey.

About Technology—Computer Vision: We used Tensorflow to uncover new learnings using computer vision, which tapped data streams from cameras that have been underutilized. There seem to be a lot of opportunities for identifying new sources of information, and extracting insights using AI. Tools like Tensorflow have made it a lot easier to train and deploy applications for a number machine learning applications. We learned that the examples accompanying Tensorflow models made it really easy to setup our own system.

About Opportunities—Design principle for Smart Cities initiatives: ask questions first, then look for data that are needed to answer the question. When cities explore smart cities initiatives, the discussion often starts at the level of data collection, sensor deployment, and infrastructure installation. The process should begin what are the city’s goals, followed by how to translate the qualitative vision into measurable outcomes.   In order to clarify the relationship between various stakeholders in the system, we broke it into dimensions across scale (individual—group—city) and time (now—near future—far future). We can then start to identify opportunities for partnership between stakeholders, for example, utility companies (group) and MBTA (city).
content.why:
A city is an aggregate of individual decisions; we believe that studying the mechanisms that govern individual decisions will help surface patterns of behavior on a city scale.

By studying individual decisions, we start to discover:

1- what information drives which decisions (e.g. does the likelihood of getting a seat on the bus determining proclivity for taking the bus)?

2- in order to derive such information, which new data streams should be measured (e.g. measuring occupancy and producing a predictive model for bus seat availability over time)?

3- given existing data streams, how does raw data get turned into useful information that is personalized for an individual?

-KrpujMtTo-1lfpiYgvj.desc: A multi-modal commuter routing app that provides the right notification at the right time for the anomalies that might occur during one's commute.
-KrpujMtTo-1lfpiYgvj.title: Gui – your transit buddy

card.desc: IZR is a personal finance tool for cryptocurrency investments. IZR enables investors to easily create and manage a diverse crypto-asset portfolio, aggregating tools across multiple platforms. IZR leverages the unique distributed architecture of the blockchain to reimagine the traditional investment stack for crypto-assets (currencies, tokens).

content.body:
IZR is both a portfolio management tool and roboadvisor for cryptocurrency assets. 

Today, most active crypto-investors manage their investments manually, using Google Docs, centralized services, and their own memory to know what assets they hold and their price history. IZR’s portfolio management functions enables users to create, collate and manage wallets of diverse crypto-assets, visualizing their exposure to different tokens and currencies.

Building on top of the asset aggregation functionality, IZR’s investment tool  enables users to subscribe to a range of “investment strategies,”. Those strategies enable investors to quickly make investments in “baskets” of crypto-assets, without having to transfer their asset ownership to investment managers. Currently, both initial asset allocations and rebalances are managed through blockchain smart contracts that act as indices, tracking an allocation of crypto-assets and updating these allocations automatically as the assets that fall under their rule-set change. 

For example, let’s say you have a fruit salad containing 2 apples, 2 bananas, 3 pineapples and 1 watermelon. Banana season is coming to an end, and there is a tastier fruit salad mix that you really want in on. The salad chef see’s in your fridge and says, “Hey, I recommend sending those 2 bananas to me, and I’ll send you 3 juicy plums in exchange.” When the transaction is complete, you have the tastiest, most balanced fruit salad.

We believe that these strategies themselves will be distributed in the future(see Enigma's Catalyst) allowing users to subscribe to one another's indexes and strategies in a similar manner. We’ll see a mix of traditional investment professionals and active management, along with index-based investments
content.calloutBody: Create a simple, customizable, and informative experience that can help a new user purchase, manage, and trade crypto-assets?
content.desc: IZR is a personal finance tool for cryptocurrency investments. IZR enables investors to easily create and manage a diverse crypto-asset portfolio, aggregating tools across multiple platforms. IZR leverages the unique distributed architecture of the blockchain to reimagine the traditional investment stack for crypto-assets (currencies, tokens).
insights: Security and usability are unbalanced today since using crypto-investment platforms is radically different from today's investment tools and the learning curve can be steep for new users. Education must be included within the user-experience to highlight how the platform is different at important touch points, so that security and usability don’t have to mean two different things in the future.

We need design guidelines and heuristics for blockchain platforms, just like we have for the User Interfaces (UI) of front-end digital products and applications These guidelines must take into account the unique architecture, security, and distributed nature of blockchain protocols.

Transacting in the blockchain space is very cumbersome and often takes several steps across multiple platforms. There is a huge opportunity for projects who that prioritize a fluid and pleasant user-experience.

Since tokens are inherently valuable and can be used for many different reasons across different platforms, financial tools need to also be usage tools, that help people understand what rights and responsibilities their token ownership provides them and offer clear tie-ins to the platforms where they can be used.

Tokenization will cause major disruption to the status quo for financial investment. While some groups will be incentivized to resist change, change is indeed coming and successful financial and investment companies will need to evolve their own systems and infrastructure or risk getting left behind.

As the crypto space becomes more regulated, the community must ensure that regulations are for the benefit of as many people as possible. There is a strong potential for regulatory capture, a form of government failure that occurs when a regulatory agency fails to act in the public interest and instead advances the commercial concerns of special interest groups that dominate the industry/sector it is charged with regulating. While the SEC has displayed a sophisticated and nuanced understanding of new crypto-assets so far, researchers, foundations, and policy-makers must be better educated and involved in advising on this emerging asset-class to ensure that the regulations help real people, not special interests.
content.why:
Because of the rise of blockchains and other distributed financial tools, the financial system is poised for fundamental change. One big reason for this change is tokenization, the process of converting rights to an asset into a digital token on a blockchain. Tokens themselves aren’t new, but their usage to introduce the idea of property into the digital realm is unique to the blockchain. Tokenizing assets in this way allows goods to be traded as close to directly as possible, potentially even without the abstraction of government-issued (fiat) money in the future.This represents a fundamental shift in how projects and ventures are funded, providing a new level of speed (time to liquidity) security (immutable public record), and accessibility (open to anyone with internet access) to investing in future projects. 

As more and more tangible and intangible assets become tokenized and exchanged on the blockchain, several implications emerge for the financial sector.

The internet already increased liquidity by opening up competitive online marketplaces with more people and volume for exchanging goods/services. Tokenizing assets on a blockchain extends this trend, allowing for the tokenization and exchange of new types of assets and providing a huge liquidity premium. This means more types of goods and services can be ‘securitized’ and traded openly between a wider pool of investors.

When venture capitalists and early stage investors fund startups, their contribution quickly becomes illiquid as it is tied up for several years and not allowed to be traded. Selling tokens to raise money allows this investment to be traded on the open market within days or weeks. This represents a huge change in how venture capital works today.
Tokenization will cause major disruption to the status quo, meaning traditional financial models like securities lending may not work the same way in a blockchain future. The current system will have to grow and evolve to meet these changes and stakeholders who benefit from the status quo today will have to adopt new methods to continue to reap rewards.

But unlike traditional investment markets with both a long history of standards, consumer protections and a range of tools for investors of any level to aggregate, manage, and exchange investment products through simple user-interfaces and websites, crypto-investing is brand new and fragmented, spread out over a variety of platforms, services and tools with varying levels of usability. While the number of people interested in crypto-assets is increasing, either as an investment opportunity or for future use, it is still intimidating for new users to get started and for experienced investors to aggregate the existing tools and services they use into one seamless user experience. 

It’s hard for users to understand where their assets live and who has ownership over them, so today, users trade off security for easier to use platforms.  Due to the somewhat unforgiving cryptographic roots of this technology (public and private pairs) it’s easy for users to lose access to their assets completely. The platforms that address this issue specifically trade the cryptographic security features for an easy to navigate UI built on traditional centralized digital architectures that are fundamentally insecure..

Beyond that, tokens are a brand-new asset class that is hard to define and even more difficult to categorize in terms of risk and reward. Since each token can fundamentally represent a different product/service/currency/investment tool, it is hard for both users and regulators to understand what they do and the financial risk/reward they carry. For this reason, it is difficult users to make financial decisions and even harder for regulators to make policy decisions that adequately protect consumers yet allow them the freedom to invest in new ways.

Even with these challenges, the exchange of tokenized goods and services over blockchain networks will become a critical part of our future, and our token portfolios will emerge as important indicators of both our financial and philosophical preferences for where we generate and store our value. Tokens have the potential to create a strong foundation for the reputation economy we already see emerging (sharing economy) facilitating more direct and organic connections between people and projects. They are more than just money, they represent our interest, affiliation, and connection with projects and ideas and as more and more people realize this, our world will radically transform. This future is starting now, and IZR’s goal is to empower as many as possible to have a stake in deciding how it is created.

IZR enables investors to easily create and manage a diverse crypto-asset portfolio, aggregating tools across multiple platforms. IZR leverages the unique distributed architecture of the blockchain to reimagine the traditional investment stack for crypto-assets (currencies, tokens).

card.desc: This iteration of AR/ER uses AR to guide personnel to equipment and/or a patient in a Code Blue scenario by giving them the ability to see the locations of assets through walls.

content.body:
This iteration of AR/ER uses AR to guide personnel to equipment and/or a patient in a Code Blue scenario by giving them the ability to see the locations of assets through walls. The Objects being tracked are located through a mesh network of BLE beacons that communicate to a web application that exacts their locations in a physical space through a neural network. The positions are then mapped to a hololens visualization in unity.

A key point in our findings was being able to provide direction for necessary equipment in a timely fashion, when seconds can be life-saving. Our prototype maps out a potential ER area. The scenario is a nurse calls a Code Blue, AI sends messaging to 4 personnel, 2 are sent directions to equipment that is needed, and then directs them to the patient's room. AR identifies the best path, and shows the equipment thru the walls.


Tools:
HoloLens to provide the AR simulation experience, Neural Networks to triangulate the objects in space, PLE Devices to identify hidden items in rooms, Graph Search to help determine the best path to the object.
content.calloutBody: use real-time data, displayed in-context, to drive better decision making in a workplace?
content.desc: This iteration of AR/ER uses AR to guide personnel to equipment and/or a patient in a Code Blue scenario by giving them the ability to see the locations of assets through walls.
content.why: The objects could be life-saving (reduce Workers Comp impacts), or simply a map to the correct tool, or the closest working one (Energy).  Mapping could be used to teach a process, or show next steps (Any industry). AR could be an onboarding tool that shows a new person around, and provides contextual information based on their role (Any industry). Customers trying to find the closest office, or provider or ER (Blue Cross Blue Shield, could be linked to an online AR experience to provide them with context to their location in relation to the place.
