card.desc: MAX stands for Medical Artificial eXperiences. It is a voice interface designed to capture primary care physician notes during patient visits.

content.body:
MAX is a dynamic, voice based EMR. Max collects initial information from patients up front, so doctors can spend one on one time understanding patient ailments.

Max is installed in large format screens in treatment rooms. After being introduced to Max, patients are asked a series of questions to understand the purpose of their visit and collect medical history, and are directed to a series of machines (e.g., a scale) to record baseline health information.

Max synthesizes the information into a higher order list of priorities, which the doctor and patient can both see, and dynamically update (via voice) during the visit.
content.desc: MAX stands for Medical Artificial eXperiences. It is a voice interface designed to capture primary care physician notes during patient visits.

card.desc: Faster, safer disaster response through ubiquitous computer vision.

content.body: Utilities plan for disaster response, but the truth on the ground often challenges processes and systems intended to restore power quickly. IntelliResponse gathers real-time disaster images from ubiquitous computer vision, including cameras associated with smart infrastructure, drones, and citizen cell phones. Trained machine learning algorithms tag the images to identify and report problems and geolocate the relevant infrastructure, driving a prioritization list for utility restoration activities. Utility dispatchers can easily access, modify, and filter the restoration priority list, following AI-driven recommendations for actions to take on each issue or choosing an alternate course. The system allows for real-time tracking of responders, along with their dashboard cameras, to continue optimizing successive restoration tasks. The system also identifies road hazards (downed trees and wires, floodings) and provides dispatch routes to help teams successfully and quickly reach their destinations. While the first users will be electric utilities working to restore power infrastructure, the system is intended eventually to link with other first responders' systems, allowing for comprehensive, coordinated, safe, and fast recovery after a disaster.
content.calloutBody: use computer vision in disaster response and restoration?
content.desc: Faster, safer disaster response through ubiquitous computer vision.
insights: Computer vision will dramatically enhance the data available during and immediately after a disaster, but responders need a way to translate that data in to actions they can take toward restoration.

The system will be most useful if it integrates priorities and recommendations with real-time data on how restoration is going; it's important to maintain a feedback loop between prioritization and real-time data from response teams.

The greatest value is likely to come from integrating a utility system like this one with prioritization and activities of other types of first responders. An ideal architecture could include versions of this platform for medical personnel, emergency responders, and government organizations that talk to one another and enable close coordination.
Multiple sources of video data  - traffic cameras, drone cameras, cell phone videos, dashboard cameras - exist today and can be utilized.
content.why: In the immediate aftermath of a disasters like hurricanes and earthquakes, speedy infrastructure restoration will save lives. Social media, citizen-recorded images, and computer vision data are already helping utilities and other responders identify infrastructure damage, but those responders need a comprehensive system to collect, process, and use the data they receive. IntelliResponse is a platform for turning vision data into a prioritized list of problems with recommended actions, integrated with real-time tracking of dispatched response teams and optimization of their actions. The platform will create and provide maps to help teams avoid hazards and thus dramatically shorten recovery times while enhancing situational awareness for citizens and workers in the disaster aftermath. By making this information available to other audiences (media, government, citizens) it also will enable utilities to better assess and communicate the timeliness of response efforts.

-KvhiV7BuPjekr-Hd1MY.desc: Faster, safer disaster response through ubiquitous computer vision.
-KvhiV7BuPjekr-Hd1MY.tags: energy, disaster response, computer vision, AI, machine learning
team: Eric Doyle, Lara Pierpoint, Karen Sabatino, Matt Whitaker
-KvhiV7BuPjekr-Hd1MY.title: IntelliResponse

card.desc: Journey specific risk based insurance for autonomous vehicle ride-sharing.

content.body:
Our product, which we named kurrently, is a journey-specific risk-based insurance product for autonomous vehicle ride sharing. Our product is aimed at ride-sharing fleet owners, who would in turn offer insurance to their passengers that is priced on a per-journey basis. 

Our insurance product uses a wealth of data to price accurate insurance quotes. The data sources include road conditions (eg are there potholes?), weather (eg is it icy?), route score (eg are you passing any dangerous areas?), time of day (eg is it dark?), traffic (eg how many cars on the road?) and more. Once the expected cost of the trip is calculated, an insurance price is charged to the customer. When the journey is completed, this prediction is stored alongside the actual results of the journey. These results are aggregated and used to iteratively improve the insurance pricing using machine learning techniques.
content.desc: Journey specific risk based insurance for autonomous vehicle ride-sharing.
content.why:
How might we protect ourselves from downside change in a world of real-time, always available information? 

A world with autonomous vehicles has numerous pain-points, one of which is the applicability of traditional auto insurance products. In particular, when cars have no human drivers who is to blame when accidents occur? Additionally, how much longer can the insurance industry provide blanket insurance solutions to passengers? 

The increasing prevalence of data can be used to solve both of these issues.

-Kvi9qC4iRSsGu6L8TS3.desc: Journey specific risk based insurance for autonomous vehicle ride-sharing.
media: kurrently - journey specific risk based insurance for autonomous vehicle ride-sharing 913
-Kvi9qC4iRSsGu6L8TS3.tags: machine learning, autos, autonomous vehicles, AI, big data, insurance
-Kvi9qC4iRSsGu6L8TS3.title: kurrently

card.desc: RideCare and RideShare provide software to supplement the autonomous vehicle owner experience.

content.body:
Autonomous vehicle owners are looking for a way to take advantage of the self-driving capabilities of their cars. Whether it be car maintenance, charging or cleaning, these everyday activities can be completed without driver intervention.

RideCare and RideShare are white labeled software installations for autonomous vehicles. This software option can be integrated into your buying process to create a seamless buying experience for your customers. Based on a Rule Based POI system and Proof of Services Smart Contracts, owner can view and verify in real time where their car has been, what services the car has received, and profit and expenses per ride.

RideCare provides owners a fully autonomous experience when dealing with routine activities such keeping your vehicle fully maintained and looking its best.

• Basic car care and maintenance services
• Car cleaning services
• EV charging services
• A real time dashboard enables service logging and verification

RideShare provides opt in/opt out ride share availability for your vehicle. RideShare includes RideCare services plus the options for ride pool participation. This ride based pricing model allows owners to make money with their car when not in use. Additional services are available to make the ride share experience seamless for the owner, e.g. supplemental insurance.
content.desc: RideCare and RideShare provide software to supplement the autonomous vehicle owner experience.
insights: Coming up with an idea and coming up with something to prototype are two very different things.  Focusing on a viable prototype helped to simplify our idea into presentable options to be tested through our interviews and demos.  Over our three days we landed on three iterations of concepts until we were able to land on an MVP.
content.why: Our starting brief was ‘What’s possible when vehicles are given the ability to transact and participate in markets?’  Through our brainstorming sessions we kept coming back to the idea of transactional interactions between the user and the vehicle, like the purchasing of in vehicle WiFi or paying for tolls on the highway.  The use of Smart Contracts and the underlying use of Blockchain provided a transparent ledger of activities that could be trusted and verified.

-KviA-W85zKIyF09rDt6.desc: RideCare and RideShare provide software to supplement the autonomous vehicle owner experience.
-KviA-W85zKIyF09rDt6.tags: Autonomous vehicles, Ride sharing, Blockchain, Smart contracts
-KviA-W85zKIyF09rDt6.title: RideCare

card.desc:
Problem:

Today, credit scores are calculated by Credit Bureaus. 
•	The process is very opaque to consumers 
•	0 Control over data, how it’s used, shared or sold 
•	Financial ID is not secure 

How might we redesign credit bureaus to put humans at the center? (Leveraging distributed networks)
•	Using blockchain: Because we wanted a decentralized network to add a layer of security and give users controls over their data 

Imagine:

Your credit score is no longer a mystery. 

•	Consortium of relevant stakeholders that acts a standard body 
o	Stakeholders Include: Creditors, Consumers, Lenders, Banks, CPA
•	Define the rules for calculating a block chain based Credit Score 

How does it work today?: 

Credit scores are based on available data about your credit history. Credit bureaus get information about your credit history from creditors to calculate a credit score. Creditors then use this Credit Score to evaluate your credit worthiness. 

This process is not standardized and consumers have no visibility into how their score is calculated. Credit Bureaus combine this information with Personal Information and sell it to creditors. 

What we are proposing: 
We want to shift the ownership of data to consumers and make the calculation of Credit Scores transparent and standardized. 

How we plan to do it:
App Developers will convert current contracts (utility providers, phone, credit card, etc.) into smart contracts. An algorithm will calculate Credit Score based on standardized rules. 
We will replace personal information with an encrypted ID to protect your personal data (System generates a public key for you) 


What you gain:

Consumers 
•	Transparency
•	Control 
•	Security

content.body:
Today, credit scores are calculated by Credit Bureaus. The process is very opaque to consumers who have no control over data, how it’s used, shared or sold. This leaves financial ID insecure.

We were interested in understanding—How might we redesign credit bureaus to put humans at the center, leveraging distributed networks?

Imagine:
Your credit score is no longer a mystery.

• We've assembled a consortium of relevant stakeholders that acts a standard body
• The stakeholders Include: Creditors, Consumers, Lenders, Banks, CPA
• They define the rules for calculating a block chain based Credit Score, and use it to issue credit


How does it work today?:

Credit scores are based on available data about your credit history. Credit bureaus get information about your credit history from creditors to calculate a credit score. Creditors then use this Credit Score to evaluate your credit worthiness.

This process is not standardized and consumers have no visibility into how their score is calculated. Credit Bureaus combine this information with Personal Information and sell it to creditors.

What we are proposing: We want to shift the ownership of data to consumers and make the calculation of Credit Scores transparent and standardized.

How we plan to do it: App Developers will convert current contracts (utility providers, phone, credit card, etc.) into smart contracts. An algorithm will calculate Credit Score based on standardized rules. We will replace personal information with an encrypted ID to protect your personal data (System generates a public key for you)

What you gain:

Consumers • Transparency
• Control
• Security

card.desc: An abstracted cryptocurrency savings account that allows first time cryptocurrency buyers to invest in crypto without numbers or foreign terms at the forefront.

content.body:
During our crypto-wallets sprint we brainstormed multiple methods of creating more low friction methods of investing in cryptocurrency, focusing on wallet types and onboarding methods as a place where design is heavily needed to become a standardized experience.

Bitpool arouse after discussing what might happen if we create a cryptocurrency wallet storage application that was purely for depositing and withdrawal. In this method, the user could deposit local currency funds into an account that would then buy cryptocurrency coins on their behalf. The distributions could possibly be adjusted, but in certain cases, the user might not want to be burdened with knowing exactly what they're investing in, just that the money that they deposit is being invested in crypto of some type. With that in mind, what would happen if we took that thought to more of an extreme?

Bitpool presents a new abstracted way of investing in cryptocurrency. You are presented with an empty tide pool, a bare ecosystem in place for you to build on. You can diversify the ecosystem by strategically "buying" elements in increments of $1, $2, or $5 that you believe will benefit the pool. You can also choose to create a flat deposit of money into your pool, say, $250, to create a new type of fish to put inside of your pool. Over time, certain creatures that you add can multiply, and as they do, your pool's worth grows. Just the same, certain creatures may be bad for the ecosystem, or become a victim of natural selection, and your pool's worth can shrink. At any time, you can withdraw your funds from the pool and deposit them back into your bank account using a net to scoop out some of your fish.

So what's actually happening here? The currency that you "spend" is deposited through a linked bank account, and is deposited into your pool's funds, which is actually multiple exchange cryptocurrency wallets. You pool's value is the total holding value of your crypto shown in your local currency. Depositing is as easy and fun as buying new creatures for your pool. You can also make a flat deposit, and see your investment stick around inside of your pool. Withdrawing takes fish away from your pool and transfers currency out of your wallets to be exchange for your local currency and then is deposited back to your linked bank account. Withdrawing currency from your wallet or making a deposit may incur network or exchange fees which you are notified of at the time of the transaction (just like any transfer on an exchange or within network chains). You can also choose to manage your distributions or how your currency is invested, affecting what percentages of your deposits get invested into what currencies.
content.calloutBody: Make crypto-currency investment more accessible for first-time buyers or younger age groups?
content.desc: An abstracted cryptocurrency savings account that allows first time cryptocurrency buyers to invest in crypto without numbers or foreign terms at the forefront.
content.why: With Bitpool we wanted to create a simple, two function savings account for crypto-investment. Bitpool's base features are that you can deposit money and withdraw money, making it far simpler than other complex crypto-currency wallets and exchanges on the market today. Bitpool combines multiple interactions with services into a single function, and abstracts the user interface in a way that it doesn't feel like you're buying cryptocurrency. Bitpool also makes a stake in the ground for CoLab's interest in biomimicry projects, using tidepools as a metaphor for investing.

-L-YOxrCPuqy_mKKPLrC.desc: An abstracted cryptocurrency savings account that allows first time cryptocurrency buyers to invest in crypto without numbers or foreign terms at the forefront.
-L-YOxrCPuqy_mKKPLrC.tags: blockchain, cryptocurrency, crypto, savings account, money, abstraction, biomimicry
-L-YOxrCPuqy_mKKPLrC.title: Bitpool

card.desc: Three Things combines real-time sensor data, public domain city GIS data, and user-generated recreational activity data to create a real-time digital twin of a city. This can provide geographical and socioeconomic insight into the affects of public developments and allow for more informed decision making when re-zoning or improving an era of a city.

content.body:
Three Things combines real-time sensor data, public domain city GIS data, and user-generated recreational activity data to create a real-time digital twin of a city. This can provide geographical and socioeconomic insight into the affects of public developments and allow for more informed decision making when re-zoning or improving an era of a city.

In Three Things, we explore how different users might interface with data that is currently scattered across many different sources. Citizens might look for curation and travel efficiency data to help them discover their cities differently. Urban planners and city officials might want more specific and real-time data to get finer detail on the efficiency of city infrastructure.

Three Things uses Mapbox to bring together different types of data in the form of 'Lenses' that can be layered to see the city from many different perspectives at once. An example could be a 'loudness lens' that displays data collected by audio sensors in and around Cambridge businesses. When overlaid with city GIS data such as zoning, construction permit applications, or business data from facebook, Three Things starts to show correlations among data patterns for certain streets and areas.

Trends and historical patterns can be used to predict future change: has a certain area evolved from being the center of trade in a downtown location to now becoming more residential due to a new improvement a street over? Is a certain area beginning to become victim to gentrification due to new developments?
content.calloutBody: Use multiple data sources to create a digital twin of a physical city that can empower city planners and citizens to look at their city differently?
content.desc: Three Things combines real-time sensor data, public domain city GIS data, and user-generated recreational activity data to create a real-time digital twin of a city. This can provide geographical and socioeconomic insight into the affects of public developments and allow for more informed decision making when re-zoning or improving an era of a city.
content.why: We believe that data-driven intelligence can help to empower urban planners and citizens to be more informed about their cities and the effects citizens have on them. Three things stands as a new way to start thinking about how data-driven AI could use GIS data, crowdsourced activity data, and live sensor data streams to surface trends or make automated suggestions or decisions that humans may not perceive.

card.desc: A trust-less, decentralized analytics platform that helps advertisers and publishers speak the same language. (And make more money.)

content.body:
Rosetta is a decentralized advertising platform built on Ethereum. Right now, of every dollar spent by advertisers, publishers only see 40 cents. From 2015-16, the U.S. advertising market grew by 19% -- but only because Google and Facebook had crazy successful years. If you exclude those two players, the rest-of-market actually *contracted* by 2%. We designed two-sided marketplace and compete with Google and Facebook on their own home turf. To achieve that vision, we needed to start small. And, after some pivoting and pivoting some more, we believe the first opportunity is in cryptographically-verified email analytics for crypto-newsletters.

Rosetta begins with a javascript snippet that can cryptographically track key email metrics (e.g., clicks on a button, opens, subscribers, view time). Think of it like a "crypto-pixel" that can easily track activity in the digital world and record it on a blockchain.

Crypto-newsletter publishers often don't trust the metrics that MailChimp or Google give them. Today, metrics often they often conflict with each other -- so newsletter publishers love "double-verification" (their words) of key metrics. Rosetta enables true metrics tracking, along with the ability to benchmark against competitors without sacrificing privacy. Rosetta enables via a public ranking system by taking pseudonymous data captured by our blockchain and making it more readily visible and interactable. .

Once we achieve a critical mass of email newsletter publishers on the platform, we will expand to a buy/sell marketplace for ads. The pixel we developed could easily expand to be a container for an ad. Then, once you have publishers and advertisers, you have the market you need to go for the gold bitcoin.
content.calloutBody: ...use Ethereum addresses and attention auctions to decentralize advertising?
content.desc: A trust-less, decentralized analytics platform that helps advertisers and publishers speak the same language. (And make more money.)

card.desc: The customer experience around itemizing insurance claims stinks. In fact it's the last thing that anyone who has gone through an accident or event wants to do. With Inventory, we're changing the game by using photos from your camera roll and image recognition technology to automatically inventory your personal belongings.

content.body:
The customer experience around itemizing insurance claims stinks. In fact it's the last thing that anyone who has gone through an accident or event wants to do. With Inventory, we're changing the game by using photos from your camera roll and image recognition technology to automatically inventory your personal belongings.

Inventory works as a standalone product, or rolled into an insurance agency's claims processing funnel. Fraud in claims costs insurance companies billions each year—but without accurate inventories of possessions, from high to low value, it's difficult to combat.

Beyond that, not inventorying our belongings hurts people. Once their items are damaged or destroyed, they're faced with the monumental task of remembering what they owned and rebuilding their lives.

Inventory solves this problem. Building off the consumer insight that people want their insurance to be reactive without them needing to take an proactive effort, we built a tool that could scrape camera roll data geo-tagged at your house, and quickly identify what items you had. Those items might be furniture, clothing, or electronics -- and our prototype recognizes them all. Then it guides the person through an opportunity to tag and filter their images before sending them out—adding details the API can't figure out (yet) like brand or price. As consumers add those details, those feed into the machine learning model powering Inventory.

Once the prototype is robust enough, we imagine partnering with retailers to help making rebuilding even more seamless. Imagine being able to recognize that your couch came from West Elm, and automatically reordering it—or even having Crate and Barrel give you a competing offer. We're excited by the immediate problem to solve, and the long term opportunities that highlight what we might do when we have an accurate inventory of belongings.
content.desc: Inventory is an app for insurance companies that leverages existing image data (camera roll images) to identify an "inventory" of a home's belongings to rebuild in the event of a total loss.

-L26OP5sO-OWxN0j-5pG.desc: Inventory is an app for insurance companies that leverages existing image data (camera roll images) to identify an "inventory" of a home's belongings to rebuild in the event of a total loss.

card.desc: Marketplace for insights based on fleet data

content.body:
Ford Newton is an insights marketplace for fleet owners. We facilitate transactions between OEMs and fleet owners of their vehicles to benchmark fleet performance against other OEM fleets. As new data sources became available, we provide analytics based on performance against other manufacturers, and begin to create a more thriving, robust marketplace for vehicle data.

With the emergence of autonomous vehicles, we saw the opportunity for marketplace to share data to enable better systems. There are many different use cases for this data and many different data points which are being produced by one party and could be consumed by another. 

Data creators who might be able to generate data useful to a set of AV system manufacturers. Think of the human rider, sharing movement or interaction information, insurers sharing claims settlement information, municipalities sharing city sensor data, dashcam providers sharing information on high definition mapping, or even the OEM buying and selling on-vehicle data from other OEMs.

Each of these companies or providers have data and this data could be used by other providers in the system to improve their performance or have a broader set of data to work from. This would create more robust AV systems -- each manufacturer would be able to solve for edge cases more simply.

After interviewing Ford, we recognize that the opportunity wasn't in raw data—it was in insights. OEMs today hold their data close, believing in its competitive advantage. While that may have long term benefits, in the short term, it means that they are shielding a suite of relevant data from their customers.

Ford Newton enables us to solve for the near-term concerns of OEMs, protecting their data at the outset, while still incentivizing the sharing of more useful, insight level analytics.
content.desc: Insights marketplace for fleet vehicle data, enabling benchmarks against other fleets.

-L26Zuy_0_t-xxtNyw4k.desc: Insights marketplace for fleet vehicle data, enabling benchmarks against other fleets.

card.desc: Promise is a smart contracts application built for cash strapped contractors that serves to provide them with access to equipment on credit from suppliers upon the creation of service contracts with customers. The service works on the concept of escrow. Customers would create a service contract with a contractor agreeing to have services provided while putting money upfront in escrow for the service and the products. The contract created between a customer and the contractor serves as a auditable document that shows a proof of services giving the supplier confidence to provide the product on credit and create a contract with the contractor. Once services are rendered by the contractor, the escrow would pay out to the contractor and supplier.

content.body:
Promise is a smart contract app for service providers that puts the details of their contract onto a blockchain, enabling them to finance their inventory. Imagine an electrician is just starting out and haven't established a history of work yet. They need to get products to complete a job with a new customer but don't have any money to buy the materials. Most banks don't offer credit in this scenario, or charge high interest. As a result it becomes difficult for electricians to take on these jobs.

Using Promise, once an electrician signs up a customer, they can draft and send a contract for approval. The customer would get an SMS message that the contract has been created and they can review it by a link provided in the message that sends them to Promise.

Unlike traditional contract management, the Promise app prompts customers to pay their deposit up front, but ensures that that money stays in escrow until the services are completed. Once the electrician and customer agree on terms, the customer sends money to an escrow account.

With that contract (digitally) in hand, electricians can now go to a supplier and buy products on credit. Suppliers can easily audit the electrician's contracts to reduce the risk of handing over inventory on credit. Beyond audits, Promise lets manufacturers create new contracts with the electrician, that link directly to the electrician's contract with the customer. When one is paid, the other automatically acts to pay back the manufacturer. Once the job is finished and both the electrician and the customer verify that it has been completed then the escrow pays out. If there is a dispute then Promise initiates an arbitration process, and the money is held in escrow until a decision is made.

As the contractor completes more jobs successfully their credit increases potentially allowing him to be able to purchase products at discounts or additional credit without the need for having any contracts in the future.

Promise could revolutionize financing for small businesses, and create more transparency for individuals. Customers could know that their funds/deposits were used to pay for their jobs, electricians could access new inventory and scale their business, and manufacturers could sell more goods.
content.desc: Promise is a smart contracts application built for cash strapped contractors that provides them with access to equipment on credit from suppliers upon the creation of service contracts with customers.
content.why:
The project was built to solve a problem of allowing contractors that had little to no credit-worthiness obtain some kind of financing or products on credit from suppliers or other parties, so as to be able to do business. The request was made that we create something that was auditable and that ensured that pricing between the supplier and customer / supplier and contractor was masked so as not to risk the release of any information that would lead to any loss of competitive advantage between the parties. 

When looking at the problem we realized that the challenge was one of confidence between the parties. Why would a supplier provide any equipment to a contractor on credit? The thought was that if we can use smart contracts between the contractor and the customer (with an escrow amount being specified in the contract) as a proof of service to be carried out and ability to pay, then the supplier might want to provide the products to the contractor on credit.  The promise of payment along with a binding contract that presents proof of a job that is to be carried out, might give the supplier enough confidence to provide the contractor with the materials he needs.

-L26uToCkxlMsd-h3R4O.desc: Promise is a smart contracts application built for cash strapped contractors that provides them with access to equipment on credit from suppliers upon the creation of service contracts with customers.

card.desc: The solar-powered stablecoin

content.body:
USDx is a stable cryptocurrency that creates ​10X more green energy than it consumes.

How does it work? We build and buy solar installations from solar companies (solar farms, solar mini-grids, solar home systems) around the globe. We mint 1 USDX coin worth 1 USD for every 1 W of installed solar power. We sell USDX coins on exchanges to crypto investors.

USDx coins enable crypto investors to protect their assets with a stablecoin in the event of a downturn, and make financial applications (P2P transactions, lending, remittances) possible on the blockchain. They're funded through a USDx foundation that pegs their value to the USD, and uses the purchases to fund new solar developments.

Investors can track their impact by visiting the USDx foundation's web page, to see which solar developments each USDx coin has funded. Think of it like a Kiva PPA, built on a blockchain.
content.calloutBody: What if we introduced a cryptocurrency that deployed 1 GW of clean energy globally and powered 200 Million lives?
content.desc: The solar-powered stablecoin
insights: Mining BTC wastes trillions of watt hours per year.
1.2 billion people don’t have access to electricity.

card.desc: Peer-to-peer flight insurance powered by Smart Contracts on the Ethereum blockchain to enable dynamic premium pricing and instant, claim-free payouts for travelers and investors.

content.body:
Brella is a peer-to-peer marketplace for flight delay insurance leveraging data-driven risk models for dynamic premium pricing and Smart Contracts for instant, claim-free insurance payouts.

Travelers engage with Brella through a Chrome extension, which activates at the point of purchase of a flight on an airline website. Brella provides a risk score for flight delay and cancellation, explanation, and tiers of insurance premiums, which offer variable payouts for delays of different lengths. User and payment information is stored in a Brella account and individual premium purchases for each flight are pooled into a Smart Contract, which serve as the financial instrument available for investment.

Investors use Brella through a portfolio-based investment interface, like Betterment or Wealthfront. Based on the size of their fund and risk profile, Brella makes targeted flight investments for each individual, pooling multiple investors into each flight's Smart Contract.

On the backend, the Smart Contract is built on the Ethereum blockchain, connecting groups of travelers and investors. The beauty of a Smart Contract is instant, binding payment upon completion of an event, in this case, calculation and confirmation of a flight delay. This data originates from a trusted third-party oracle such as the FlightStats API. This provides a better user experience for travelers by offering clarity of terms (get paid when your flight gets delayed) and guaranteed, claim-free payout. Due to the necessity of transacting with an Ethereum-based currency in the Smart Contract, premium quantities are tied to a Stablecoin to ensure payout quantities match premium terms.

Brella's mission is to build a platform trusted by travelers and investors, to encourage an increase in flight insurance premium purchases and create a sustainable investment market.
content.desc: Peer-to-peer flight insurance powered by Smart Contracts on the Ethereum blockchain to enable dynamic premium pricing and instant, claim-free payouts for travelers and investors.
insights: Consumers feel a lack of trust and clarity towards existing flight/travel insurance policies, leading to low rates of insurance purchase.
Access to a secure, trusted third-party "oracle" is essential for confirming contract-triggering events.
content.why:
Surveys show that >78% of travelers never buy flight or travel insurance, largely due to lack of trust and clarity surrounding payout terms.

Peer-to-peer marketplaces cut out the middleman, in this case the insurance company that sets prices, has the power to approve claims, and receives the bulk of profits from premium purchases. Smart contract technology offers an opportunity to provide better outcomes through trustless systems of instant, claim-free payouts upon the occurrence of an event. By more directly connecting buyers and sellers and providing clarity of payout terms and risk-based pricing, we believe we can spur growth in the insurance market and provide a better experience for travelers and investors.

-L2M-GwW1xXkcVS-yiBy.desc: Peer-to-peer flight insurance powered by Smart Contracts on the Ethereum blockchain to enable dynamic premium pricing and instant, claim-free payouts for travelers and investors.
-L2M-GwW1xXkcVS-yiBy.title: Brella: 1

card.desc: A marketplace that facilitates group funding of energy development projects.

content.body:
Re-fund helps connect energy producers to businesses, and allows an aggregation of funding between multiple businesses. This helps larger projects get funded and any business get involved.

Businesses choose to get involved by donating a small percentage of purchases. Say each time a customer buys a coffee, 3% of that money is allocated to the smart contract fund. The funds grow continuously as customers make purchases, but only certain amounts can be released under certain circumstances.

The release of funding is powered by a smart contract, which allows for a system of checks and balances to be used. As energy producers reach benchmarks in their building process, for example completing the frames at the solar panel site, funds for the next step in the process will be released. The successful completion of benchmarks is determined by artificial intelligence and computer vision system that compares Building Information Modeling to on-site video feeds, removing for a centralized auditor.
content.calloutBody: make the renewable energy market more accessible to businesses?
content.desc: A marketplace that facilitates group funding of energy development projects.
content.why:
The voluntary renewable energy market currently caters to large corporations to either buy Renewable Energy Certificates (RECs) or sign Power Purchasing Agreements (PPAs), and both existing options have potential issues with either accessibility (most companies cannot afford to sign PPAs) and/or actual impact on renewable energy asset investment (when compared to the regulated RPS-driven renewable energy market).

The smart-contract technology behind Re-fund provides a middle-ground solution, where thousands of transactions at end customer point-of-purchase can be aggregated together, and then released only when producers fulfill the smart contract parameters. This gives any business an alternative to both RECs and PPAs.

In addition to providing an alternative solution to the existing voluntary RE market, we also wanted to incentivize a greater potential pool of businesses to incorporate RE into their marketing and branding efforts. By allowing the funding of specific RE development projects, businesses can create targeted marketing campaigns to increase revenue and customer engagement with their products, regardless of the business’s core mission statement—increasing accessibility for any type of business model.

-L2M3ZHZgM1FjOjGrs4v.desc: A marketplace that facilitates group funding of energy development projects.
-L2M3ZHZgM1FjOjGrs4v.tags: solar, energy, smart contracts, computer vision

card.desc: Trala is a non-visual web browser that enables users to surf the web on the Google Home.

content.body:
Trala is a web browser optimized for voice-based browsing. For visually impaired or hands-free web users, it is an entirely new way to surf the web. 

Trala's machine learning algorithms analyze the visual structure of websites and convert them into a conversational user interface for the Google Home.

Trala's engine tags all visual elements of a website including images, text, layout, and aesthetics, and translates them into their intuitive verbal equivalents. After tagging these elements, Trala restructures the information in a format that allows users to have a conversation with the website through their Google Home. When web surfers converse with Trala, they experience an audio equivalent of the full sensory experience of a site. 

Trala also optimizes the browsing experience by tracking how users access the information through conversation and learning the most popular actions. Trala automatically optimizes and personalizes the conversational UI to provide efficient access that intuits the user's needs. 

Trala is designed with built-in developer tools so that web developers can easily create robust and beautiful sites that are natively compatible with conversational browsing. In turn, Trala tracks the conversational design choices made by developers to improve its machine learning models and offer a better consumer-side experience for every website.
content.calloutBody: What if the Next Generation of Websites are Screen-Free and Accessible?
content.desc: Trala is a non-visual web browser that enables users to surf the web on the Google Home.
content.why: We believe that there are new ways to experience the web beyond visual browsing. This future is particularly exciting because of its repercussions on the accessibility of information.  Using machine learning, we can also optimize how users access information. Unlike when users access the web through a screen, Trala is free to present information in an order that is personalized to the user.

-L2MUI4dfawKISykj7zu.desc: Trala is a non-visual web browser that enables users to surf the web on the Google Home.
-L2MUI4dfawKISykj7zu.title: Trala

card.desc: FutureCast is a web and mobile application that uses AI to help car owners track diagnostic readings and maintenance of their cars over time, record data to a publicly available, decentralized network, and help car owners and potential buyers make informed decisions about buying, selling, and repairs using predictive output from the network data.

content.body:
Our brief asked us to design a decentralized system of tracking vehicle ownership and maintenance. It focuses on the value proposition to users who maintain the system. Carfax maintains a centralized database that provides buyers and sellers with a vehicle history but the problems with this include questions of accuracy and the methods of data collection. 

We wanted to understand how Carfax works. What information do they provide? How do they collect data? What is their value proposition? What is the user experience like? What we found is that Carfax collects data from a number of third-party sources but primarily relies on insurance companies (accident reports, stolen vehicle records), DMVs (titles, registration, ownership transfers, accident reports, inspection records, etc.), and dealer/repair shops (odometer readings, vehicle sales). Carfax’s marketing strategy preys upon the suspicions of buyers on the used car marketplace.

We conducted interviews with people with experience buying and selling used cars. We learned where Carfax fit in their process of buying and selling, what information they expected to see at every step of the process, and the additional steps they took before completing a deal. This is where it became apparent that viewing the Carfax report is seen as mandatory for many potential buyers in the used car marketplace but also that many seller supplied additional maintenance records. The buyers we spoke to mentioned and described the additional records as more effective than the Carfax report in building trust in their counterpart.

We came up with blockchain technology for cars called SweetChain. With blockchain technology we utilize smart contracts to store driving data on leased or rented cars. This allows a car's driving history to be continuously updated and transactions for rental cars to be executed without the need for humans. In addition, it also protects the privacy of drivers. We tested this technology with two main use cases shown below.

Our app called FutureCast gives owners a way to participate in a network of shared information about the car that they are driving (compared to others of same make, model and year) with the strongest incentive to them being access to an easy-to-maintain system of tracking their own car’s history and maintenance. We learned in our user research that many drivers/sellers on the used car marketplace maintain such records to preserve their resale value and build trust with potential buyers. 

FutureCast is also a response to the questions of accuracy in the Carfax reports. The physical component, which attaches to a car’s OBD port, collects data without any need for user input, minimizing opportunities for bad data. The OBD port automatically stores the car's information on the blockchain. Therefore, if there a car gets into an accident this information is stored on the blockchain. Then, users are incentivized to amend this information with accurate data that will strengthen the knowledge of the network and provide a more complete representation of their vehicle’s condition.

We learned that buyers feel that obtaining a Carfax report is necessary, even if incomplete. A single Carfax report costs $40 but our interviews also uncovered a common practice where sellers will pay for and provide the report to interested buyers. In response to this, FutureCast looks to provide data that is not contained in the Carfax report and gives owners an opportunity to give a more complete history of how their car has been driven and maintained.

FutureCast does not make Carfax obsolete but a mass adoption of the application could decrease buyer reliance on the Carfax report as the sole source of historical information on a used car.

SweetRide differentiates itself from other car borrowing platforms by using machine learning as a way to track and reward safe driving habits. It also allows people to create immutable forms of data via smart contracts that are formed on the BlockChain.
content.calloutTitle: How might we build trust around people's experiences with used cars?
content.desc: SweetChain utilizes smart contracts to store driving data. This allows a car's driving history to be continuously updated and transactions for cars to be executed without the need for humans.
insights: The people we interviewed generally liked the idea of smart contracts as a way to build trust, but still wanted a human to talk to if something went wrong.
content.why: We built these prototypes to examine how people feel about building trust around used cars and what is needed for trust to be built.

-L2M_Q0_iLUu67Xvngcl.desc: SweetChain utilizes smart contracts to store driving data. This allows a car's driving history to be continuously updated and transactions for cars to be executed without the need for humans.
-L2M_Q0_iLUu67Xvngcl.tags: carfax, decentralized web, blockchain, machine learning

card.desc: Design principles for improving the UX of voice-enabled AI agents for the elderly aging in place, through a prototype of a collaborative AI-powered memoir writer.
card.thumbAlt: Design principle playing cards, along with Alexa interaction prototype and companion TV interface

content.body:
We created Voyaging, a voice-based artificial intelligent skill for Alexa. Voyaging acts as a companion for the elderly, listening to them and recording their stories. Ultimately, these stories will become a living and breathing memoir that can be used as a way to reflect or share with family and friends. 

We designed Voyaging as a way to use voice AI agents to help the elderly to record their daily memories, share past memories, and reflect on their life without needing to struggle with tactile inputs like keyboards and pens, which could sometimes be difficult due to arthritis and limited mobility.
content.calloutBody: Design principles for improving the user experience of voice-enabled AI agents for the elderly aging in place
content.calloutTitle: Voice & Aging: Improving Voice UI for Aging Populations
content.desc: Design principles for improving the UX of voice-enabled AI agents for the elderly aging in place, through a prototype of a collaborative AI-powered memoir writer.
insights: When thinking about building an experience for the elderly, we wanted to build something that boosts their quality of life rather than merely offloading menial tasks for them. Current voice based agents are focused on taking instructions and performing tasks for us, such as ordering groceries and turning off lights. However, we realized that making tasks easier via automation may not be the answer here.  During our interviews with elderly and their care takers, we were reminded that elderly, just like others, want to engage in society. Boredom and lack of engagement are critical issues.

We wanted to use voice UIs to boost the elderly’s sense of community and belonging, rather than isolating them further. We played with the idea of collecting stories of the elderly from around the world and use the power of artificial intelligence to organize and swift through these stories, and then share them with the rest of the world. Perhaps a young student in France maybe interested in learning more about Oklahoma and would find stories from there helpful. However, during our conversations we realized many elderly have a much narrower definition of community – their family and existing close friends are their tribe. Unlike millennials, they are less likely to talk to strangers.

One interviewee liked the concept, suggesting that “doing something like this regularly would give her something to do and be therapeutic”. Another said that she would absolutely use it and see it as a companion with “whom [she] can look back on life with, together”.
content.why: As the world population ages, an increasing number of seniors are aging in place and will need support to live independently. Voice-enabled AI agents like Alexa and Siri can use natural language processing and smart design considerations to drastically improve the ease of interacting with technology. Voice UI, a subset of Natural User Interfaces (NUI), can be particularly effective in replacing text input on tiny screens, which can be difficult for users with arthritis, limited mobility, or poor vision. Given the accessibility concerns of this population, defining a playbook of best practices what seniors value and how to best design technological products for their needs will become even more salient in coming years.

-L2MabbTxWEL7FBgL_oL.desc: Design principles for improving the UX of voice-enabled AI agents for the elderly aging in place, through a prototype of a collaborative AI-powered memoir writer.

hero.imageAlt: Hero image for the Voyaging project, featuring the TV user interface and the Echo Dot

card.desc: Peer-to-peer flight insurance powered by Smart Contracts on the Ethereum blockchain and machine-learning generated risk scores for instant-claim free payouts and affordable, variable premium pricing.

content.body:
When a flight is delayed, it sucks. When a flight is canceled, it sucks even more. There is no way to make up for lost time, but we believe that Brella can make a flight delay experience more bearable. 

Brella is a peer-to-peer marketplace for flight insurance, leveraging data-driven risk models for premium pricing and Smart Contracts for instant, claim-free insurance payouts for flight delays or cancellations. Brella offers low variable premiums based on flight price, with an interactive tool to check premium and payouts after entering ticket purchasing. Travelers have options of when and how to engage with Brella. To purchase Brella insurance whenever they are booking a flight, travelers can enable a Chrome extension, which activates at the point of purchase of a flight on an airline website. Additionally, there is a Brella credit card option. For an annual membership fee based on your travel preferences, we offer three credit cards: a smart traveler, avid traveler, and wayfaring traveler; all which provide a variety of coverage for delays and cancellations. 

Part of the underlying technology that powers Brella is an algorithmically generated risk score, which represents the likelihood and magnitude of a flight delay or cancellation. This score uses historical data such as departure/arrival times, airport/airline, and weather, and includes machine learning horsepower to help Brella price premiums and provide insight to our customers to make informed decisions.
content.desc: Peer-to-peer flight delay insurance powered by Smart Contracts on the Ethereum blockchain and machine-learning generated risk scores for instant-claim free payouts and affordable, variable premium pricing.
insights: A clear and simple insurance plan is what people want. Being able to offer an insurance that has no claims and can payout refunds instantly, at a low cost, will motivate travelers to purchase the insurance. This includes travelers who have never purchased flight insurance.
A viable insurance offering requires a sizable pool, to cover initial customers, and to withstand times of peak demand (ex. Holiday season).
People are motivated by low cost premiums and it does not scale proportionally to flight cost. “Delays feel the same regardless of the flight cost”

Payouts should be paid out continuously (calculated by the minute), not at discrete intervals (1 hr and 3 hr). People do not want to hope for a longer delay, a continuous payout eliminates this desire to some extent.

The business is viable based on using average values from the DoT. We modeled the finances for a tiered structure, flat fee, and variable fee. The prices and payouts were in the ranges that would motivate people to purchase this insurance.

It's unclear still whether the risk score for each flight should be made public, to help customers make flight/insurance decisions, or kept private, as insurance companies do today, to avoid discouraging people from buying insurance on low-risk flights.
There is a fine line between decentralized p2p insurance and betting/gambling.
content.why:
Flight delays and cancellations are common annoyances travelers face. We can’t make up for missing a life event or being late to a meeting but we think Brella can ease the pain a bit. By leveraging novel Smart Contract technology, Brella allows customers to get paid when they are delayed or canceled without them having to submit any claims. Because we don’t have to hire people to process claims, this means instant payout and lower premium fees. All payouts accrue by the minute once your delay begins and are sent upon the Smart Contract’s automatic confirmation of flight takeoff and delay time. The first payout starts at 1 hour delay and maxes out at 6 hour delay.

Because Brella is powered by a peer-to-peer insurance model, this allows customers to purchase affordable premiums and receive better payouts. Beyond building the infrastructure for insurance service, we are building a community of travelers. The cost of coverage goes to a common pool to cover payouts for all of the members. Purchasing Brella means you can protect yourself while protecting others. At the end of the year, any money left in the pool goes back to our valued members.

-L2fajdww-lb01kOWT1k.desc: Peer-to-peer flight delay insurance powered by Smart Contracts on the Ethereum blockchain and machine-learning generated risk scores for instant-claim free payouts and affordable, variable premium pricing.
-L2fajdww-lb01kOWT1k.title: Brella: 2

card.desc: A marketplace experience for commercial business customers to responsibly crowd-fund renewable energy development projects through smart contracts.

content.body:
Development companies are building renewable energy projects at a rapid pace. The costs to implement solar arrays and wind farms continue to decrease while the demand for these types of energy grows. With demands increasing, the financing community is getting more creative with how funds become available. Additionally, a reverse "NIMBY" effect is occurring where progressive communities are looking to have solar arrays or wind farms showcased in their areas.

RE-fund seeks to serve this growing demand through its blockchain enabled smart contract technology. Project developers can utilize the technology to gain access to crow-funded resources specifically being collected for the projects they seek to build. Once the project is derived, RE-fund is used to allocate profit share percentages elected by the businesses choosing to participate. Their customers purchase goods or services just as they normally would and a percentage of the transaction earnings go directly to RE-fund's "digital escrow." Once the funding goal is attained, the project can commence!

Funds from RE-fund are deployed subject to project milestones created in the smart contracts. Using a 1MW solar array as an example, the "Build," "Electrify," and "Commission" stages of the project are monitored using computer vision augmented reality (CVAR). By connecting the CVAR to the smart contracts, no middleman or auditor is needed to confirm when milestones are met. Funds are automatically deposited in the developer's account once a "project phase" has been completed. The reverse, funds going back to the businesses, can also be administered should the project not go as contracted.
content.calloutBody: How might we identify the qualities, attributes, and metadata of energy, and connect it to users' and organizations' preferences?
content.desc: A marketplace experience for commercial business customers to responsibly crowd-fund renewable energy development projects through smart contracts.

-L2g1H4vLogbwFrVkerz.desc: A marketplace experience for commercial business customers to responsibly crowd-fund renewable energy development projects through smart contracts.
-L2g1H4vLogbwFrVkerz.title: RE-fund

card.desc: Mesa is an AI-powered tabletop appliance designed to help our elderly loved ones stay connected to family and friends through contextual conversations.

content.body:
In our explorations of how we could augment the standard of living of 'aging in place' individuals, we found that as one ages into a more sedentary situation, family becomes more and more important. 

We asked ourselves the following: How might we use conversational AI to help aging in place individuals stay deeply connected to their families, regardless of distance?

To this end, we built Mesa, the first purpose-built solution designed to help our elderly loved ones stay connected to family and friends, no matter how far the distance. As an elegant tabletop appliance built on Amazon Alexa's powerful voice commands, Mesa is designed for senior accessibility, relying on voice controls to help families with vision, hearing, or mobility issues.
content.calloutBody: Mesa is a conversational AI for the elderly, delivered through a physical tabletop centerpiece.
content.desc: Mesa is an AI-powered tabletop appliance designed to help our elderly loved ones stay connected to family and friends through contextual conversations.
insights: In the balance between AI as a channel for communication and a sentient entity by itself, acting as an active/personable channel gives more emphasis to the real human interactions.
Environmental factors, such as light, sound, etc. can be used to set a particular tone for a conversation -- even if that conversation is being led by an AI.
Giving an AI presence is important for both giving an individual a target to speak to and grounding the experience in the familiar.
Pulling from the social context of the person engaging with the AI can help to create more grounded, realistic experiences and set conversation topics.
Truly conversational AI might be achieved through a combination of topic analysis (content) and sentiment analysis (context).
content.why:
As the world population ages, an increasing number of seniors are aging in place and will need support to live independently. Voice-enabled AI agents like Alexa and Siri can use natural language processing and smart design considerations to drastically improve the ease of interacting with technology. Voice UI, a subset of Natural User Interfaces (NUI), can be particularly effective in replacing text input on tiny screens, which can be difficult for users with arthritis, limited mobility, or poor vision. Given the accessibility concerns of this population, defining a playbook of best practices what seniors value and how to best design technological products for their needs will become even more salient in coming years.

An additional concern for this project was the goal of making this product fit naturally into the lives of the elderly. To do this, we wanted to a) focus on the people that they care about (their family) and b) design around an established ritual in their lives: meal time. For the latter, we played with the concept of the dinner table itself, and how this physical object could be enhanced to set the mood of communal storytelling and give the artificial intelligence a sense of presence.

-L2g7aDwcIuCsXRlYrts.desc: Mesa is an AI-powered tabletop appliance designed to help our elderly loved ones stay connected to family and friends through contextual conversations.

hero.imageAlt: The full Mesa setup, featuring the centerpiece and all of its hardware.

card.desc: Cryptonite is a game to collect and battle crypto-collectible planets. Each collectable planet is tradable, evolvable, and uniquely built on the Ethereum platform.

content.body:
Cryptonite is a game built on Ethereum that lets players collect and battle the planets to create the strongest planet. Intrigued by the emerging world of cryptocollectibles, like CryptoKitties, we saw an opportunity to create an interactive experience that goes beyond collecting and into game play.

In Cryptonite, planets are the basic collectible units in the universe. Each player is issued a planet when they sign up with an Ethereum address. Planets can be bought, sold, or grown, by placing them into battle with other's planets.

When users are ready to play, they select an environment they believe their planet might succeed in, where they want to earn new resources. When others enter the same environment, the planets battle.

Whoever wins the battle (a combination of experience and luck) earns new resources, and their planet grows to acknowledge their win. Over time, we expect to build a marketplace of these tradable planets, and unlock new features and resources as planets grow.

Cryptonite explores how we might combine the provenance, provable ownership and scarcity elements of a blockchain system with the interactive capabilities of gaming.

A long time ago in a galaxy far, far away...
You live in a universe with limited resources
You have to build your own empire by collecting and battling the planets
You find the best environment to win battles for the much-needed resources
You form your own galaxy with planets that are powerful enough

How much is your universe worth?

card.desc: Giving an intuition for people to know how a change in a city will look like by comparing to other cities.

content.body:
CityMatch is a tool to intuitively compare changes in a city with other cities according to different parameters. The intent of comparing cities relating different variables to a given change takes into consideration the empathy aspect of how a city feels like to each user. The data can then be consumed in a more relatable and faster way. It's easier for us to grasp how a new development will impact a city when we visualize, for example, that a change in Redwood City would cause new traffic level that it would make it look like Mountain View or if a change in public transportation will make it more similar to Palo Alto. It doesn't necessarily require having a high usability index, but rather to have a better way for people to understand how a proposed change transforms a current place or system.

This tool not only serves as a communicative presentation tool for non-expert users, but also can serve as a formative addition to the architect/urban planner's design process. By reframing the question from optimizing a specific parameter as defined by a client to thinking about how a design or development change evokes an intangible sense of place, this tool allows designers to think about change beyond conceptual models and numbers (i.e. applying a more "human-centered" approach to the urban designer/architect's design process). We define 10 sliding input variables (which arguably have greatest impact on determining how a neighborhood "feels") for each neighborhood in our user interface, which allows for intuitive engagement and easily iterative application.

We leverage rich vector space embedding of cities with temporally coherent datasets to estimate the impacts of changes to those cities, and generalize those changes in such a way as to afford easy assessment of the impacts of similar changes in other cities. The tool is designed to be dataset agnostic, meaning that any city data, or even non city data, with arbitrary dimensionality, can be leveraged in a similar manner. We believe that the more data that is added to this model, the more useful it will be.

Furthermore the features we demonstrated about communicating changes to a city through a map projection use style transfer through deep learning to show how the stylistic elements of one environment would augment another environment.
content.desc: An AI tool for city planners to design better cities and urban areas, by anchoring suggested changes to other cities.
content.why: CityMatch is for city planners, urban developers, city governments, architects, and urban change consultants, especially in the moment when they need to convey a message to clients and/or to the public about a particular change in a city. Today, they use small scale models and presentations, but it's hard to convey the impact of how changes will feel when planning.

-L2h0HnEUsFTMNRBvS-7.desc: An AI tool for city planners to design better cities and urban areas, by anchoring suggested changes to other cities.
-L2h0HnEUsFTMNRBvS-7.title: citymatch

card.desc: Cleo is a hand-held, screen-free device that enables users to navigate non-visual audio experiences created by developers for Trala.

content.body:
Cleo is a hand-held, screen-free device that enables users to easily navigate audio websites. The gestures for Cleo are also compatible with the Myo for screen-free and hands-free users. For visually impaired or screen free users, Cleo enables an entirely new way to surf and skim audio websites developed through Trala. 

Cleo was inspired by the main pain-point of screen-readers: how might we reimagine the experience of browsing the content of a website in a manner that is inherently non-visual and screen free, so that visually impaired or screen-less users experience all the richness of the site without a loss of fidelity to the content? While the normal experience of the internet is limited to the two-dimensional actions of point-and-click, scroll, and visual cues, Cleo brings Trala’s audio browsing experience to life by imagining a screen-free experience of the web. 

Cleo was designed to enable a specific set of gestures that screen readers make difficult. Firstly, it allows a user to skim through content summaries as one might visually skim the text on a page. Secondly, it enables a user to ‘skim’ the actions and links on a page in a separate menu, which reimagines the spatially-situated “call-to-action” buttons on websites. Finally, while a screen reader would use an automated voice to read through chunks of text, Cleo works with Trala’s developer kit to provide users with a podcast-quality sound experience complete with branding through background music and human voice acting. On the Myo, Cleo allows the user to scroll through the page for content, using hand gestures while performing tasks that require both hands like cooking. Using the wii-inspired remote control, Cleo allows users to navigate the content non-linearly using click-wheel-like sliders and wii-inspired trigger buttons.
content.calloutBody: How might we deliver an easier browsing experience for Trala's native audio websites?
content.desc: Cleo is a set of interaction paradigms that effectively provide non-linear navigation for audio-based web browsing experiences. It is an extension to our previous project, an audio-based web browser called Trala.
insights: Conversational interfaces are delightful but hard to sustain in longer interactions.
content.why: Our group wanted to continue to build on the imaginary Trala empire, so we chose to create two  screen-free interfaces that would be able to access the native audio experiences created by developers through Trala.

-L43C7lIXs3kxNbj3AJu.desc: Cleo is a set of interaction paradigms that effectively provide non-linear navigation for audio-based web browsing experiences. It is an extension to our previous project, an audio-based web browser called Trala.
-L43C7lIXs3kxNbj3AJu.title: Cleo

card.desc:
A decentralized platform to crowd-source
civilian data for Amber Alerts.

content.body:
Chain Reaction is a system to triangulate camera "sightings" of vehicles under Amber Alert.

Despite being a system built around incidents of paramount importance — a child abduction — the current Amber Alert system isn’t fulling leveraging the participation of civilians. Currently, the program is based on mobile phone alerts for opted-in participants and highway billboards.

Taking action on an Amber Alert or another alert of its kind requires civilians to keep their eyes peeled and remember a long sequence of numbers. This poses a number of obstacles for many people that do want to help. A high barrier for participation lends itself to a number of unintended consequences: distracted driving, good samaritan apathy, and ultimately low participation rates.

ChainReaction leverages the wealth of vehicle data available to be passively collected by the general public in order to assist in the recovery of abducted children.

Our prototype uses open-source OCR technology to recognize license plates, pushing the car’s location to a blockchain middleware only in the event of a match with an ongoing amber alert.

We replicated a dashcam/rear view camera with a web cam, testing it out with images of street scenes with visible license plates. Additionally, all cars under 10,000 pounds will be required to have a rear-view camera following May 2018. This alowed us to have a pretty good idea of what was feasible. This in addition to existing after-market add-ons such as the Nexar Dashcam allow users to use their own cellphones as a dashcam.

Furthermore, we surfaced the data through a web interface intended for use by law enforcement agents. The interface allowed law enforcement agents to see hits on Amber Alerts in real time, displaying geographic information in connection with specific plates and cases. The information was displayed through an interactive map, and cases were searchable to allow for a more specific view on hits for a specific case over time. Through a civilian opt-in system similar to the mobile Amber Alert system of today, the platform opens up access to crowd-sourced data through avenues currently as a whole inaccessible by any single party. This gives value to the data that any person can collect and provides structure for the data to be passed between parties. Although not crucial to the structure of the prototype and the platform in general, having a blockchain middleware allowed for several benefits.

In interviewing law enforcement, we understood that there existed multiple barriers to trust in creating a system that aided law-enforcement. People were concerned about how their information was being handled and accessed. A distributed ledger system allowed for more transparency in the structure. Additionally, with a larger source of data, hashing could provide a layer of anonymity for data providers. Multiple hits on the same location from multiple sources bolster information in ways single-source tips can not, while still allowing room for the provider’s identity to be concealed. This is a vast improvement for all parties compared to the current system, where tippers for Amber Alerts need to be personally verified by law enforcement personnel.

Additionally, a distributed ledger system provides a much lower cost barrier for implementation than a centrally hosted database. This would allow different jurisdictions to have more leeway in their ability to use the system, rather than having a large cost upfront.
content.desc:
A decentralized platform to crowd-source
civilian data for Amber Alerts.
content.why:
With the infrastructure for a platform for exchanging data built, it’s important to think about the prototype’s implications for the future.

Although we constrained the use case to Amber Alerts and law enforcement (allowing us to structure the marketplace without having to factor in incentivizations), potential monetary exchange could create an ecosystem of car locating for bounties. Additionally, the platform could then be expanded for uses outside of license plate information: GPS location is valuable for mapping and city information, cam footage in general has enormous potential for analysis, and more. Gradually allowing for additional players to enter the marketplace outside of different law enforcement entities would allow the data to take on more value and be reused in multiple contexts.

With the creation of a crowd-sourced data sharing platform with future plans of opening into a wider marketplace, the initial providing of civilian data could pressure additional entities to enter the marketplace, both as purchasers and as providers. Creating competition regarding data could shift OEMs’ protection of the data they collect by allowing them to assess with an immediate monetary value.

Additionally, thinking towards a future of autonomous vehicles data collection might shift from driver opt-in to fleet manager optin. This would have interesting implications in how data is managed and owned.

-L4Dbk62oIutuyI4Dbt9.desc:
A decentralized platform to crowd-source
civilian data for Amber Alerts.
-L4Dbk62oIutuyI4Dbt9.title: Chain Reaction

1.desc: An interactive prototype using Nomad datastreams at our biannual Blueprint event. The prototype simulated a smart energy grid that took in data from internet connected solar panels that sensed ambient light levels dispersed in multiple locations in a city. The data streams were aggregated and a signal was sent to a peaker plant to intelligently turn on or off based on how much light was around the city at any given time.

2.desc: Attendees could simulate cloud cover and block lights from the sensors in one or more locations to watch as Nomad intelligently reacted to light loss around the city and turned on the peaker plant to balance the grid.

roe689_13.desc: Our system has several layers -- one of them being battery storage allocation at the car level. Thinking of an EV battery as 2 batteries, one for driving, and one for grid arbitrage, we want to figure out how much space to allocate for each use. One approach we tried is using past driving data to predict a driver’s destinations by identifying “clusters” of their location coordinate data on previous days, using a machine learning method called k-means clustering. Given a specific car and day of the week, we can find the destinations of that car, and furthermore, the energy required to reach all of those destinations. Given that calculation, we can allocate the required amount of power for driving to the car, and use the rest for energy arbitrage.
